title: Comparative Politics of the Post-Soviet States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative examination of politics and government among the 15 successor states to the Soviet Union, focusing on variation in the development of institutions, the degree of democratization, state strength, and economic prosperity. Topics include mass politics and political action institutions, nationalism and identity politics, and economic transformations since the end of the USSR in 1991.

title: Authoritarianism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class identifies similarities and differences among authoritarian regimes.   The first half identifies the tools authoritarian leaders use to stay in power, and the second half examines the biggest threats to the stability of authoritarian regimes.  Students have the opportunity to explore one authoritarian regime in greater detail as part of a semester long research project.

title: The Politics of India
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will introduce students to politics in the world's largest democracy, focusing on themes both important to India and to a general study of politics in developing countries. How does one make sense of democracy in a poor multi-ethnic setting? How has democratic politics shaped and been shaped by a society divided along a caste, class, linguistic and religious lines? And how well has India fared in promoting economic development, both growth and equity?

title: Improving Governance in Developing Countries: What can We Learn from Experiments?
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Experimental research is an exciting new part of the political science toolkit. This course will introduce students to a number of field and natural experiments that have been conducted in developing countries to study governance failures. Can such experiments help us to understand how social and ethnic divisions prevent cooperation on problems affecting the common good? how corruption, vote-buying,  and diversion of public funds can be overcome? how elites might become more accountable to voters? how opposition parties can be made more effective? how the capacity to deliver public goods might be created in places where it appears that the state has failed? Students will get the chance to collaborate on designing their own experiments to generate insight into these and other urgent issues facing developing countries.

title: East Asian Political Economies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why did the economies of Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan grow so rapidly in the post-war period? And why do they seem so fragile now? This course will examine the economic policies, economic practices, and state-society relations that have shaped the past, present, and future of the Northeast Asian capitalist economies. It will seek to clarify the ways in which different political and economic systems deal with common problems through a careful comparative analysis of change and continuity in such areas as industrial policy, financial regulation, industrial organization, and labor relations.

title: Government and Politics of Modern Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to political life in contemporary Japan. Explores the interaction of political parties, the bureaucracy, interest groups, the media and the government, with an emphasis on the ongoing transformation of the Japanese political system. Special attention will be paid to contemporary issues, such as economic policy, social welfare programs, national security, disaster response, and administrative reform.

title: Government and Politics of Modern Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to political life in contemporary Japan. Explores the interaction of political culture, leadership, political parties, ideology, bureaucracy, and big business as forces in political life from 1868, with emphasis on the present, when the country looms as a major economic power. Special attention to the role of the state and the private sector in the Japanese economy; the nature of Japanese democracy; social conflict and Japanese approaches to its resolution; the impact of market opening pressures and other external forces on Japanese politics and policies today.

title: Government and Politics of Modern Japan

Explores the interaction of political parties, bureaucracy, interest groups, the media, leadership and ideology, with an emphasis in the ongoing transformation of the Japanese political system. Special attention to current policy issues, including industrial policy, social policy, trade, defense, foreign policy, administrative and political reform.

title: Japanese Politics in an Era of Transformation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course uncovers the inner workings of Japanese politics in the post-war era. Who has power? What explains the long LDP dominance? What was the basis for the long economic miracle? A substantial portion of the course focuses on key transformations in the 1990s: the long economic crisis, the rise of civil society, the foreign policy debates, the see-saw of party politics, the protracted political and administrative reforms, and the Koizumi period.

title: The Political Economy of Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the history of Japan's political economy, its recent success and its current problems. Why did Japan succeed in becoming the first non-Western society to industrialize? Did Japan develop a particular brand of capitalism? What role did the political system play? What are its advantages and disadvantages of the Japanese model? Can it overcome the current technological changes and global pressures? Or is it no longer a viable model to emulate?

title: Political Economy of Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the political foundations and economic achievements of modern Japan. The first portion of the course explores the historical roots of Japan's contemporary political economy. The second deals with the evolving roles and functions of the principal political-economic institutions of postwar Japan.

title: Government and Politics in South Asia: India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: South Asia, whose population exceeds one billion, has had a striking variety of political regimes since independence from British colonial rule: democratic regimes in India and Sri Lanka, authoritarian systems in Pakistan and Bangladesh, and monarchies in Nepal and Bhutan. Religious and ethnic diversity is also remarkable. Major religious groups in the region include Hindus, Muslims, Buddhists, and Sikhs. Linguistic groups are even more numerous. Topics include: the national movement, political parties, electoral behavior, the caste system, ethnic and religious conflict, institution building and institutional erosion, politics of the rural and industrial sector, and new social movements.

title: Political Economy of East & Southeast Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the interplay between politics and economics in East and Southeast Asia. We will cover a wide range of countries (Japan, South Korea, China, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam) and a wide variety of topics (industrialization, colonization, World War II, state-led development, the Asian Financial Crisis, and late development).

title: Political Economy of Modern South Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the political economy of development in South Asia, particularly India, in the half century since independence. Themes include the evolving party system, the public sector, the army, rural and urban interest groups, federalism and external influences.

title: Political Economy of Modern South Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the political economy of development in South Asia, particularly India, in the half century since independence. Themes include the evolving party system, the public sector, the army, rural and urban interest groups, federalism and external influences.

title: Government & Politics of China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a broad introduction to the main issues of contemporary Chinese politics and social change. The course is divided into two sections:  the first section covers the period from the end of the last imperial dynasty to the end of the Cultural Revolution in 1976.  The second section examines the last thirty years of economic reform, looking at both how the reforms began and how they were sustained.

title: Government and Politics of China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: General introduction to the politics of contemporary China. Basic objectives are to provide a working knowledge of Chinese political programs and practices, and to encourage a critical evaluation of the positive and negative aspects of China's socialist experiment.

title: Government and Politics of China

title: The Government and Politics of China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the politics of the People's Republic that examines the origins of the revolution and the consolidation of Communist power. Emphasis is on the major political and economic campaigns since 1949, such as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution; the function of ideology; the role of the Communist Party; the position of the bureaucracy and the personalized nature of control; and the impact of reforms instituted after Mao's death.

title: The Government and Politics of China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the politics of the People's Republic of China built around the theme of the Chinese leadership's search for a model of national development. Focus on the conflicts, policies, and changes generated by this search. The course begins by reviewing the rise to power of the Chinese communists against the background of the modern Chinese revolution; it then surveys the development of the People's Republic by dividing it into major subperiods and analyzing their main trends.

title: The Government and Politics of China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the politics of the People's Republic that examines the origins of the revolution and the consolidation of Communist power. Emphasis is on the major political and economic campaigns since 1949, such as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution; the function of ideology; the role of the Communist Party; the position of the bureaucracy and the personalized nature of control; and the impact of reforms instituted after Mao's death.

title: Government and Politics of China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: General introduction to the politics of contemporary China. Basic objectives are to provide a working knowledge of Chinese political programs and practices, and to encourage a critical evaluation of the positive and negative aspects of China's socialist experiment.

title: State and Peasant in Contemporary China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An analytical survey of grassroots politics in the People's Republic of China. The focus is on the post-Mao period of reform, including post-Tiananmen developments. Topics include decollectivization, market reform, and fiscal decentralization and their impact on state power and the pursuit of local interests. Government 1280 or equivalent recommended.

title: State and Peasant in Contemporary China
subject: GOV

Topics include decollectivization, market reform, and fiscal decentralization and their impact on state power and the pursuit of local interests. Government 1280 or equivalent recommended.

title: Making Revolution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative examination of the genesis and maturing of the revolutionary armies of, primarily, the Bolsheviks, the Chinese, and Vietnamese communists and Castro's 26th July movement, with an analysis of their postrevolutionary roles.

title: Making Revolution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative examination of the genesis and maturing of the revolutionary armies of, primarily, the Bolsheviks, the Chinese, and Vietnamese communists and Castro's 26th July movement, with an analysis of their postrevolutionary roles.

title: The Military in Modern Chinese Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Organized around two interrelated themes - the modernization of the Chinese army since 1949 and civil-military relations - the course is comprised of three parts. The introduction reviews the role of the military in modern Chinese politics. The second part surveys the Maoist period with particular emphasis on the dominance of the "people's war" doctrine and military involvement in politics. The final part analyzes the army's post-Mao modernization - its technological progress, disengagement from politics, and renewed involvement.

title: Central Asia and the Caucasus: Empire and Sovereignty
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how identity concepts are mobilized in Central Asian politics. Focuses on post-Soviet Central Asia, while providing background in historical and comparative contexts. Topics include: formation of current national, regional and religious identities, national ideologies as part of state-building and regime loyalty, and roles of identity in opposition mobilization, conflicts, and international relations. Theories of political identity are explored as developed in the literature on Central Asia and comparative cases.

title: Politics of Identity in Central Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how identity concepts are mobilized in Central Asian politics. Focuses on post-Soviet Central Asia, while providing background in historical and comparative contexts. Topics include: formation of current national, regional and religious identities, national ideologies as part of state-building and regime loyalty, and roles of identity in opposition mobilization, conflicts, and international relations. Theories of political identity are explored as developed in the literature on Central Asia and comparative cases. Intended primarily for advanced undergraduates and graduate students; some background in Islam and/or the former Soviet Bloc desirable.

title: Politics of Identity in Central Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how identity concepts are mobilized in Central Asian politics. Focuses on post-Soviet Central Asia, while providing background in historical and comparative contexts. Topics include: formation of current national, regional and religious identities, national ideologies as part of state-building and regime loyalty, and roles of identity in opposition mobilization, conflicts, and international relations. Theories of political identity are explored as developed in the literature on Central Asia and comparative cases. Intended primarily for advanced undergraduates and graduate students; some background in Islam and/or the former Soviet Bloc desirable.

title: Contemporary Chinese Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides a broad overview of contemporary Chinese politics, examining both the Maoist revolutionary period and the post-Mao reform period. In addition to analyzing Chinese politics in comparative perspective, the course also introduces students to a variety of influential Chinese political theorists to gain an insider's perspective on the country's problems and potential.

title: Contemporary Chinese Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides a broad overview of contemporary Chinese politics, examining both the Maoist revolutionary period and the post-Mao reform period. In addition to analyzing Chinese politics in comparative perspective, the course also introduces students to a variety of influential Chinese political theorists to gain an insider's perspective on the country's problems and potential.

title: China’s Economic Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How has China achieved high economic growth rates for 40 years?  Have the post-Mao economic reforms created a market economy, or a new form of state capitalism?  To answer these questions, this course explores the causes and consequences of China’s market reforms, placing the Chinese experience in comparative perspective.  The focus of this course will be on the politics of economic reform: seeking to understand how and why different policies have been adopted in China, to analyze their impact, and to seek lessons for reform in other countries.

title: Democratization in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys the shift from authoritarian rule to democratic government in Latin America in the 1980s. Compares the breakdown of democracy, authoritarian rule, and redemocratization in countries at different levels of economic and political development, and analyzes factors conducive to and obstructive of democratic consolidation. Topics include the roles of the military, political parties, and social classes and actors, and the future prospects for democracy under economic crisis.

title: Institutions and Accountability in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Modern Latin American governments are generally elected, but whether they meet democratic standards varies from country to country, and depending on the elements of democracy under consideration. This course examines the performance of Latin America's political regimes in areas such as elections and representation, transparency in policymaking, decentralization, and corruption. It addresses the central questions of whether the goal of accountability of public officials to citizens has been realized, where it has not, and why.

title: Democratization in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes prospects for the consolidation of democracy in Latin America, and the conditions which favor democratic rule and the process of democratization. Focuses on transitions from authoritarian rule in the 1980s from both theoretical and empirical perspectives. Examines the roles of various political and social actors and institutions in democratization, including the military, Catholic Church, social movements, and political parties. Considers effects of economic constraints and market-oriented policy reforms on new democracies.

title: Institutions and Accountability in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Modern Latin American governments are generally elected, but whether they meet democratic standards varies from country to country, and depending on the elements of democracy under consideration. This course examines the performance of Latin America's political regimes in areas such as elections and representation, transparency in policymaking, decentralization, and corruption. It addresses the central questions of whether the goal of accountability of public officials to citizens has been realized, where it has not, and why.

title: The Politics of Social Policy in Brazil
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Assesses Brazil's social policy failures and successes, focusing on education, health, social security, and poverty alleviation. Introduces students to Brazil's political institutions; political and social actors; and state reforms. Identifies factors, including program design, power of privileged groups, and widespread political clientelism in the social services, that have contributed to Brazil's weak social welfare state and policy failures, and examines changes that have improved social policy outputs and the lingering obstacles to further progress.

title: The Politics of Social Policy in Brazil

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Assesses Brazil's social policy failures and successes, focusing on education, health, social security, and poverty alleviation. title: Politics in Brazil
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces students to politics and political change in Latin America's largest country. Outlines historical perspectives and contemporary challenges, and examines political institutions, civil society, and contemporary politics and policy. Emphasis is on how institutional change, decentralization, and the mobilization of civil society have interacted to change the trajectory of Brazilian politics by deepening citizen participation, strengthening political parties and political representation, reforming social policy, guaranteeing citizenship rights, and ultimately reducing inequality and deepening democracy.

title: Democracy and Dictatorship in 20th-Century Spain
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores patterns of development and change in 20th-century Spanish politics through periods of democracy, dictatorship, civil war, and, ultimately, a peaceful regime transition to democracy. Emphasis both on distinctive aspects of Spanish political developments and on broader theoretical and conceptual lessons drawn from analyzing this national case. Consideration of the emergence and virtual disappearance of anarcho-syndicalism and maximalist socialism; of the experience of revolution and civil war; of four decades of authoritarian rule; and of transition to democracy by negotiated reform.

title: Latin American Politics and Economy in the Long Run
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines political and economic change in Latin America. It focuses on five macro-processes: the creation of states and markets in 1850-1900, the design of oligarchic power-sharing institutions at the beginning of the 20th century, industrialization and the emergence of mass politics in 1920-1950, the widespread collapse of democracy and establishment of military regimes in 1960-1980, and contemporary processes of democratization and economic liberalization. In the search for causes and consequences, we consider multiple theoretical perspectives.

title: Latin American Politics and Economy in the Long Run
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines political and economic change in Latin America. It focuses on five macro-processes: the creation of states and markets in 1850-1900, the design of oligarchic power-sharing institutions at the beginning of the 20th century, industrialization and the emergence of mass politics in 1920-1950, the widespread collapse of democracy and establishment of military regimes in 1960-1980, and contemporary processes of democratization and economic liberalization. title: Comparative Politics in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines dynamics of political and economic changes in modern Latin America, focusing on Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Cuba, Mexico and Venezuela. Topics include the rise of populism and import-substituting industrialization, revolutions and revolutionary movements, the causes and consequences of military rule, the politics of economic reform, democratic transitions, and democratic consolidation. The course analyzes these phenomena from a variety of different theoretical perspectives, including cultural, dependency, institutionalist, and leadership-centered approaches.

title: Comparative Politics in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines dynamics of political and economic changes in modern Latin America, focusing on Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Cuba, Mexico and Venezuela. title: Comparative Politics of Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focus on political cleavages and cleavage systems and on mass-based political groups (parties, unions, peasant federations, ethnicity, religion, private foreign investment, industrialization) comparatively and through time in eight Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries in the Americas. Analysis of the expansion of mass political participation, elections, the impact of the military and of recent democratization, and the impact of international factors on these actors and issues. Government 1295 has sections in English. Foreign Cultures 18, which is taught at the same time, has sections in Spanish. Core credit is granted only for Foreign Cultures 18.

title: Comparative Politics of Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Latin America has recently witnessed a shift toward political democracy, neoliberal reforms, and new forms of popular protest. These contemporary developments seemingly contrast with a history of authoritarianism, repression, import-substitution industrialization, and revolutionary movements. Competing theoretical explanations of these historical and contemporary patterns of political regimes, types of development, and popular participation v. protest are analyzed by looking at Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries in the Americas.

title: Comparative Politics in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines dynamics of political and economic change in modern Latin America, focusing on Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Cuba, Mexico, and Venezuela. Topics include the rise of populism and import-substituting industrialization, revolutions and revolutionary movements, the causes and consequences of military rule, the politics of economic reform, democratic transitions, and democratic consolidation. The course analyzes these phenomena from a variety of different theoretical perspectives, including cultural, dependency, institutionalist, and leadership-centered approaches. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Societies of the World or the Core area requirement for Social Analysis.

title: Comparative Politics in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the dynamics of political and economic change in 20th-century Latin America, exploring the causes and consequences of the phenomena we have conceptualized as populism, import substituting industrialization (ISI), bureaucratic authoritarianism, democracy, and neoliberalism. Examines Latin American politics from the collapse of oligarchic rule and the emergence of populism and ISI in the 1930s and 1940s to the widespread collapse of democracy and establishment of military regimes in the 1960s and 1970s, to the contemporary processes of democratization and economic liberalization. The course compares different theoretical approaches in an effort to explain both these general processes of change and important differences across Latin American countries.

title: Comparative Politics in Latin America
subject: GOV

Explores the construction and failure of populist democracy and state-led industrialization; the politics, policies, and collapse of authoritarian regimes; and the transformations of militaries, civil societies, political representation, and state-market relations that have accompanied the process of redemocratization.

title: Comparative Politics in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Latin America has recently witnessed a shift towards political democracy, market reforms, and new forms of popular protest. These developments mark a significant departure from politics that just a decade ago was generally characterized by some combination of repressive authoritarian regimes, state-led economic development, and revolutionary movements. This course analyzes these developments in Latin America by examining competing arguments about the foundations of democratic, authoritarian, and revolutionary regimes in the region; associated patterns of economic development; institutional forms of participation and exclusion; and the evolution of popular protest.

title: Contemporary Mexican Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes Mexico's change from an authoritarian polity with a command-and-control economy to an electoral democracy with a mostly liberalized economy over the past three decades. Focuses on Mexico's political economy with and emphasis on its parties, voters, public opinion, and interest groups. Provides historical context and overviews the nation's most pressing policy challenges, including poverty, inequality, and the rule of law.

title: Contemporary Mexican Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes Mexico's change from an authoritarian polity with a command-and-control economy to an electoral democracy with a mostly liberalized economy over the past three decades. Focuses on Mexico's political economy with and emphasis on its parties, voters, public opinion, and interest groups. Provides historical context and overviews the nation's most pressing policy challenges, including poverty, inequality, and the rule of law.

title: Corruption and Quality of Governance in a Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Trustworthy, reliable, impartial, uncorrupted, and competent government institutions are widely regarded as important for democratic, social, and economic development. This course will address three questions: How should the quality of government be conceptualized and measured? When, how, and for what does it matter? What can countries do to improve the quality of their governing institutions?

title: Corruption and Quality of Governance in a Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Trustworthy, reliable, impartial, uncorrupted, and competent government institutions are widely regarded as important for democratic, social, and economic development. This course will address three questions: How should the quality of government be conceptualized and measured? When, how, and for what does it matter? What can countries do to improve the quality of their governing institutions?

title: The Politics of Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Intended as a broad survey of the legislative branch of the American government. Topics include representation and elections, party leadership, committee power, rules and procedures, and inter-branch relations. Special attention devoted to changes in Congress, as well as current political and scholarly controversies such as congressional war powers, the influence of parties, and campaign finance. The place of Congress in the US separation of powers system will be a theme throughout the course.

title: The Politics of Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A broad survey of the legislative branch of the American government. Topics include committee power, party leadership, rules and procedures, legislative elections, and inter-branch relations.

title: Legislative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a thorough survey of what scholars know about legislative elections and legislative organization. Its focus is both descriptive and theoretic; the expectation is that legislative outcomes are the product of systematic calculation by goal-directed political actors. However, we will also consider normative concerns_i.e., does Congress function ^'^'well.''

title: Congress, Politics, Power, and Preference
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the structure and operation of the U.S. Congress with emphasis on changes in the internal distribution of power in the postwar period. Topics include changing electoral basis, constituency relations, role of committees and subcommittees, paths to leadership, and presidential-congressional leadership.

title: The Politics of Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: With crucial elections in November 2006, and with the Bush Administration's agenda now highly constrained, attention returns to the Congress. Government 1300 explores theories of representation, the history of Congress, campaigns and elections, lobbying, institutional rules, committees, party leadership, and how Congress works with other institutions. Taught by the chair of Harvard's program for Newly Elected Members of Congress, Government 1300 will bring elements of the elections - and the subsequent 110th Congress - into the classroom.

title: The Politics of Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A broad survey of the legislative branch of the American government. Topics include committee power, party leadership, rules and procedures, legislative elections, and inter-branch relations.

title: The Politics of Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the ways in which the electoral system as well as the rules and institutions of the House of Representatives and the Senate interact to produce law. Emphasis is put on placing current legislative behavior --campaigning and campaign finance reform, filibustering, logrolling, and vote trading -- in historical and analytic perspective.

title: The Politics of Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Government 1300 explores theories of representation, the history of Congress, campaigns and elections, lobbying, institutional rules, committees, party leadership, and how Congress works with other institutions.

title: Congress: Power and Preferences
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the structure and operation of the U.S. Congress with emphasis on changes in the internal distribution of power. Topics include changing electoral basis, constituency relations, role of committees and subcommittees, paths to leadership, and presidential-congressional leadership in the era of the Republican "Contract with America."

title: Introduction to Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course seeks to provide students with a comprehensive introduction to Congress. The first half of the course addresses the nuts and bolts of how Congress operates in terms of foundational theories, the committee system, congressional elections, and congressional procedures. In the second half of the course we will apply this knowledge to an exploration of how and why Congress pays attention to certain issues rather than others. Students are encouraged to view Congress not only as an institution unto itself but also as an institution that interacts with a variety of actors to shift public policy.

title: Race, Film, and American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Race, Film, and American Politics is a course that examines the multifaceted ways in which racial and ethnic identity has been represented in American film. Drawing on political science, sociology, anthropology, and film and media studies, we will assess the ways in which the mainstream media in the United States — focusing primarily on the Hollywood film industry — has portrayed different population groups and shaped our understanding of what it means to be American. The course will address issues of social stratification, and consider the intersection of identity and politics by analyzing historical shifts in cinematic representation in the United States.

title: Race, Film, and American Politics

The course will address issues of social stratification, and consider the intersection of identity and politics by analyzing historical shifts in cinematic representation in the United States.

title: American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course addresses what makes the US special as a society and a culture. How are the institutional arrangements of the country and its dominant beliefs related? It also discusses how divergent understandings of American realities may inform contrasting proposals for the reforms needed to realize American ideals more fully. We confront clashes of vision and method in the social sciences and humanities. Ethnic diversity provides one focus among others for these concerns. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as PAL-220 and with the Law School as 30500-31.

title: State and Local Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines states and localities. Considers the particular tasks and dilemmas facing states and cities, and scrutinizes the complex interactions between governments that characterize much of what occurs on the state and local level. Topics include regional political culture, intergovernmental grants, state parties, and state and local political economy.

title: State and Local Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines states and localities. Considers the particular tasks and dilemmas facing states and cities, and scrutinizes the complex interactions between governments that characterize much of what occurs on the state and local level. title: Electoral Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Elections are the foundation of American democracy. This course focuses on the simple questions: Who wins elections and why? Answers to these questions guide the interpretation of elections and evaluation of how well government represents the public preferences. The first half of the course presents the basic explanations and models of elections and voting behavior, and asks students to make their best forecast of the election. The second half of the course will examine why the models worked or didn't work. Students will learn how to interpret and analyze surveys and other data, to estimate models and make forecasts, and test arguments and models using predictions.

title: The Role of the Jury in a Democratic Society
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: We will examine the history and current practices of the U.S. criminal jury system. We will focus on important Constitutional cases that shaped our jury system as well as ongoing debates about jury reform. Section meetings will take the form of jury deliberations, where students will be asked to make difficult decisions about law and justice in the context of a particular case.

title: Constitutional Interpretation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of American constitutional interpretation. The approach is partly historical and partly analytical, with special attention to the nature of the judicial process and the role of the Supreme Court in American government.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers what various social scientific models of the court system, and of the Supreme Court in particular, can teach us about how the Court makes decisions on issues concerning the constitution. Topics include federalism, civil rights and liberties, and the constitutional powers of the president.

title: Civil Liberties in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Civil liberties and civil rights in the US, with special attention to the political theory implicit in constitutional doctrines. Topics include: (1) freedom of religion; (2) freedom of speech; (3) privacy, including issues related to abortion, medical care and assisted suicide; (4) racial and gender discrimination and affirmative action; and (5) terrorism and national security.

title: Civil Liberties and the American Ideal of Freedom
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a coherent theory of freedom behind leading court cases on civil liberties in America? This course will search for such a theory, drawing both on Supreme Court cases and classical works of political theory. Specific topics include freedom of religion, freedom of speech, privacy, and affirmative action.

title: Civil Liberties and the American Ideal of Freedom

This course will search for such a theory, drawing both on Supreme Court cases and classical works of political theory. Specific topics include freedom of religion, freedom of speech, privacy, and affirmative action.

title: Law and Public Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes various issues of policymaking by courts. Topics include crime and punishment, administrative law, precedent and doctrine, separation of powers, the judicial appointment process, and constitution building. Application of tools from game theory, law and economics, judicial politics and other positive theories. Primarily for graduate students and advanced undergraduates.

title: Parties, Elections, and the Mass Media
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Party system from realignment to reform and decreasing influence; shift of electoral behavior from party ties to candidate cues; increased role of television in era of candidate-centered politics and the "permanent" campaign.

title: Political Parties and Interest Groups
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course covers the historical development of parties and interest groups inthe US and the ways in which parties and interest groups influence individualvoting behavior, elections, and the governmental process. Special attention willbe paid to the alleged culture wars between the two parties and to the roleparties and interest groups have played in recent elections.

title: Campaigns and Elections
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines US congressional and presidential campaigns and elections, including candidates and the incentives and constraints they face, the role of political parties, and the evolution of the presidential nomination process. Considers how voters acquire information and make vote choices. Discussion of media coverage, negative advertising, campaign finance, and electoral reform.

title: Campaigns and Elections

title: Campaigns and Elections
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines US congressional, gubernatorial, and presidential campaigns and elections. Topics include campaign strategy, the role of political consultants, the role of political parties, along with the role of interest groups. Discussion of voters and voting behavior, media coverage and use of the media by candidates, negative advertising, polling, campaign finance, and electoral reform.

title: Topics in American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of elections. Voter behavior, candidate selection, the role of incumbency and money, ``economic'' voting, and the midterm balance hypothesis. Some attention is given to electoral reform. Elements of game theory and statistics introduced as needed.

title: Elections
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of elections. Voter behavior, candidate selection, the role of incumbency and money, ``economic'' voting, and the midterm balance hypothesis. Some attention will be given to electoral reform. Elements of game theory and statistics will be introduced as needed.

title: Topics in American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces some of the standard methods used in American politics. Methods are studied in context of applications to voter behavior, polls, incumbency advantages, campaign finance, legislative organization, and agenda control.

title: The Presidential Nomination Process
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The process of choosing presidential candidates has become one of the most elaborate and engrossing features of American politics. Course examines the present system for reducing the number of possible candidates to two, from the perspectives of citizens, reporters, and candidates, and assesses some of the alternatives.

title: The Presidential Nomination Process
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the process used to nominate presidential candidates, with special attention to the history of presidential selection, recent changes in the rules and their effects, the dynamics of primaries and caucuses, and proposals for reform. Also examines the role and potential of third party and independent candidates.

title: The Presidential Nomination Process

Also examines the role and potential of third party and independent candidates.

title: Presidential Power in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the origins and evolution of presidential power in the United States. Studies the powers of the President and how those powers translate into power. Examines and evaluates the most prominent political science theories, scholarly debates, and public controversies about presidential power. Explores the strategic choices available to modern American presidents in their efforts to augment the power of the presidency and provide active leadership to the political system.

title: The Road to the White House
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the role of presidential campaigns and elections in American politics.  It studies the origins and evolution of the presidential selection process and explores how modern campaigns inform, influence, and mobilize voters.  Topics to be studied include the role of political parties and candidates, campaign strategies and tactics, political advertising and media coverage, campaign finance and voter mobilization, and the transition from campaigning to governing.  The 2016 campaign will be used as a laboratory in which to explore political science research on presidential campaigns and elections.

title: The Road to the White House
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the role of presidential campaigns and elections in American politics.  It studies the origins and evolution of the presidential selection process and explores how modern campaigns inform, influence, and mobilize voters.  Topics to be studied include the role of political parties and candidates, campaign strategies and tactics, political advertising and media coverage, campaign finance and voter mobilization, and the transition from campaigning to governing.  The 2016 campaign will be used as a laboratory in which to explore political science research on presidential campaigns and elections.

title: The Road to the White House
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of presidential campaigns and elections in American politics. Studies the origins and evolution of the presidential nominating and electoral process and explores how modern campaigns inform, influence, and mobilize voters. Topics include the role of political parties and candidates, campaign strategies and issues, political advertisement and media coverage, and campaigning and governing. Special efforts will be made to incorporate major developments in the 2012 campaign with political science research on presidential campaigns and elections.

title: The Road to the White House
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of presidential campaigns and elections in American politics. Studies the origins and evolution of the presidential nominating and electoral process and explores how modern campaigns inform, influence, and mobilize voters. Topics include the role of political parties and candidates, campaign strategies and issues, political advertisement and media coverage, and campaigning and governing. Special efforts will be made to incorporate major developments in the 2008 campaign with political science research on presidential campaigns and elections.

title: The Road to the White House
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the role of presidential campaigns and elections in American politics.  It studies the origins and evolution of the presidential selection process and explores how modern campaigns inform, influence, and mobilize voters.  Topics to be studied include the role of political parties and candidates, campaign strategies and tactics, political advertising and media coverage, campaign finance and voter mobilization, and the transition from campaigning to governing.  The 2016 campaign will be used as a laboratory in which to explore political science research on presidential campaigns and elections.

title: American Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How does public opinion shape government?  Students will learn how pollsters ask questions in order to test ideas about politics and how public opinion data are used to make political decisions.  Students will learn theories of public opinion and government accountability, fundamentals of public opinion research, and how to design and analyze surveys.  Students will work with a national survey firm to design and analyze national sample surveys, and they will learn how to write an effective memo that uses survey data to advise a candidate or president about political strategies and decisions

title: American Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes several related questions about contemporary American public opinion. What do Americans know and think about politics? Why do people hold these particular opinions? How do politicians, the media, and other people influence an individual? How do researchers know what they do about public opinion? Finally, in what ways does public opinion affect (or not affect) public policy?

title: American Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes what Americans think about politics, why they do so, and what consequences these beliefs have on citizen behavior and system response. Investigates methods of survey research.

title: U.S. Electoral Behavior and Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the ways in which individual Americans form opinions about political issues and actors and express their opinions through voting. Examines the foundations of public opinion and political orientation, factors that affect the decision to vote, determinants of the choices that voters make, and the interpretation of electoral outcomes.

title: Analyzing American Elections
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the electoral process, the effects of campaigns, and the decisions of voters. Explores the role of money, the media, and the political parties. Considers the design, conduct, and use of surveys of public opinion by journalists, campaign consultants, and government officials. Teaches the basics of empirical social science research and statistics at the level of Government 50. Includes original analysis of survey data and election returns.

title: Democratic Citizenship Public Opinion and Participation in the US
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course examines the nature of public opinion and political participation. Considers how people acquire, organize, and apply their political beliefs; historical and contemporary patterns of public opinion, with emphasis on conflicts of values and social groups; who votes and why; the role of the media and political campaigns in mobilization and in formation of public opinion; and linkage between opinion, participation, and policy, with attention to whether citizens can discharge the responsibilities of democratic citizenship.

title: The Fourth Estate: Politics and Mass Media
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A critical view of the media and of charges made about the media, in order to understand its influence on American politics. Considers journalists and the settings in which they work, to identify the inclinations, habits, incentives, and constraints that shape the news. Examines the content of news about politics, its influence on the public and on the people who make public policy.

title: Media and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of the mass media in American politics. Considers the relationship between politicians, the press, and the public, and how this relationship has changed over time. Looks at media influence on the workings of government, policy making, and election campaigning. Special emphasis on theories of political communication and research on media effects. Concludes by considering how politics affects the media, ethical issues in the role of the media, and how media politics in the U.S. compare to other democracies.

title: Media and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of the mass media in American politics. Considers the relationship between politicians, the press, and the public, and how this relationship has changed over time. Looks at media influence on the workings of government, policy making, and election campaigning. Special emphasis on theories of political communication and research on media effects. Concludes by considering how politics affects the media, ethical issues in the role of the media, and how media politics in the U.S. compare to other democracies.

title: The Fourth Estate: Politics and Mass Media
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Increased role of the press since the 1890s. Wire services and Progressive muckraking, emergence of radio and the news weeklies, trend to newspaper consolidation and rise of prestige papers, internal and external pressures on television. Questions of government regulation, fairness, and economic consolidation. Effects of news on public opinion and elections. Response of parties, Congress, and the President to the media age.

title: The Media as a Political Institution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers political science research about how the media has evolved as an institution in American history, how it interacts with public officials, and how it may or may not shape public opinion. Topics include the structure of the media, the effects of negative advertisements, and questions raised by the so-called `new media'.

title: Media and Politics

Concludes by considering how politics affects the media, ethical issues in the role of the media, and how media politics in the U.S. compare to other democracies.

title: The Fourth Estate: Politics and Mass Media
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Increased role of the press since the 1890s. title: Political Economy of Public Decision
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Combines substantive knowledge about political processes and institutions with good analytic and technical skills. Provides instruction in organizational politics, American institutions, and the politics of urban finance, environment, public health, pollution control, and welfare reform, while introducing analytic concerns including forecasting, cost-benefit analysis, and decision analysis as well as generally improving students' modeling skills. Combines lectures, readings, discussion, role-playing experiments, and exercises with preprogrammed examples of computer models of important public decisions sufficiently rich to encourage student interest and experimentation. Intended for students with no quantitative background.

title: The Politics of American Education
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines historical and contemporary forces shaping American K-12 education policy. It also reviews research and commentary on contemporary issues: class size, fiscal policy, teacher recruitment, compensation and tenure, accountability, school vouchers, charter schools and digital learning.

title: The Politics of American Education
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the politics of education in the United States. It considers the key institutions (e.g. school districts, mayors, states, Congress, and courts) and actors (e.g. elected officials, parents, teachers, interest groups, and the general public) shaping the American K-12 education system in order to understand recent reform efforts and their consequences for students. We will look closely at past conflicts over education governance, ongoing policy challenges, and the forces shaping current reform efforts. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as SUP 447 (formerly HLE 347).

title: Psychology of Politics in the US
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: At each level of the American political system, outcomes are shaped not only by existing laws and institutions, but also by the behavior of human beings_citizens, representatives, judges, political operatives etc. This class examines how models of behaviors such as rationality, decision-making, groupthink, risk-taking, cognitive dissonance, and others shape what we know about mass and elite political behavior in the US.

title: Psychology of Politics in the United States
subject: GOV

title: Political Psychology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the psychological mechanisms behind political behaviors and institutions. Topics covered will include voting behavior, campaigns and media, partisanship, political violence, and racial attitudes. For these and other topics we will not only ask what happens but examine how human psychology makes it happen.

title: American Social Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is designed to give students an overview of the American system of social policy, with a focus on contemporary issues and challenges facing the nation. We will examine the history and nature of social welfare policy in the US and discuss the social, economic, and political factors that influence policymaking and implementation. In addition, we will explore the key demographic and economic trends underway in the US, with particular attention placed on the changing picture of the poor, the elderly, and our increasingly diverse population.

title: Data Science to Save the World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores ways to create and use technology to assess and solve real-world societal, political and governance problems. Case studies involve real-world data (e.g., twitter, online ads, and images). Hands-on lab format.

subject: GOV

title: The Politics of Personal Data
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course examines legal, political, social, commercial and technical struggles for control over personal data in our globally connected data-rich world. Case studies include data sharing mandated by the state, traded for personal services, and controlled by individuals. Analyses demonstrate ways to think about clashes and the interplay between technology design and policy. Includes a data lab component, but course is accessible to all students willing to experiment with new technologies and participate in class discussions.

title: The Politics of Personal Data
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course examines legal, political, social, commercial and technical struggles for control over personal data in our globally connected data-rich world. Analyses demonstrate ways to think about clashes and the interplay between technology design and policy. title: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: We live in a new kind of technocracy –a society in which technology design dictates the rules that govern daily life. In the race to construct the latest gadget, app and online service, winning depends on rapid uptake and business success. Losing are social norms and democratic values. This course uses case studies to understand issues, introduces a formal framework to model and reason about technology-society conflicts and then demonstrates the power of scientific experimentation and ability to exploit paradigm shifts as means to a victorious future where society reaps the benefits of technological innovations without sacrificing critical values.

title: Representation, Participation, and American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Deals with the variety of ways in which citizen needs and preferences are communicated to the government. Comparisons are made among voting, interest group activity, social movements, and protests. The consequences for ^'^'who gets what from the government'' are explained.

title: Representation and American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the alternative ways that public preferences are expressed and communicated in American politics. Comparison made between representation of citizen interest via elections and via interest groups, as well as via such mechanisms as town meeting government, referendum, protest, and public opinion polls. Material related to theories of democracy and social choice.

title: Urban Politics and Policymaking
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of urban politics and policymaking in the United States in the postwar period. Topics include the politics of urban redevelopment, fiscal politics, urban education and the politics of race.

subject: GOV

title: Inside Government: Topics in Economic, Regulatory, and Legal Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores policymaking inside the federal government, with particular reference to significant issues confronted in recent years and to the likely shape of future challenges. Students will be asked to write either a series of short papers or a long paper at the end of the semester. Several outside speakers, with substantial high-level government experience, are expected to help lead some of the sessions. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as BGP 300 and with the Law School as 2548. To apply please email the instructors, with copy to Melissa Proctor, mproctor@jd14.law.harvard.edu. Course meets at the Law School, Wasserstein 3016.

title: Bureaucracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of bureaucracies primarily in the American context. Analyzes what bureaucracies do; theories for their formation; the behavior of bureaucratic actors (managers, operators, and executives) and recurring problems and complaints. Concludes by assessing bureaucratic effectiveness and proposals for reform. Illustrated through case studies of public bureaucracies. Depending on class size, an additional section may be scheduled.

title: Bureaucracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of bureaucracies primarily in the American context. Analyzes what bureaucracies do; theories for their formation; the behavior of bureaucratic actors (managers, operators, and executives) and recurring problems and complaints. Concludes by assessing bureaucratic effectiveness and proposals for reform. Illustrated through case studies of public bureaucracies.

title: Bureaucracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How do government bureaucracies work? How do they affect the character of political decisions? Focus on military, diplomatic, and police bureaucracies, including comparative examinations of European and business bureaucracies.

title: American Constitutional Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an introduction to contemporary American constitutional law, with a principal focus on decisions by the Supreme Court of the US. Topics to be studied include freedom of speech and religion, guarantees of due process and equal protection, and the powers of Congress and the courts.

title: The Constitution and the American Political System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will focus on the principal features of the United States Constitution that structure the American political system. Most of these, such as bicameralism, are never the subject of litigation and, therefore, of any cases decided by the United States Supreme Court. The central question, inevitably, is whether constitutional structures really "matter," and, if so, what the consequences are. Although the focus will be the United States Constitution, the course will inevitably have a comparative dimension, along two quite different lines. One of the assigned books, for example, will look at the "American State Constitutional Tradition," and we will look at some of the decidedly different choices made by various states. (Nebraska, for example, has operated with only a unicameral legislature for over 75 years.) But we will also look at least intermittently at other national constitutions as well, especially, for example, with regard to different approaches toward the subject of "emergency powers" or suspension of ordinary constitutional rights. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Moral Reasoning

title: The Constitution and the American Political System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will examine American constitutions regarding both the normative and empirical assumptions they make about political life and the specific kinds of politics they help constitute through the institutions they establish. Although the United States Constitution will inevitably be the central focus, state constitutions will also be receive considerable attention, not least because they are often strikingly different from the national constitution and each other. Occasional attention will also be directed at foreign constitutions. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core requirement for Moral Reasoning.

title: The American Legal System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines how the American political system, viewed comparatively and empirically, deals with selected problems - e.g., empowering and selecting judiciaries, adjudicating criminal cases, regulating environmental harm, compensating accident victims, remediating harsh inequalities. Formal requirements: a midterm examination, a final examination, and a substantial research paper based on field research concerning an actual legal dispute.

title: Bureaucratic Politics: Government, Economic, Social and Military Organizations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A theoretical and historical analysis of bureaucratic organizations in various domains of modern society, including military organizations, business corporations, non-profit organizations, regulatory agencies, executive departments, and religious organizations. Theories include institutional, transaction-cost, reputation-based, and cultural theories of formal organizations. Readings and cases will include the US Army and other militaries, the business corporation in industrializing America and today, the FDA and the Forest Service, the Catholic Church, and police and educational organizations.

title: Agenda Setting in Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is interested in understanding how and why Congress pays attention to certain issues rather than others. The intent is to provide a comprehensive look at the roles of institutional design, citizen participation, political entrepreneurism, and media coverage in placing issues onto the congressional agenda. Students will be encouraged to integrate knowledge from a variety of subfields in American politics to offer a broader view of how issues are placed onto the congressional agenda - and ultimately - shift public policy.

title: American Political Parties
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the role of political parties in U.S. politics. Traces the development of parties and party systems from the country's founding to the present day, examining how the function and organization of parties has changed and been changed by the politics of the times. Considers the influence of parties in making policy and winning elections. Serious attention is given to the part of ordinary citizens in party politics, especially the causes, consequences, and dynamics of party identification.

title: Supreme Court Decision-Making
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comprehensive examination of Supreme Court decision making, aided by analysis of a computer databases on the court along with the statistical package STATA. The course covers various stages of the judicial process, including appointments to the Court, the decision to grant certiorari, the decision on the merits, majority-opinion assignment, and majority-opinion coalitions.

title: Supreme Court & American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides undergraduates with a systematic understanding of the Supreme Court from a social science perspective. We examine issues regarding judicial process and politics, and how various actors attempt to achieve their goals with in a broader institutional framework.

title: Supreme Court & American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides undergraduates with a systematic understanding of the Supreme Court from a social science perspective. We examine issues regarding judicial process and politics, and how various actors attempt to achieve their goals with in a broader institutional framework.

title: The American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the strategies candidates employ when campaigning for the presidency, starting in the primaries and continuing through the general election. Also examines the historical and institutional foundations of presidential power; the president's relationships with Congress, the bureaucracy, courts, interest groups, and the public; and the influence presidents wield in domestic and foreign policymaking. Special efforts will be made to incorporate theories of political organization and power that have emerged in the field of political science.

title: Supreme Court & American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides undergraduates with a systematic understanding of the Supreme Court from a social science perspective. We examine issues regarding judicial process and politics, and how various actors attempt to achieve their goals with in a broader institutional framework.

title: Politics of the American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course surveys the politics of the American presidency in a system where power is distributed across branches of government.  From this institutional perspective, the course uses historical and contemporary examples to engage the following questions: What is presidential power and what are its implications for American democracy?  When do presidents succeed — and why do they fail?  How do presidents manage relations with Congress, the courts, the bureaucracy, and the public?  How do presidents make decisions about war and peace? Through answering these questions, the course illuminates the factors that shape the behavior of the world’s most powerful political leader.

title: The American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course analyzes the development and modern practice of presidential leadership. Examines the institutional presidency, presidential selection, decision making, and the relationship of the presidency with the executive branch, Congress, courts, interest groups, the press and the public. Considers the political resources and constraints influencing the President's ability to provide leadership in the US political system.

title: The American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course analyzes the development and modern practice of presidential leadership. Examines the institutional presidency, presidential selection, decision making, and the relationship of the presidency with the executive branch, Congress, courts, interest groups, the press and the public. Considers the political resources and constraints influencing the President's ability to provide leadership in the US political system.

title: The American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the development and modern practice of presidential leadership in the U.S. Examines the evolution of the modern presidency, the process of presidential selection, and the structure of the presidency as an institution, leading to an assessment of the ways in which presidents and their staffs make decisions and shape policies within the Washington political community. Explores the relationship of the presidency with other major governmental institutions, organized interest groups, the media, and the public. Primary concern is with the political resources and constraints influencing the President's ability to provide leadership in the American political system. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as M-671.

title: The American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the development and modern practice of presidential leadership. Focus is on presidential decision making: how is it affected by changes in presidents; the presidency (institution and electoral processes); and by other major actors: national governing institutions (executive branch, Congress, courts); interest groups; the media; and the public. Selected case studies to sharpen analyses. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as PAL-115.

Examines the institutional presidency, presidential selection, decision making, and the relationship of the presidency with the executive branch, Congress, courts, interest groups, the press and the public. Considers the political resources and constraints influencing the President's ability to provide leadership in the U.S. political system. Spring Term: Examines the strategies candidates employ when campaigning for the presidency, starting in the primaries and continuing through the general election. Also examines the historical and institutional foundations of presidential power; the president's relationships with Congress, the bureaucracy, courts, interest groups, and the public; and the influence presidents wield in domestic and foreign policymaking. Special efforts will be made to incorporate theories of political organization and power that have emerged in the field of political science. During the fall term, this course is offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as PAL-115. Meets at FAS.

title: The American Presidency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the development and modern practice of presidential leadership in the U.S. Examines the evolution of the modern presidency, the process of presidential selection, and the structure of the presidency as an institution, leading to an assessment of the ways in which presidents and their staffs make decisions and shape policies within the Washington political community. Explores the relationship of the presidency with other major governmental institutions, organized interest groups, the media, and the public. Primary concern is with the political resources and constraints influencing the President's ability to provide leadership in the American political system. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as PAL-115.

title: Women, Gender and Politics in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is designed to introduce students to the issues and activities related to women and gender in American politics. This course is divided into four sections. Section I considers the history of American women's rights movements. Section II looks at gender, citizenship and liberalism in American politics. Section III reviews the social policy debates relevant to women, and finally the fourth section reflects on sexuality and culture as they relate to gender politics. We will conclude the course with some thoughts about the future of gender and politics in the United States.

title: Women and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why are there so few women in politics? And would more women in politics make a substantive difference in public policymaking? Course examines the barriers and opportunities for women in electoral politics, and their impact_as voters, candidates and officeholders_in the United States and Europe. Offered jointly with, and meets at, the Kennedy School of Government as PAL 235.

title: Women, Gender and Politics in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is designed to introduce students to the issues and activities related to women and gender in American politics. This course is divided into four sections. Section I considers the history of American women's rights movements. Section II looks at gender, citizenship and liberalism in American politics. Section III reviews the social policy debates relevant to women, and finally the fourth section reflects on sexuality and culture as they relate to gender politics. We will conclude the course with some thoughts about the future of gender and politics in the United States.

title: Gender and Representation in US Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines contemporary issues related to gender and political representation in the US, with a comparative component. Topics include the history of gender disparities in political participation, theories surrounding political representation, and gender dynamics in electoral politics and government institutions. Investigates the relationship between gender and public policy, along with future expectations and realities surrounding political representation in the US.

title: Gender and Representation in US Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines contemporary issues related to gender and political representation in the US, with a comparative component. Topics include the history of gender disparities in political participation, theories surrounding political representation, and gender dynamics in electoral politics and government institutions. Investigates the relationship between gender and public policy, along with future expectations and realities surrounding political representation in the US.

title: Gender and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the role of gender in American politics. Topics covered include the roles of women and men as citizens and as political elites; the nineteenth and twentieth century movements on behalf of the collective political interests of women; and, in the second half of the course, the politics of public policies having an explicit gender dimension--among them, various workplace issues, equal educational opportunity, family matters, reproductive issues, and sexual assault.

title: Gender and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the role of gender in American politics.
