title: Latinos and American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the development of Latin political communities in the U.S., with particular attention to political culture, organizational development, modes of incorporation, and structural factors that have impeded and facilitated their incorporation. Concentrates on the population of Mexican origin but also considers the experiences of Puerto Rican and Cuban populations.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines central themes in the politics of American cities, with emphases on the historical development of urban political institutions, the impact of federalism, the political incorporation of new groups, and the formation of coalitions across economic, racial and ethnic lines.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines central themes in the politics of American cities, with emphases on the historical development of urban political institutions, the impact of federalism, the political incorporation of new groups, and the formation of coalitions across economic, racial and ethnic lines.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines central themes in the politics of American cities, with emphases on the historical development of urban political institutions, the impact of federalism, the political incorporation of new groups, and the formation of coalitions across economic, racial, and ethnic lines.

title: Politics and Society Among Afro-Americans
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of Afro-Americans' political patterns in urban areas North and South. Relationship of Afro-American social structure (e.g., racial status, occupational patterns, class dynamics) and politics is emphasized. The process of political inclusion or political incorporation of blacks into city power structures is given special consideration. Case studies of selected cities are undertaken (e.g., Atlanta, Birmingham, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Detroit, Baltimore).

title: Politics and Society Among Afro-Americans
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of Afro-Americans' political patterns in urban areas North and South. Relationship of Afro-American social structure (e.g., racial status, occupational patterns, class dynamics) and politics is emphasized. The process of political inclusion or political incorporation of Blacks into city power structures is given special consideration. The experience in particular cities is also given special attention.

title: Politics and Society Among Afro-Americans
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of Black-American political patterns in urban areas North and South. Relationship of Afro-American social structure (e.g., racial status, occupational patterns, class dynamics) and political development is emphasized. The process of political incorporation of Blacks into city power structures is given special consideration. Case studies of selected cities are used to provide systemic specificity for our analysis (e.g., Cleveland, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Atlanta, Detroit, Baltimore, New Orleans).

title: Black Americans and the Political System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on how the continuing struggle for black empowerment has helped to shape both the current American political environment as well as the social and economic conditions of the black community. The unique nature of African-American politics necessitates a multi-disciplinary approach to the subject. Consequently, materials and lectures also show how the study of race relations, psychology, economics, and sociology can inform our understanding of the critical importance of black politics to American politics.

title: Minority Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a general survey of constraints and opportunities in minority politics, focusing on the tensions between electoral politics and protest politics, separatism and assimilation, and cooperation and competition within and among minority groups since WWII. The purpose of the course is not only to pinpoint the similarities and differences of the agendas and strategies adopted by African-Americans, Asian-Americans and Latinos, but to indicate the interaction between "minority" politics and American politics as a whole.

title: Black Americans and the Political System

title: Ethnic Groups in American Political Culture
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the role of ethnic groups in American political development and thus in shaping American political culture. Ethnic leadership or political styles, interethnic attitudes, ethnic-bloc politicization patterns, and ethnic electoral alliances are studied in terms of their unique political culture influence. The evolution of political patterns since the late 19th century among Irish, WASPs, Italians, Jews, Hispanics (especially Mexican-Americans) receives special attention, as well as the political patterns among Polish-Americans, Blacks, and Asian-Americans.

title: Afro-American Politics in the Post-Civil Rights Era
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Evaluates the rise of Black Americans as a new electoral force and discusses the set of issues generated by the increase in the number of Black elected officials, the role of Blacks within the Democratic party coalition, and Jackson's 1984 and 1988 bids for the Democratic presidential nomination. The implications of the election of Black mayors in metropolitan centers and the role of Blacks in contemporary Southern politics are also examined.

title: The New Black Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Evaluates the rise of Black Americans as a new electoral force and discusses the set of issues generated by the increase in the number of Black elected officials, the role of Blacks within the Democratic party coalition, and Jackson's 1984 and 1988 bids for the Democratic presidential nomination. The implications of the election of Black mayors in metropolitan centers and the role of Blacks in contemporary Southern politics are also examined.

title: Asian and Latino Politics in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a general survey of constraints and opportunities in minority politics, focusing on tensions between immigrants and minorities, separatism and assimilation, electoral politics and protest politics, and cooperation and competition within and among minority groups. The purpose of the course is not only to pinpoint the similarities and differences of the agendas and strategies adopted by minority groups, but to indicate the interaction between ^'^'minority'' politics and American politics as a whole.

title: American Identity: Nationalism, Ethnicity, and Race
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Addresses a number of theoretical questions about political approaches to identity through the lenses of ethnicity, nationalism, and race. How should we go about describing these forms of political identity? Are they primordial, or are they constructed? If they are constructed, how and by whom? What constrains/structures these constructions? What purposes do these constructions serve? Whom do they serve? Are some constructions better representations of identity than others, and why? Is it really so easy to discard primordial notions of identity?

title: Race, Ethnicity, and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines identification, both subjectively and from the ouside, of various races and ethnicities in the US, and the political and policy implications of those identifications. Will also consider complexities involved by adding gender, nationality, class, and other factors to race or ethnicity. Topics include schooling, affirmative action, redistricting, job and housing discrimination, political activity, and others.

title: Immigration Policy and the Politics of Immigration: The U.S. in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Origins and consequences of attempts by the United States to initiate, regulate, and restrict immigration and refugee flows, especially from Latin American, Caribbean, and Asian countries. Social and economic forces that have shaped immigration policies and stimulated anti-immigrant movements and political parties. Changing functions of immigrant labor in the economies of the U.S. and other industrialized countries. How public polices affect the social, economic, and political integration of immigrants. Comparative reference to experiences of West European countries and Japan in controlling immigration from Third World nations and integrating immigrant populations.

title: Who Are We? Issues of American National Identity
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A limited enrollment discussion course for both graduate and undergraduate students. Topics include: ethnic, racial, cultural, and ideological concepts of American identity; the relation between national and other identities; contemporary debates over national identity; immigration, assimilation, and Anglo-Hispanic biculturalism; America as the ``exceptional'' or ``universal'' country; the problem of the lack of an opposing ``evil empire;'' the impact of different conceptions of identity on America's international role.

title: Explorations in American National Identity
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This is a limited enrollment discussion course open to both undergraduate and graduate students. Topics to be covered include: theories of identity; nationalism and ethnicity; origins, elements, and development of American national identity; immigration and assimilation; the place of religion in American self-definitions; current challenges to national identity; competing cultural and transnational identities; concepts of America as the ^'^'exceptional'' or ^'^'universal'' nation; prospects for a new American nationalism; the impact of changes in American identity for the American role in the world.

title: Who Are We? Issues of American National Identity

title: Who Are We? Issues of American National Identity
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A limited enrollment discussion course for both graduate and undergraduate students. Topics include: ethnic, racial, cultural, and ideological concepts of American identity; the relation between national and other identities; contemporary debates over national identity; immigration, assimilation, and Anglo-Hispanic biculturalism; America as the ``exceptional'' or ``universal'' country; the problem of the lack of an opposing ``evil empire;'' the impact of different conceptions of identity on America's international role.

title: Poverty and American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews the evolution of antipoverty policies, beginning with the New Deal. The first half of the course focuses on the politics of policy formation: why have certain programs (and not others) been adopted, and what does this historical record reveal about the nature of American politics? The second half is an exercise in policy analysis: given contemporary political realities, how can government best respond to the problem of poverty in America?

title: Making American Public Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of basic approaches to the study of national policymaking in the United States. What factors influence the identification of policy problems, the setting of agendas, and executive legislative decisions? How does the distinctive structure of American political institutions affect the policymaking process? Course balances a review of theoretical approaches to public policy analysis with detailed case studies on environmental, health, and budgetary policy.

title: National and International Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The problem of security in the international system and as a goal which states seek. Conceptual approaches to security, its relation to conflict, sources of insecurity and threat, the role of nuclear weapons and alliances in security strategies. Special problems of regional security, civil-military relations, economics and security policy, and security policy in democracies.

title: National and International Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The central issue in this course is what security is, and how states in the international system pursue or maintain it. Discusses how national leaders define security_what its requirements are and how it may be obtained. Identifies potential sources of security and insecurity in the international system, and how these can lead to crises and war. Looks at specific issues of regional security, nuclear weapons, economics and security, arms acquisition and the military, and U.S.-Soviet competition.

title: The Politics of Terrorism: Causes and Consequences from a Global Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Terrorism dominates the headlines, but few observers attempt to think critically about the origins, evolution, and variable impacts of terror groups over the course of history. Alongside many enduring myths and misperceptions about terrorism, the history of this violent technique is rife with puzzles. Why is it so difficult for people to agree on a common definition of terrorism across the globe? Why do groups take up arms against civilians to effect political change? Why do some groups remain fairly restrained in their use of violence while others routinely engage in mass atrocities? Why do some terror groups end within a year of their emergence, whereas others toil along for decades? What are the most effective ways to combat terrorism? What is really “new” about the “new terrorism”? The course takes a theoretical and historical approach, attempting to nest contemporary challenges within the broader global context of terrorism as a phenomenon. To this end, the course will acquaint students with the historical evolution of domestic and international terrorism while introducing them to the major analytical approaches to the study of terrorism. The five primary goals of the course are for students to: (1) present leading theories, approaches, and concepts for understanding terrorist behavior around the globe; (2) evaluate current approaches to terrorism against prevailing evidence; (3) apply cumulative knowledge to current policy problems and make informed inferences about future developments; (4) deepen their knowledge about particular cases or topics regarding terrorism and counterterrorism; and (5) synthesize their knowledge during in-depth course discussions and several written assignments. By the end of the course, students should understand the fundamental analytical and policy debates surrounding terrorism globally, as well as several policy alternatives that may lead to solutions. Students should also develop substantive knowledge about current trends in terrorism and counterterrorism. By the end of the term, students should be comfortable taking an intellectual stand about topics related to terrorism, defending their positions with evidence, engaging in self-critique, deriving actionable policy recommendations, and communicating those recommendations to both specialist and non-specialist audiences—particularly when the empirical record contrasts with the conventional wisdom. Course assignments are designed to enhance those skills.

title: Models of Conflict in International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is both a simple introduction to game theory, and a literature review of game theoretical approaches to the study of international conflict and war. Game theory is a tool for analyzing strategic interaction between rational actors. The course will feature games like the Prisoners' Dilemma, the Chicken, and models of bargaining. Students will learn how these and related tools can be used to understand and analyze historical and current instances of international conflict. Specifically, we will try to answer questions like: why do states fight costly wars in international relations? Why do peaceful negotiations fail? How does deterrence work? Why do states get into costly arms races? How does domestic politics shape international conflict?

title: The Causes and Prevention of War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why do countries go to war? How can war be avoided? Considers some of the major explanations_including human nature, the anarchic international system, domestic politics, technology, misperception, nationalism, and culture_and evaluates them in light of historical wars, and of crises resolved short of war. Cases include the Peloponnesian War, World War I, World War II, the Cold War, the Arab-Israeli wars, and ex-Yugoslavia.

title: The Causes of War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the wide variety of explanations for the onset of war. Begins with a discussion of theories of war at a variety of levels of analysis, including international structural theories, institutional theories and the role of regimes, dyadic theories such as deterrence, domestic, political, or economic theories of war, and finally individual level theories such as those based on cognitive or motivated misperceptions. Then examines several historical cases - including both wars and international crises that did not become wars - in order to evaluate these theoretical approaches.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of the leading theories of the causes of international war, application of these theories to a number of historical cases over the last several centuries, comparison of the origins of these wars, and analysis of whether the causes of war have changed over time.

title: The Causes of War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the wide variety of explanations for the onset of war. Begins with a discussion of theories of war at a variety of levels of analysis, including international structural theories, institutional theories and the role of regimes, dyadic theories such as deterrence, domestic, political, or economic theories of war, and finally individual level theories such as those based on cognitive or motivated misperceptions. Then examines several historical cases - including both wars and international crises that did not become wars - in order to evaluate these theoretical approaches.

title: The Origins of Modern Wars
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores the causes of war. It examines the different theories that have been devised to explain organized violence between states (or groups seeking to control a state), and evaluates these competing theories by exploring several major conflicts of the past 100 years: World War I, World War II, the Cold War, the Arab-Israeli conflict, and the recent wars in the Persian Gulf. The course also considers the phenomenon of ethnic conflict, the implications of nuclear weapons and the question of whether large-scale war is becoming "obsolescent."

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores the causes of war. It examines the different theories that have been devised to explain organized violence between states (or groups seeking to control a state), and evaluates these competing theories by exploring several major conflicts of the past 100 years: World War I, World War II, the Cold War, the Arab-Israeli conflict, and the recent wars in the Persian Gulf. The course also considers the phenomenon of ethnic conflict, the implications of nuclear weapons and the question of whether large-scale war is becoming "obsolescent." This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core area requirement for Historical Study A.

title: Ethics and War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What is the origin, character, and impact of ethical constraints on war?  The course will review major theoretical discussions of this subject in readings and lectures. Students will then engage in in-class debates on the ethical status of actions taken in war based on historical cases.

title: Ethics and War
subject: GOV

title: Arms and Arms Control
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces students to the topic of arms racing, arms control and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Covers the causes and consequences of arms racing, theory and practice of arms control, nuclear, chemical and biological weapons proliferation, and arms control issues in Europe, Korea, South Asia and the Middle East.

title: International Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to public international law for students of international relations. The primary purpose is to enhance students' understanding of the ways in which international law orders international politics. Emphasis is on the substantive rules of international law, the relationship between law and politics, and cases that illustrate the issues. Topics include international human rights law, international economic law and institutions, the use of force, war crimes, and terrorism.

title: The Euro-Crisis: Causes and Consequences
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course takes an advanced political economy perspective to analyze the causes and consequences of the crisis in the euro area. The main topics covered in this class include (i) the political and economic rationales behind European integration and the creation of the euro, (ii) the main economic and financial market implications arising in a single currency block that is neither an optimum currency area nor a politically integrated fiscal union, (iii) the causes of the crisis in the euro area and the main steps/instruments in its resolution, (iv) the broader implications for EU economic governance and EU politics, with a particular focus on the design of fiscal federations. The course adopts an applied policy-perspective, but some basic to intermediate understanding of macro-economics would be useful. Previous knowledge of European integration and the functioning of EU institutions would be welcome but is not a requirement. Offered with HKS as IGA-663.

title: The Euro-Crisis: Causes and Consequences
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course takes an advanced political economy perspective to analyze the causes and consequences of the crisis in the euro area. The main topics covered in this class include (i) the political and economic rationales behind European integration and the creation of the euro, (ii) the main economic and financial market implications arising in a single currency block that is neither an optimum currency area nor a politically integrated fiscal union, (iii) the causes of the crisis in the euro area and the main steps/instruments in its resolution, (iv) the broader implications for EU economic governance and EU politics, with a particular focus on the design of fiscal federations. The course adopts an applied policy-perspective, but some basic to intermediate understanding of macro-economics would be useful. Previous knowledge of European integration and the functioning of EU institutions would be welcome but is not a requirement. Offered with HKS as IGA-663.

title: The Geopolitics of Emotion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Are emotions useful to understand and deal with the complexities of international relations? Are we in a "clash of emotions", with the United States and Europe dominated by a culture of fear, the Moslem-Arab world paralyzed by a culture of humiliation and Asia stimulated by a culture of hope?

title: The Geopolitics of Emotion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Are emotions useful to understand and deal with the complexities of international relations? Are we in a "clash of emotions", with the United States and Europe dominated by a culture of fear, the Moslem-Arab world paralyzed by a culture of humiliation and Asia stimulated by a culture of hope?

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines "problems of cooperation'' among states. Surveying topics in security and trade politics, explores the sources and consequences of discord in the international system, and evaluates national "strategies'' and institutional frameworks for conflict resolution.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the "problem of cooperation'' among states. Surveying topics in security and political economy, explores the sources and consequences of discord in the international system, and evaluates various national "strategies'' and institutional frameworks for conflict resolution.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the "problem of cooperation'' among states. Surveying topics in security and political economy, explores the sources and consequences of discord in the international system, and evaluates various national "strategies'' and institutional frameworks for conflict resolution.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines "problems of cooperation'' among states. Surveying topics in security and trade politics, explores the sources and consequences of discord in the international system, and evaluates national "strategies'' and institutional frameworks for conflict resolution.

title: Contemporary Global Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of conflict, cooperation, and change in contemporary international politics, focusing primarily on security issues. Topics include general theories and interpretations of contemporary global politics, changes in the distribution of power among states, the most prevalent and dangerous forms of violent conflict, the resurgence of Islam, demographic change, communal conflict, rogue states, terrorism, state decay, alternative ways of promoting global order. Students who took Government 2784 for credit may not take this course for credit.

title: Contemporary Global Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of conflict, cooperation, and change in contemporary international politics, focusing primarily on security issues. Topics include general theories and interpretations of contemporary global politics, changes in the distribution of power among states, the most prevalent and dangerous forms of violent conflict, the resurgence of Islam, demographic change, communal conflict, rogue states, terrorism, state decay, alternative ways of promoting global order. Students who took Government 2784 for credit may not take this course for credit.

title: Terrorist Movements in International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the philosophical and historical antecedents of contemporary terrorist movements and theoretical efforts to explain these movements. Explores in detail several movements in different parts of the world and compares their goals, tactics, financing, organization and achievements. Explores the relationship between democracy and terrorism and analyzes the counter-terrorism strategies of states acting unilaterally and multilaterally.

title: Terrorist Movements in International Relations
subject: GOV

title: Political Psychology of International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to methods and theories from social and cognitive psychology along with an explanation of how these concepts have been or can be applied to the study of international relations.

title: Political Psychology of International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to methods and theories from social and cognitive psychology along with an explanation of how these concepts have been or can be applied to the study of international relations.

title: International Institutions
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The governance structures of the nation state are increasingly complemented and partially challenged by international institutions. This seminar offers an in-depth overview of the structures, operating procedures and effects of international institutions. The empirical focus is on key international institutions in the fields of security, money and trade: the UN Security Council, NATO, the IMF and the WTO. The course is introductory. No prior knowledge of international politics is required.

title: Nationalism in International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Nationalism is one of the most salient phenomena in the contemporary world. Yet it remains an under-theorized topic in International Relations. The first part of this course will explore its historical and conceptual origins focusing on Europe. The second part applies the findings of the first part to issues in the contemporary world, including decolonization, the end of the cold war, post-communist politics, ethnic conflict and supranational integration.

title: Nationalism in International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Nationalism is one of the most salient phenomena in the contemporary world. Yet it remains an under-theorized topic in International Relations. The first part of this course will explore its historical and conceptual origins focusing on Europe. The second part applies the findings of the first part to issues in the contemporary world, including decolonization, the end of the cold war, post-communist politics, ethnic conflict and supranational integration.

title: International Institutions
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The governance structures of the nation state are increasingly complemented and partially challenged by international institutions. title: Human Rights
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the politics of human rights. The course looks at theoretical underpinnings for rights; the politics of humanitarian military intervention; national and international efforts to undermine dictatorships; the politics of international war crimes tribunals, from World War I to the International Criminal Court; and the role of human rights in terrorism and counterterrorism after September 11. Major cases include the Ottoman Empire, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Bosnia, Rwanda and Darfur.

title: Human Rights
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the politics of human rights. The course looks at theoretical underpinnings for rights; the politics of humanitarian military intervention; national and international efforts to undermine dictatorships; the politics of international war crimes tribunals, from World War I to the International Criminal Court; and the role of human rights in terrorism and counterterrorism after September 11. Major cases include the Ottoman Empire, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Bosnia, Rwanda and Darfur.

title: Behavioral Insights and Public Policy: Nudging for Good
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Behavioral economics focuses on the ways in which our individual actions, rather than resulting from rational self-interested decisions, reflect a variety of biases, habits, emotions, and considerations about others. Many governments have created behavioral insights teams to apply these insights to rethink traditional approaches to policy. We will examine recent research and applications in areas including healthcare, crime, discrimination, retirement savings, consumer credit, environmental conservation, welfare, employment, education, taxation, and foreign aid.

title: Behavioral Insights and Public Policy: Nudging for Good

title: The International Relations of East Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What are the main characteristics of international relations in East Asia? Are these distinctive? How ^'^'stable'' are inter-state relations in the region? How does one explain changing levels of conflict and cooperation in the region over time? How useful are Euro-centric international relations theories in understanding East Asia? This course examines the effects of changing distributions of strategic power, economic development and trade liberalization, multilateral institutional development, political development and democratization, and cultural convergence/divergence on conflict and cooperation in East Asia.

title: International Relations of East Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the historical, military, political, economic, and cultural features of interstate relations in East Asia and the Pacific. The course will also present some theoretical and methodological tools for more systematic analysis of these issues. The goal will be to understand changing levels of conflict and cooperation in the region.

title: International Relations of East Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to trends in interstate political, economic and cultural relationships. What explains variation in levels of economic and security cooperation over the last decade? Focus is on the degree to which there is distinctive pattern of international relation in the region. No prior background in China or international relations theory required.

title: Asia-Pacific Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys key security dynamics, actors and issues in the Asia-Pacific. Topics include: the US alliance system in the Asia-Pacific; China's military rise; Japanese militarization; the security capabilities of the Koreas and Southeast Asia, Australia, and Russia; insurgency and transnational terrorism; territorial disputes; North Korea and Taiwan; nuclear proliferation; MD; arms races; maritime security, energy security, and transnational crime; and multilateral security. All issues are studied in conjunction with major paradigmatic and critical theoretical approaches.

title: Asia-Pacific Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys key security dynamics, actors and issues in the Asia-Pacific. Topics include: the US alliance system in the Asia-Pacific; China's military rise; Japanese militarization; the security capabilities of the Koreas and Southeast Asia, Australia, and Russia; insurgency and transnational terrorism; territorial disputes; North Korea and Taiwan; nuclear proliferation; MD; arms races; maritime security, energy security, and transnational crime; and multilateral security. All issues are studied in conjunction with major paradigmatic and critical theoretical approaches.

title: The Foreign Policy of Modern Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Japan's search since 1868 to define its place in the world order, with emphasis on development since the early 1970s when Japan emerged as an economic giant. Looks at the domestic forces shaping foreign policy; the effects on Japan of trilateralism and the relative decline of U.S. economic power; pressures within and outside Japan to redefine its security role; and the potential consequences for Japan and the world of the U.S.-Japan trade conflict. Special attention to U.S.-Japan relations, Japanese-Soviet relations, and Japan's role in the Third World.

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Japan's changing role in the world political economy through a consideration of both domestic issues (Japanese corporate system, industrial and financial policy, and policy making) and foreign economic relations (trade, aid, and finance). What have been the developmental costs and benefits of various economic and political structures? Does the Japanese economic "model" inherently create conflicts with economic partners?

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the historical background, salient issues, and future scenarios of Japan's foreign relations and its role in the world political economy. What are the causes of conflict in U.S.-Japan relations? What is the nature of Japan's relations with the Soviet Union, China, Western Europe, and the newly industrializing countries of East Asia? What will be Japan's future role on the international stage?

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the historical background, salient issues, and future scenarios of Japan's foreign relations and its role in the world political economy. What are the causes of conflict in U.S.-Japan relations? What is the nature of Japan's relations with the Soviet Union, China, Western Europe, and the newly industrializing countries of East Asia? What will be Japan's future role on the international stage?

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Japan's changing role in international diplomacy, economic relations and military affairs. Topics include Japan's relations with the United States, China, South Korea and Southeast Asian countries; trade; aid policy; foreign direct investment; technology transfer; defense; and the domestic politics of Japanese foreign policy. Special attention to the Japanese economic system as a challenge to the international trading system and possible model for developing countries.

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Japan's changing role in the world political economy through a consideration of both domestic issues (Japanese corporate system, industrial and financial policy, and policy making) and foreign economic relations (trade, aid, and finance). What have been the developmental costs and benefits of various economic and political structures? Does the Japanese economic "model" inherently create conflicts with economic partners?

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Japan's changing role in the world political economy through a consideration of both domestic issues (Japanese corporate system, industrial and financial policy, and policy making) and foreign economic relations (trade, aid, and finance). title: Japan in the World Political Economy

What will be Japan's future role on the international stage?

title: Japan in the World Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Japan's changing role in the world political economy through a consideration of both domestic issues (Japanese corporate system, industrial and financial policy, and policy making) and foreign economic relations (trade, aid, and finance). What have been the developmental costs and benefits of various economic and political structures? Does the Japanese economic "model" inherently create conflicts with economic partners?

title: The International Politics of North-South Economic Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is intended as an advanced course in international political economy. Prior exposure to theories of international relations, economics, and the use of these in combination is assumed. The course examines the political aspect of international economic relations between the developing countries and the economically advanced countries since World War II. This course also looks at some of the reasons several Third World countries have done well in the international economy. The course ends with a consideration of the prospects for future North-South political economic relations.

title: Business, Government, and the Global Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Compares and analyzes strategies of national economic development and national economic performance in an era of increasing global integration. It uses the tools and concepts of both economics and political science to explore how the global economy shapes national economic decision-making. The course integrates analysis of specific decision-making episodes with more general discussion of pertinent themes. These issues include the costs and benefits of different development strategies. The seminar also looks at different kinds of capital flows, at environmental and labor standards and at international efforts to manage capital, labor, and the environment. The seminar draws on the experiences of a broad range of countries including the U.S., Mexico, and India, among others.

title: America and the World Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The politics of the international economic order in the 20th century, with emphasis on the changing role and position of the United States. Theories seeking to explain the structure and political foundations of the world economy are discussed and evaluated with reference to the rise and decline of American hegemony. Issues include: international trade regimes, the relationship between military and economic power, and the politics of expansionism.

title: Domestic Politics and International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will explore the ways domestic politics influence relations between countries, as well as the ways domestic political relationships are influenced by interstate relations. We will cover both security and economic policy areas and explore how they influence each other. The role of interest groups, domestic institutions, and the general public in determining foreign policy will all be studied with a primary emphasis on the United States.

title: Domestic Politics and International Relations

title: Central Asia in Global Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course is designed as an in-depth study of the place of Central Asia in global politics and the policies of key external actors, such as Russia, the United States, China, European Union, Turkey, Iran, Japan, South Korea and India, toward the region. Students are familiarized with the ways Central Asia has been contextualized both in scholarly sources and media. We will dwell on the changing geopolitical dynamics of the region and analyze similarities and differences in the foreign policies of Central Asian states. At the end of the course, we will discuss future prospects of the region.

title: American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of the theories and history of American foreign policy in the economic arena. Topics include the U.S. in the world economy, economic instruments of statecraft, processes and institutions for making foreign economic policy, the American role in international political economic institutions, and the economic aspects of national security. Issues to be covered include multinational corporations, trade, finance (and the debt crisis), oil, agriculture, and foreign aid.

title: American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys theories of foreign economic policy and assesses their usefulness in explaining patterns of American foreign economic relations, past and present. Topics included the domestic and international politics of U. S. trade policy, the management of exchange-rate relations, policies toward American multinational corporations operating abroad and policies toward foreign multinationals operating in the United States, the international debt crisis, and foreign aid policy.

title: Globalization and American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the foreign economic policies of the United States in the context of increasing global economic integration. Topics include: Globalization_benefits and costs, winners and losers; lessons from history; determinants of trade policy; political economy of multinational corporations; and reforming the international financial architecture.

title: American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Topics include: theories of foreign economic policy; trade, monetary, and energy policies; the industrial policy debate; the management of multinational corporations and banks; the U.S. response to the debt crisis; East-West trade; aid to developing countries.

title: American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys theories of foreign economic policy and assesses their usefulness in explaining patterns of American foreign economic relations, past and present. Topics included the domestic and international politics of U. S. trade policy, the management of exchange-rate relations, policies toward American multinational corporations operating abroad and policies toward foreign multinationals operating in the United States, the international debt crisis, and foreign aid policy.

title: Globalization and American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the foreign economic policies of the United States in the context of increasing global economic integration. Topics include: Globalization_benefits and costs, winners and losers; lessons from history; determinants of trade policy; political economy of multinational corporations; and reforming the international financial architecture.

title: American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys theories of foreign economic policy and accesses their usefulness in explaining patterns of American foreign economic relations in this century. Topics include the international sources of U.S. foreign economic policy, the relative importance of state actors vs. societal groups in the policy process, and the role domestic institutions play in shaping relations between state, society, and the international system. Issues include trade, foreign direct investment, foreign lending, foreign aid, and exchange rate policy.

title: American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys theories of foreign economic policy and accesses their usefulness in explaining patterns of American foreign economic relations past and present. Topics include the international sources of U.S. foreign economic policy, the relative importance of state officials vs. interest groups in the policy process, and the role institutions play in shaping relations between state, society, and the international system. Issues include trade exchange-rates, foreign direct investment, foreign debt, and foreign aid policy.

title: The International Politics of the Environment
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since the quality of the natural environment facing citizens of any state depends in part on the policies of other states, national environmental policies are on the agenda of international relations. Course examines the resulting politics from the standpoint both of analytical work on international interdependence and writings on contemporary environmental politics.

title: The International Politics of the Environment

title: American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines and explains the international actions of the US Government. Explanations drawn from history, international relations theory, and from the study of American political and bureaucratic institutions. Emphasis is placed on the recent rise of the US to a position of unprecedented military dominance, how this military power has been used, and how other states, non-state actors, or global governance institutions have responded.

title: American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores America’s role in global politics as explained by the major theoretical perspectives in international relations.  Topics covered include American grand strategy, bureaucratic politics, the role of public opinion in foreign policy, and contemporary challenges such as anti-Americanism, the rise and fall of great powers, terrorism, and nuclear weapons.

title: U.S. Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the making of U.S. foreign policy, covering the historical record from the founding of the United States to the present. The focus is primarily on relations with the Soviet Union/Russia and Western Europe during the Cold War, although various issues in post-Cold War U.S. foreign policy are also covered. The course analyzes basic facts, themes, and issues, highlighting the influence on foreign policy of: (1) power considerations; (2) domestic politics in the United States and in other countries; (3) domestic and international economic factors; and (4) credibility concerns.

title: American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV

title: The Character of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: President Bush ran for office promising "a distinctly American internationalism." Does American history suggest there is a distinctly American foreign policy? If so, what are its sources? What have been the tensions between the desires to promote liberty abroad and to preserve it at home? These and other issues will be explored through a study of key moments and debates in the history of American foreign policy, from the 1790's through the present.

The goal of the course is to provide students with a general understanding of the individuals, institutions, and broader social and political forces shaping the formulation and implementation of American foreign policy.

title: American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Seeks to uncover the sources of change and continuity in U.S. foreign policy after 1945 in both national security and economic affairs. Competing explanations are paired with case studies to facilitate discussion and analysis. The section on national security focuses on the ^'^'containment'' of the Soviet Union and intervention in the ^'^'Third World.'' The section on U.S. foreign economic policy examines the ideological and economic underpinnings of U.S. policy, the influence of domestic politics on trade policy and economic relations with Europe and Japan. A concluding section surveys American foreign policy after the cold war.

title: Media, Public Opinion and Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the means through which the media and public opinion influence U.S. foreign policy. We will consider how the public learns about foreign policy, whether and when they care about it, and when political leaders will be responsive to public preferences. We will also consider the effects of real-time global news reporting and media fragmentation. The goal is to understand the interaction between the media, the public and political leaders.

We will also consider the effects of real-time global news reporting and media fragmentation. The goal is to understand the interaction between the media, the public and political leaders.

title: US-Latin American Relations: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of political and economic relations between the United States and Latin American countries, and of the international relations of Latin America since 1960. Attention also given to foreign policy decision making in the US and Latin America, and to alternative approaches to the study of international relations and foreign policy. // This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for United States in the World or the Core area requirement for Social Analysis.

title: US-Latin American Relations: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of political and economic relations between the United States and Latin American countries, and of the international relations of Latin America since 1960. Attention also given to foreign policy decision making in the US and Latin America, and to alternative approaches to the study of international relations and foreign policy.

title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Using a series of case studies from the front page, and from the most urgent issues on the U.S. national security agenda, this course will engage students in grappling with the hardest American national security challenges of the decade ahead. Issues range from the Arab Awakening and intervention in civil wars to combating Iran's nuclear ambitions and dealing with the economic and military rise of China. Assignments require strategic thinking: analyzing dynamics of issues and developing strategies in a government whose deliberations are discombobulated by leaks, reports about internal differences among policymakers, and press analyses. Students will learn to devise strategies and write strategic options memos as participants in the policymaking process. Strategic options memos combine careful analysis and strategic imagination, on the one hand, with the necessity to communicate to major constituencies in order to sustain public support, on the other. A subtheme of the course explores coping with a world where a pervasive press makes secrecy more often the exception than the rule. In each case, there will be exploration of how media coverage affects decision making, with an examination of WikiLeaks, the revelations about drones and secret, American-led cyberattacks, and other examples of the publication of classified information. Because of time constraints, Mr. Sanger will be joining a limited number of class sessions, and will join some remotely.

title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Using a series of case studies that jump off the front page, this course grapples with the hardest U.S. national security challenges of the decade ahead. They range from decisions about when to intervene in civil wars or participate in regime change, to preventing nuclear terrorism, the Arab Spring, preventing Iran from getting the bomb and pressuring North Korea to surrender its weapons. The course delves deeply into the problem of dealing with Afghanistan and Pakistan, and coping with the rise of China-while the endless cycle of leaks and press analysis complicates the process of developing sound policy and strategy. Students will learn to devise strategies and write strategic options memos as part of the policymaking process, all while balancing the need to communicate to major constituencies to sustain public support, while coping with a world where a pervasive press makes secrecy a luxury of the past. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as IGA-211. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Globalization and Its Discontents
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How is globalization changing domestic and international politics? Are global markets and media drawing us together or driving us apart? Is the new global capitalism good or bad for democracy? The course will explore the consequences for international conflict, national sovereignty, cultural diversity, and political identity of a world in which national boundaries count for less than they once did.

title: Globalization and Its Discontents
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How is globalization changing domestic and international politics? Are global markets and media drawing us together or driving us apart? Is the new global capitalism good or bad for democracy? The course will explore the consequences for international conflict, national sovereignty, cultural diversity, and political identity of a world in which national boundaries count for less than they once did.

title: North-South Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course analyzes the relations between the developed nations of the "North" and the developing nations of the "South." Addresses historical and current issues in North-South relations, including migration, drug trafficking, the environment, and economic development.

title: North-South Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course analyzes the relations between the developed nations of the "North" and the developing nations of the "South." Addresses historical and current issues in North-South relations, including migration, drug trafficking, the environment, and economic development.

title: Religion and International Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Students are introduced to major topics on religion and politics across societies. At the same time, students learn about social-science theories of religion. We look at the explanatory value of these theories for the interplay between religion and politics: institutions and structures, political parties, civil society and social movements, violence, and economic development. What influence does religion have on politics within and across societies? What effects do political factors have on religion?

title: Religion and International Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Students are introduced to major topics on religion and politics across societies. At the same time, students learn about social-science theories of religion. We look at the explanatory value of these theories for the interplay between religion and politics: institutions and structures, political parties, civil society and social movements, violence, and economic development. What influence does religion have on politics within and across societies? What effects do political factors have on religion?

title: International Relations Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An analysis of theories of conflict and cooperation in world politics. Emphasis is on the logic and applicability of a wide range of contemporary theories, although some attention is paid to earlier writers, particularly Thucydides. Open to advanced undergraduates and graduate students.

title: International Relations Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An analysis of theories of conflict and cooperation in world politics. Emphasis is on the logic and applicability of a wide range of contemporary theories, although some attention is paid to earlier writers, particularly Thucydides. Open to advanced undergraduates and graduate students.

title: Introduction to Public International Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the main concepts and themes in public international law. Covers the role of states and international organizations as subjects of international law, treaties, the law of the sea, human rights, self-determination, and European integration.

title: The United States in World Affairs
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: American foreign policy since 1945: the origins of containment, the Korean and Vietnam wars, East-West and North-South relations, detente, the foreign policies of the Carter and Reagan years. The role of strategic interaction, domestic politics, and psychological variables in foreign policy decision making.

title: The United States in World Affairs
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: American foreign policy since 1945: the origins of containment, the Korean, Vietnam, and Gulf wars, East-West and North-South relations, detente. The end of the Cold War. The role of strategic interaction, international institutions, domestic politics, and psychological variables in foreign policy decision making.

title: The United States in World Affairs
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: American foreign policy since 1945: the origins of containment, the Korean, Vietnam, and Gulf wars, East-West and North-South relations, detente. The end of the Cold War. The role of strategic interaction, international institutions, domestic politics, and psychological variables in foreign policy decision making.

title: Soviet and Post-Soviet Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of Soviet and post-Soviet foreign policy. Focus is understanding the history, sources, and changes of the country's relations with the rest of the world through theories of domestic politics, leadership policies, and international relations.

title: The International Relations of the Post-Soviet States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the foreign policy legacies of the Soviet period and of the collapse of the USSR. Examines contemporary Russian foreign policy, including Russia's relations with Europe, the US, NATO, and China. Also looks at the policies of the other Soviet successor states and their ties to the outside world and to Russia. Among the issue areas will be NATO and EU expansion, energy cooperation, economic cooperation, the war on terrorism, and US-Russian relations.

title: Soviet and Post-Soviet Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of Soviet and post-Soviet foreign policy. Focus is understanding the history, sources, and changes of the country's relations with the rest of the world through theories of domestic politics, leadership policies, and international relations.

title: The International Relations of the Post-Soviet States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the foreign policy legacies of the Soviet period and of the collapse of the USSR. Examines contemporary Russian foreign policy, including Russia's relations with Europe, the US, NATO, and China. Also looks at the policies of the other Soviet successor states and their ties to the outside world and to Russia. Among the issue areas will be NATO and EU expansion, energy cooperation, economic cooperation, the war on terrorism, and US-Russian relations.

title: Soviet Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: History and analysis of Soviet foreign policy from 1917 to the present.

title: The International Relations of the Southern Cone of South America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interplay of economic, symbolic, and domestic objectives, and the impact of historical experience, self-perceptions, and images of the world upon the formulation of the foreign policies of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, Bolivia, and Paraguay. Also studies the past and present relations of these countries with the United States, major European powers, the rest of Latin America, and among themselves.

title: International Relations of South America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of main trends in South American international relations in post 1945, with emphasis on three shaping factors: political regime and foreign policy patterns; relations with the United States; developments in intra-regional relations. Special attention to post-cold war changes underlying the impact of democratization, economic reforms, regional integration initiatives and security cooperation.

title: International Relations of South America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of main trends in South American international relations in post 1945, with emphasis on three shaping factors: political regime and foreign policy patterns; relations with the United States; developments in intra-regional relations. Special attention to post-cold war changes underlying the impact of democratization, economic reforms, regional integration initiatives and security cooperation.

title: International Relations of South America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of main trends in South American international relations in post 1945, with emphasis on three shaping factors: political regime and foreign policy patterns; relations with the United States; developments in intra-regional relations. Special attention to post-cold war changes underlying the impact of democratization, economic reforms, regional integration initiatives and security cooperation.

title: The International Politics of the Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the international politics of the Middle East from an historical perspective. Topics include: the emergence of the contemporary states, external concerns and foreign policies of the principal states, ideological trends and religious resurgence, regional conflicts, and the relationships between Middle Eastern problems and the global rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. & the Arab-Israeli Conflict
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course created to support student import

title: The Arab-Israeli Conflict Today: A Contemporary Policy Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar traces the background of this unusually bitter, all-encompassing, resolution-resistant conflict. Primary emphasis is on the issues as they stand today (Israel - Palestinians, Syria, Lebanon, Iran), the sides' concerns, fears and policy objectives. Students will write policy papers from the perspective of leaders from the different countries and participate in simulations. The course is suitable for all, especially those interested in "real world" politics and considering careers in the field.

title: The Arab-Israeli Conflict Today: A Contemporary Policy Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar traces the background of this unusually bitter, all-encompassing, resolution-resistant conflict. Primary emphasis is on the issues as they stand today (Israel - Palestinians, Syria, Lebanon, Iran), the sides' concerns, fears and policy objectives. Students will write policy papers from the perspective of leaders from the different countries and participate in simulations. title: International Politics in the Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the interaction between indigenous Middle East conflicts and the policies of the outside powers. Will examine the roots of the Arab-Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the colonial legacy. With that background, will address questions such as: Did the Cold War always exacerbate the local conflicts in the region or did it actually dampen and control them as well? In this post-Cold War era, will we see more local conflicts? Will we see a final Arab-Israeli peace treaty? What is the likelihood of intensifying religious and ethnic conflicts?

title: International Politics in the Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the interaction between indigenous Middle East conflicts and the policies of the outside powers. Examines the roots of the Arab-Israeli-Palestinian conflict and addresses questions such as: Did the Cold War always exacerbate the local conflicts in the region or did it actually dampen and control them as well? In the aftermath of the collapse of the Oslo peace process and the events of September 11, what is the future role for the outside powers?

title: International Relations of the Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces students to patterns of international relations in the contemporary Middle East, to provide basic information about the region, and to prepare those who are interested in further study. The basic theme is the interrelatedness of issues that characterize politics in the Middle East. The main dimensions to be studied are the interactions between domestic and external politics, inter-Arab relations, the Arab-Israeli and Iran-Iraq conflicts, and the involvement of extraregional powers.

title: Chinese Foreign Policy, 1949-2017
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the descriptive history of China's international relations with special focus on different theoretical explanations for changes in foreign policy behavior (e.g. polarity, history, ideology, leadership, bureaucracy, among others).

title: Chinese Foreign Policy, 1949-2015
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the descriptive history of China's international relations with special focus on different theoretical explanations for changes in foreign policy behavior (e.g. polarity, history, ideology, leadership, bureaucracy, among others).

title: Chinese Foreign Policy, 1949-2012
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the descriptive history of China's international relations with special focus on different theoretical explanations for changes in foreign policy behavior (e.g. polarity, history, ideology, leadership, bureaucracy, among others). No prior background in China or international relations theory required.

title: Chinese Foreign Policy, 1949-1992
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to Chinese foreign policy. Provides a general descriptive history of Chinese foreign policy since 1949, and uses different theoretical and conceptual approaches from international relations and comparative foreign policy to test explanations of Chinese foreign policy behavior. A guiding question is: To what extent can Chinese foreign policy be explained by appealing to political, social, and cultural factors unique to China, and to what extent is Chinese behavior determined by processes and factors common to other states in the international system?

title: Foundations of Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an introduction to key concepts and theoretical approaches in comparative politics. Major themes include the causes of democratization, economic development, ethnic conflict, and social revolutions; as well as the role of the state, political institutions, and civil society. Examines and critically evaluates different theoretical approaches to politics including modernization, Marxist, cultural, institutionalist, and leadership-centered approaches. Compares cases from Africa, Asia, Europe, Middle East and Latin America to provide students with grounding in the basic tools of comparative analysis.

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an introductory grounding in the key theoretical frameworks, concepts, and analytical methods in comparative politics. The major theme focuses upon explaining patterns of democracy and democratizations, including the role of political culture and value change, civic society and social capital, economic development, problems of ethnic conflict, and the importance of political institutions. A broad global comparison will draw from many countries and regions.

subject: GOV

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an introduction to key concepts and theoretical approaches in comparative politics. Major themes include democratization and good governance, institutional structures, political culture, economic development, political participation, and ethnic conflict. Examines and critically evaluates major contemporary controversies in comparative politics and applies these in group workshop exercises focused on state-building in Afghanistan and Iraq. Compares cases from Africa, Asia, Europe, and Latin America to illustrate the basic tools and methods of comparative analysis. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Societies of the World.

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores important questions and concepts in contemporary comparative politics. Themes will include the dynamics of democracy and democratization, the historical evolution of citizenship, the power of ethnicity, the possibility of revolution, the importance of institutions, the cultural foundation of politics, and the pairing of market reform with political liberalization. Cases will be drawn from different regions and historical periods to give students a grounding in the tools of comparative analysis.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Graduate-level version of Gov. 1002. Meets with Gov. 1002, introduces theories of inference underlying most statistical methods and how new approaches are developed. Examples include discrete choice, event counts, durations, missing data, ecological inference, time-series cross sectional analysis, compositional data, causal inference, and others. Will require extra homework and examination problems in addition to those for Gov. 1002.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces theories of inference underlying most statistical methods and how new approaches are developed. Government 2000 or the equivalent.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces the theories of inference underlying most statistical methods. It covers how new approaches to research methods, data analysis, and statistical theory are developed. With this foundation, we introduce (and "reinvent") a wide variety of known statistical solutions to a wide range of social science data problems. We also show how it is easy to conceive original approaches and new statistical estimators when required. The specific models introduced will be chosen based on students' research topics. In past years they have included models for event counts, ecological inference, time-series cross sectional analysis, compositional data, causal inference, and others. Government 1000 or the equivalent is a prerequisite. More information is available at Gary King's website.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Graduate-level version of Gov. 1002. Meets with Gov. 1002, introduces theories of inference underlying most statistical methods and how new approaches are developed. Examples include discrete choice, event counts, durations, missing data, ecological inference, time-series cross sectional analysis, compositional data, causal inference, and others. Will require extra homework and examination problems in addition to those for Gov. 1002. Government 2000 or the equivalent.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces the theories of inference underlying most statistical methods. It covers how new approaches to research methods, data analysis, and statistical theory are developed. With this foundation, we introduce (and "reinvent") a wide variety of known statistical solutions to a wide range of social science data problems. We also show how it is easy to conceive original approaches and new statistical estimators when required. The specific models introduced will be chosen based on students research topics. In past years they have included models for event counts, ecological inference, time-series cross sectional analysis, compositional data, causal inference, and others. Government 2000 or the equivalent is usually (but not always) taken prior to 2001. More information is available at Gary King's homepage at Gking.Harvard.Edu.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since statistics is best learned in the context of specific statistical projects, we will organize the course around the following topics, each associated with a specific research project: statistical graphics; causality; likelihood; Bayesian statistics; aggregate data; ecological inference; and time series and time series-cross sectional models. The equivalent of three weeks (spread out over the semester) will be devoted to statistical topics related to student research projects. The course will be at the same level of difficulty as in the past, but students who have taken Government 2001 before will be eligible to do so again. Government 2000 or a course in multivariable linear models.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a deeper understanding of the theory of inference underlying most statistical procedures. Instead of the usual "assumption-violation-correction" approach to statistical analysis, the theory of inference enables students to create interesting models of the processes generating their data. Useful existing methodologies are reinvented, and new methods conceived. Substantive problems in student research emphasized. Government 2000 or permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces the theories of inference underlying most statistical methods. It covers how new approaches to research methods, data analysis, and statistical theory are developed. With this foundation, we introduce (and "reinvent") a wide variety of known statistical solutions to a wide range of social science data problems. We also show how it is easy to conceive original approaches and new statistical estimators when required. The specific models introduced will be chosen based on students' research topics. In past years they have included models for event counts, ecological inference, time-series cross sectional analysis, compositional data, causal inference, and others. Government 1000 or the equivalent is a prerequisite. More information is available at Gary King's homepage at www.GKing.Harvard.Edu.

title: Advanced Quantitative Political Analysis
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a deeper understanding of the theory of inference underlying most statistical procedures. Instead of the usual "assumption-violation-correction" approach to statistical analysis, the theory of inference enables students to create interesting models of the processes generating their data. Useful existing methodologies are reinvented, and new methods conceived. Substantive problems in student research emphasized. Government 2000 or permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Graduate-level version of Gov. 1002. Meets with Gov. 1002, introduces theories of inference underlying most statistical methods and how new approaches are developed. Examples include discrete choice, event counts, durations, missing data, ecological inference, time-series cross sectional analysis, compositional data, causal inference, and others. Will require extra homework and examination problems in addition to those for Gov. 1002. Government 2000 or the equivalent.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since statistics is best learned in the context of specific statistical projects, we will organize the course around the following topics, each associated with a specific research project: statistical graphics; causality; likelihood; Bayesian statistics; aggregate data; ecological inference; and time series and time series-cross sectional models. The equivalent of three weeks (spread out over the semester) will be devoted to statistical topics related to student research projects. The course will be at the same level of difficulty as in the past, but students who have taken Government 2001 before will be eligible to do so again. Government 2000 or a course in multivariable linear models.

subject: GOV

subject: GOV

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces the theories of inference underlying most statistical methods. It covers how new approaches to research methods, data analysis, and statistical theory are developed. With this foundation, we introduce (and "reinvent") a variety of known statistical solutions to a range of social science data problems. We also show how it is easy to conceive original approaches and new statistical estimators when required. The specific models introduced will be chosen based on student research topics. In past years they have included models for event counts, ecological inference, time-series cross section analysis, compositional data, casual inference, and others. Government 2000 or the equivalent is usually (but not always) taken prior to 2001. More information is available at Gary King's home page at GKing.harvard.edu.

title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methodology
subject: GOV

title: Causal Inference
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Substantive questions in empirical social science research are often causal. Does voter outreach increase turnout? Do political institutions affect economic development? Are job training programs effective? This class will introduce students to both the statistical theory and practice behind making these kinds of causal inferences. We will cover causal identification, potential outcomes, experiments, matching, regression, difference-in-differences, instrumental variables estimation, regression discontinuity designs, sensitivity analysis, dynamic causal inference, and more. The course will draw upon examples from political science, economics, sociology, law, public health, and public policy.
