title: Causal Inference
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Substantive questions in empirical scientific and policy research are often causal.  Does voter outreach increase turnout?  Are job training programs effective?  Can a universal health insurance program improve people's health?  This class will introduce students to both statistical theory and practice of causal inference.  As theoretical frameworks, we will discuss potential outcomes, causal graphs, randomization and model-based inference, sensitivity analysis, and partial identification.   We will also cover various methodological tools including randomized experiments, regression discontinuity designs, matching, regression, instrumental variables, difference-in-differences, and dynamic causal models.  The course will draw upon examples from political science, economics, education, public health, and other disciplines.

title: Topics in Quantitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Will cover topics of general interest to political methodology: causal inference, graphical models, mixed methods, contest modeling, text-as-data, item response. Illustrates how ideas and methods from these areas can be applied to substantive questions. Government 2000 and Government 2001, or equivalent, or permission of the instructor.

title: Topics in Quantitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores various topics in quantitative methods. Focuses on the robust estimation of generalized linear models but also covers some time series cross section methods. Government 2000 and Government 2001 or equivalent, or permission of the instructor.

title: Topics in Quantitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to two broad areas of modern statistics---graphical modeling and nonparametric inference. Government 2000 and Government 2001, or equivalent, or permission of the instructor.

title: Qualitative Analysis: Analytic Frameworks for Explaining and Predicting Decisions and Actions in Dom
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Exploration and practice in qualitative methods of analysis. Begins with examination of philosophical and conceptual assumptions embodied in alternative models for explaining and predicting decisions and actions in both domestic and foreign affairs. Examines theories of rational choice, cognition and perception, organizational behavior, bureaucratic politics, intergovernmental relations, and multilevel game theory. Each student will prepare a research paper. Grades will be based on the paper and on class participation. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-305. Meets at the Kennedy School.

subject: GOV

The principal case to be examined is the Cuban missile crisis. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-305. Meets at the Kennedy School.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine the philosophical and conceptual assumptions embodied in alternative models for explaining and predicting decisions and actions in both domestic and foreign affairs. The principal case to be examined is the Cuban missile crisis, beginning with The Essence of Decision, 1971, which is being substantially revised for publication. The seminar will examine theories of rational choice, cognition and perception, organizational behavior, bureaucratic politics, intergovernmental relations, and multi-level game theory. Each student will prepare a research paper. Grades will be based on the paper and on class participation. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-305. title: Analytic Frameworks for Explaining and Predicting Decisions and Actions in Domestic and Foreign Affa
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the philosophical and conceptual assumptions embodied in alternative models for explaining and predicting decisions and actions in both domestic and foreign affairs. The two principal cases to be examined are the Cuban missile crisis and health care reform proposals, in particular the origins and present circumstances of Medicare. Beginning with Essence of Decision, 1971, and The Politics of Medicare, 1973, both of which are being substantially revised for publication in 1997, the seminar will examine theories of rational choice, cognition and perception, organizational behavior, bureaucratic politics, intergovernmental relations, and multi-level game theory. Each student will prepare a research paper. Grades will be based on the paper and on class participation. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as IPI 305. Meets at the Kennedy School.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines political institutions from a rational choice perspective. title: Experimental Political Science
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Experimentation is increasingly used by political and other social scientists to help identify causal relationships. This class will cover arguments for and against the use of experiments, as well as a broad cross-section of foundational and cutting edge experiments in political science and allied fields. In particular, we will cover the use of survey experiments, field experiments, and lab experiments. Substantive applications will span the sub-fields as well as integrate work from experimental economics and psychology.

title: History, Institutions, and Political Analysis
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Drawing from all subfields of political science, this course examines theories and research designs attuned to issues of path dependence, historical sequence, timing, and temporal horizons. Considers approaches to analyzing institutional origins, development, and transformation.

title: History, Institutions, and Political Analysis
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A recent trend in political science has been the turn to history, as analysts ask what the investigation of earlier events and processes can tell us about the nature of contemporary politics. Course examines this body of research to clarify the pitfalls and possibilities of studying politics as a process which takes place over time. Among the themes to be explored are: ideas of path dependence and critical junctures in political development; techniques for studying the significance of timing and sequence in politics; and role of actors' time horizons_which may be long or short_in shaping political processes. Places considerable emphasis on recent theories of institutional origins, development and change, because institutions are perhaps the principal instruments through which previous politics shape current politics. Readings will include a wide range of empirical and theoretical writings drawn from all the subfields of political science.

title: Strategies for Political Inquiry
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Research design for causal inference in qualitative and quantitative studies. Topics covered include measurement, conceptualization, case studies, the relationship between large-n and small-n studies, process-tracing, surveys, field experiments, and natural experiments, with examples of their use in political science. Primarily for graduate students; may also be taken by undergraduates preparing for senior thesis research.

title: Strategies for Political Inquiry
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Research design for causal inference in qualitative and quantitative studies. Topics covered include measurement, conceptualization, case studies, the relationship between large-n and small-n studies, process-tracing, surveys, field experiments, and natural experiments, with examples of their use in political science.

title: Strategies of Political Inquiry
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: If you could learn only one thing in graduate school, it should be how to do scholarly research - assess scholarly literatures, identify interesting questions, formulate research designs, learn methodological tools, and write up results for publication. We discuss each for both quantitative and qualitative studies. Primarily for graduate students; also taken by undergraduates preparing for senior thesis research.

title: Strategies of Political Inquiry
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: If you could learn only one thing in graduate school, it should be how to do scholarly research. You should be able to assess the state of scholarly literature, identify interesting questions, formulate strategies for answering them, have the methodological tools with which to conduct the research, and understand how to write up the results so they can be published. Although many graduate level courses address these issues of research design indirectly, we provide an explicit analysis of each. We take empirical evidence to be historical, quantitative, or anthropological and focus on the theory of descriptive and causal inference underlying both quantitative and qualitative research. This year, we also plan to address ways that political philosophy and empirical analysis can be used to improve research in both areas. Frequently taken by graduate students at all levels, and by undergraduates preparing for senior thesis research. More information is available at Gary King's homepage at Gking.Harvard.Edu.

title: Strategies of Political Inquiry
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Research strategies in political science, materials from literatures in American and comparative politics, and international relations. After discussing the nature of political inquiry, an exemplary research program on representation is considered. Research strategies studied: quasi-experimental design; case study analysis; interviewing and sampling techniques. Attention paid to issues of measurement and combining analytical with contextual approaches.

title: Research Design in Political Science: Qualitative and Mixed Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to multi-method research design and the basic principles and tools of qualitative research in the social sciences. Topics examined include the logic of causal inference, measurement and conceptualization, choosing cases, natural experiments, the potential uses of mixed methods, and research ethics. Research techniques covered are process tracing, archival research, interviews, and ethnography. Students will also have the opportunity to workshop their early-stage research. The application of multi-methods research designs is emphasized throughout the course

title: Law and Political Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines debates about liberal political theory from two points of view: (1) To what extent is it possible or desirable to avoid controversial moral and religious values for purposes of politics and law? title: Ethics Economics, and Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores controversies about the use of markets and market reasoning in areas such as organ sales, procreation, environmental regulation, immigration policy, military service, voting, health care, education, and criminal justice. title: Markets, Morals, and Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Are there some things that money cannot or should not buy? If so, what moral limits, if any, should the law impose on market exchanges? The seminar will examine a range of morally contested contracts and exchanges _ from surrogacy, organ sales, and prostitution to usury and interest, vote-selling, life insurance, wage labor, and pollution permits _ and consider the philosophical questions they raise. Course readings will be drawn from political theory, moral philosophy, and selected law cases. Offered jointly with, and meets at, the Law School. Open to GSAS students with permission of the instructor.

title: Athenian Democracy and its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will open up ancient political thought and contemporary democratic theory through close study of Athenian politics and ideology and of the philosophical response. The ancient Athenians invented an unusually successful type of political regime and were remarkably self-conscious about what they were trying to do and how and why it worked. An important feature of their democracy was a largely sustained openness to ideas. The execution of Socrates was the exception not the rule, and dissent thrived in Athens. The philosophical work of Plato and Aristotle did not occur in isolation of or separation from the politics of the city. To an important extent, the ancient critics of Athens were also trying to cure it of what they saw as its failings. A study of key ancient Greek thinkers as critics of the democracy shines valuable light on their political theory generally. Importantly, it is only with the moderns—the Federalist Papers, Constant, Mill, Berlin, and even Rawls—that we find purely apolitical and theoretical criticism of ancient Athens. Their target is the Athenian ideal of political equality. By extending our study of critics of Athenian democracy into the contemporary period, we gain new insight about the place of the ideal of political equality in contemporary democratic theory and theories of justice.

title: Language and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates a number of different conceptions of language and studies their political and historiographical implications, focusing on texts by Locke, Durkheim, Mill, Neitzsche, Wittgenstein, Austin, Skinner, Pocock, Derrida, and Habermas.

title: Language and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates a number of different conceptions of language and studies their political and historiographical implications, focusing on texts by Locke, Durkheim, Mill, Nietzsche, Wittgenstein, Austin, Skinner, Pocock, Derrida, and Habermas.

title: Pluralism and Citizenship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines some of the classic political theoretical texts on pluralism and citizenship in light of recent political and theoretical developments regarding such issues as nationalism, cosmopolitanism, feminism, immigration, migrant workers, multiculturalism in education, and the politics of sexuality.

title: Contemporary Political Thought: Contract and Politics
subject: GOV

subject: GOV

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Contemporary feminist theory poses a radical challenge to established understandings of politics, the public/private split, citizenship, the legal subject and the meaning of rights. Focusing in particular on the feminist reconceptualization of the self, the citizen and the legal person, also documents controversies in contemporary feminist theory between neoliberals, critical theorists, and postmodernists.

courseDescriptionLong: Considers such issues as: What idea of a rational agent is presupposed in modern rational choice theory? Does rationality have a history? What are the wider philosophical implications of issues such as the free rider problem? The course will not require anything other than a general familiarity with rational choice theory.

title: Theory of Collective Choice: Strategy, Voting, and Choice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to game-theoretic concepts within a political framework. Focus on preferences, strategic choice, and equilibrium concepts. Analysis of various voting procedures under different institutional and behavioral regimes. Systematic introduction to Arrow's Impossibility Theorem and resulting literature.

title: Theory of Collective Choice: Strategy, Voting, and Choice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to game-theoretic concepts within a political framework. Focus on preferences, strategic choice, and equilibrium concepts. title: Democratic Theory and Election Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the theoretical dimensions of contemporary legal controversies about the electoral process in the United States. Among the topics considered are concepts of representation in racial districting, the meaning of free choice in a two-party system, and the limits of majoritarianism in the governance of elections. Offered jointly with Harvard Law School as 92050-31. To be given at the Law School. Students who plan to register for the course through FAS should submit a letter of interest and a brief description of academic background to Professor Thompson. Students registering through the Law School should send this material to Professor Gerken.

title: Theory of Collective Choice: Institutions

courseDescriptionLong: Examines political institutions from a rational choice perspective. Additional topics may include elections systems, public goods and collective action, coalitions, and agenda processes.

title: Collective Choice: Institutions and Positive Political Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines political institutions from a rational choice perspective. The now-burgeoning rational choice literature on legislatures, bureaucracies, courts, and elections constitutes the chief focus. Some focus on institutions from a comparative and/or international perspective. Government 2050 or equivalent recommended.

title: Theory of Collective Choice: Institutions and Positive Political Theory

title: Plato's Political Philosophy

title: Justice and the Family
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar explores how political thought has conceived the family as a model of political society, and how standards of justice and right apply in turn to the family. Taking into account the rise of "Assisted Reproductive Technologies" (ARTs), it discusses how they affect the question of procreative liberty, and new issues of distributive justice. It also examines grounds and dimensions of parenthood, children's rights, and moral education.

title: Platonic Rhetoric
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the role of rhetoric in democratic deliberation and philosophy in Plato's middle dialogues: Gorgias, Symposium and Phaedrus. It will focus on the relationship between rhetorical persuasion and Plato's theory of the psyche. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Platonic Rhetoric

title: Political Thought of the English Revolution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will survey the remarkable range of political responses to the English constitutional crisis of 1640 to 1660, from theories of divine right to the arguments of the Levellers. Readings will include Filmer, Harrington, Lilburne, Milton, Nedham, Parker, and Sidney. Special attention will be paid to the idiosyncratic perspective of Thomas Hobbes.

title: Markets and Enlightenment: The 18th-Century Debate on the Morals and Politics of Commercial Society
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to Enlightenment theories of political economy and the various critiques and affirmations of modern civilization with which they were associated at the time. The seminar compares the morally contested theoretical histories of the origins of morality, sociability, and government emerging from the writings of Mandeville, Montesquieu, Hume, Rousseau, Adam Smith, Kant, and other 18th-century authors. Topics will include the luxury debate, ^'^'Das Adam Smith Problem'' (including controversies between Adam Smith, Rousseau, and the Physiocrats), and questions related to the form and principle of the modern (as opposed to classical) republic. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Politics and Economics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Covers the political economy of policymaking and institutional change. Readings include a mixture of foundational approaches and recent research. Topics include political business cycles and voting; debt, deficits, and the size of government; political economy of trade and growth; bureaucracy, government formation, and constitutional choice.

title: The Political Philosophy of Kant
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A consideration of Immanuel Kant with a view to uncovering the unity and significance of his thought and its importance for politics today. Readings drawn from the three Critiques as well as essays by Kant on politics, history and medicine. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: The Political Philosophy of Kant
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A consideration of Immanuel Kant with a view to uncovering the unity and significance of his thought and its importance for politics today. Readings drawn from the three Critiques as well as essays by Kant on politics, history and medicine. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Perspectives on Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A microperspective on various topics in political economy, including the emergence and development of institutions, property rights, agency relationships, the effects of time on politics, and the role of politicians (^'^'putting the politicians back in'').

subject: GOV

title: Perspectives on Political Economy: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In 1991$92, the focus is on theories of bargaining. Special prominence is given to strategic issues (foresight, signaling, commitment, incomplete information) and to substantive illustrations (legislative negotiation, executive-legislative bargaining, distributive politics, coalition governments).

title: Perspectives on Political Economy
subject: GOV

title: Perspectives on Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This year the seminar focuses on four broad areas: elections, legislative processes, bureaucratic behavior, and coalition formation. In each area, the seminar reviews the classic political economy contributions, the subsequent development of the literature, and, via guest speakers, the current position of the research frontier.

title: Perspectives on Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the broad arguments of leading political economists in recent book-length studies. Explores the work of North, Barzel, Coase, Williamson, Bates, Przeworski, and others in general treatises on political economy, theories of property rights, institutions, and organizations, and recent research on development in the industrialized and industrializing world.

title: Nations, States, and Citizens
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines questions of citizenship and political membership in the global era. Examines philosophies of citizenship as well as recent developments in citizenship practices in the European Union. Readings from Aristotle, Rousseau, Kant, Arendt, Walzer, Habermas, Taylor, Shklar, Brubacker and Rogers Smith.

title: Associations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar focuses on freedom for associational life, with readings drawn from the history of political thought, contemporary philosophy, and law. The question ``should government impose public norms of justice on the internal lives of groups?'' will focus on cultural groups, religious associations, and political parties.

title: Political Theory and the Public Sphere
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the concept of the public sphere in the light of challenges posed by the new "politics of recognition'' and "group-differentiated citizenship rights.'' Readings from: Arendt, Rawls, Habermas, Taylor, Young, Kymlicka, and Fraser.

title: Political Theory and the Public Sphere
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The concept of the 'public sphere' is central for understanding the mode of legitimacy characteristic of modern political societies. The public sphere also refers to a set of institutions, social practices, forms of association, and modes of communication central to democratic self-government. Focuses on John Rawls's concept of "free public reason,'' and Habermas's theory of the public sphere.

title: Theories of Ideology and False Consciousness
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Irrationality and self-deception are striking and troubling features of life in society. But how to understand them? This course will examine the theory of ideology as it developed in Marxist social thought before looking at some prominent recent accounts of false consciousness and its significance for politics.

title: Liberalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the arguments and strategies liberal political philosophers have adopted to handle the problem of value pluralism. Readings from J.S. Mill, J. Locke, F. Hayek, J. Habermas, J. Rawls, I. Berlin, J. Raz, and P. Mehta. Limited enrollment.

title: Liberal Constitutionalism and Its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of works in moral, political, and constitutional theory bearing on the foundations and social and cultural implications of liberal democracy. Readings to include works by John Dewey, Michel Foucault, Charles Taylor, John Rawls, Catherine MacKinnon, Roberto Unger, and others.

title: Liberalism
subject: GOV

title: Social Theory and Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides an introduction to social theory and its application to comparative politics. Theorists addressed include: Aristotle, Smith, Mill, Marx, Weber, Durkheim, and Foucault. Topics covered include: nationalism, democratization, etc.

title: Virtue and the Making of Modern Liberalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines major works in the making of modern liberalism with special emphasis on the ambivalence about virtue that has characterized the liberal spirit at its best.

title: Social Theory and Comparative Politics

title: Contemporary Virtue Ethics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This graduate seminar studies the revival of a neo-Aristotelian ethics of virtue in contemporary moral philosophy, considering, among others, Iris Murdoch, John McDowell, Bernard Williams, Philippa Foot, Nancy Sherman, Henry Richardson, and Alasdair MacIntyre. Offered jointly with the Law School as 91812A. Meets at the Law School.

title: Contemporary Virtue Ethics
subject: GOV

title: Public Reason in Theory and Practice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine the ``public sphere'' both as a distinctive feature of European society in the 18th century and as an ideal in recent political thought. Attention will be given both to discussions of the historical development of the various institutions associated with the public sphere (salons, coffee houses, the book trade, Masonic lodges) and with the attempts of thinkers such as Jürgen Habermas, Onora O'Neill, and John Rawls to articulate the particular features of the form of political reasoning that emerged from such institutions.

title: The Political Philosophy of Thomas Hobbes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Is Hobbes an authoritarian who subordinated all values to the requirements of state power or is he a defender of objective moral values and a precursor of modern liberal theory? This course will examine the tensions between the apparently 'illiberal' and 'liberal' aspects of Hobbes' political thought. Topics covered will include his absolutism versus his individualism, his theory of the citizen's duties versus his theory of the citizen's rights, and his advocacy of the political control of beliefs versus his theory of religious toleration. Texts studied: Leviathan; also the Elements of Law and De Cive; and modern commentaries. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Partial Associations and Democratic Freedom
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The late 20th century has seen a great deal of discussion about the political importance of what can be called "intermediate" associations: theories about ^'^'social capital'', ^'^'the institutions of civil society'', ^'^'middle democracy'', and so on, are all dealing with these kinds of bodies. But this discussion has a long and surprising history. From the time of Hobbes onwards, many of the most powerful modern political theorists attacked what Rousseau called ^'^'partial associations'', including churches, guilds, and political parties, as the principal constraints on human freedom and democracy. This course will consider the history of this debate, beginning in 16th-century France with Jean Bodin, and ending in late 20th-century America; writers to be studied from this perspective include Hobbes, Rousseau, Adam Smith, Kant, Hegel, Marx, the early 20th-century writers on political parties and current theorists of "social capital".

title: Liberalism and Theodicy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will investigate the theological origins of what we have come to call “liberal” political philosophy.  In particular, it will explore the degree to which central liberal commitments—to the freedom of the will, religious toleration, and political liberty—emerged as responses to the problem of “theodicy” (the challenge of vindicating God’s justice, given the manifold evils present in the world).  Throughout, we will be seeking to understand the fraught relationship between contemporary egalitarianism and the early-modern liberal tradition.  Readings will include Grotius, Milton, Locke, Leibniz, Rousseau, Kant, Rawls, Dworkin, and Cohen.

courseDescriptionLong: Justice as 'ascent' from negative legal forbearance, from harm to doing positive good from 'wise love' and benevolence. Readings from Plato, Cicero, Augustine, Shakespeare (four plays), Leibniz, Wagner and Freud (Civilization and "Leonardo da Vinci".)

title: Justice as Love and Benevolence (from Plato, Cicero and Augustine to Shakespeare, Leibniz and Freud)
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Justice as 'ascent' from negative legal forbearance, from harm to doing positive good from 'wise love' and benevolence. Readings from Plato, Cicero, Augustine, Shakespeare (four plays), Leibniz, Wagner and Freud (Civilization and "Leonardo da Vinci".)

title: Moral Values in Political Science
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will introduce students of descriptive political science to the subject of normative theory, exploring the proper place of moral values in social inquiry and addressing a variety of major ethical-political debates.

title: Moral Values in Political Science
subject: GOV

title: Political Development: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the developmental problems of contemporary Third World countries, focusing on their efforts to achieve state-building, national integration, and political participation. Discusses the role of ethnicity and religion in politics. Examines regime transitions.

title: Politics of Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This graduate seminar centers on big questions related to why development occurs in some places or times and not others and adopts a broad understanding of development, focusing on both economic and social development. Topics include but are not limited to states and markets, the origins and effects of the “developmental state” and state capacity, regime type and development, the influence of historical legacies, the role of elites and citizens in driving development, welfare regime variation in developing countries, ethnoreligious diversity and development, the relationship between development and conflict, and the relationship between the scholarly study of development and development policy and practice. The course opens with foundational approaches and quickly moves into key contemporary debates, with readings that use a broad array of methods and approaches.

title: Strategies of Political Inquiry
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Research strategies in political science, materials from literatures in American and comparative politics, and international relations. After discussing the nature of political inquiry, an exemplary research program on representation is considered. Research strategies studied: quasi-experimental design; case study analysis; interviewing and sampling techniques. Attention paid to issues of measurement and combining analytical with contextual approaches.

title: Comparative Politics: Field Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys topics in comparative politics (both the developed and the developing world), including the rise of the modern state; institutions of government; interest mediation; democracy and authoritarianism; revolution; political parties; mass and elite political behavior; political economy.

title: The New Institutionalism and Political Analysis
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the resurgence of interest in institutional analysis. Approaches based on comparative historical investigation, rational choice theory, and organizational analysis are evaluated and compared. Considers the strengths and limitations of various forms of institutional analysis for investigating empirical issues in comparative politics, especially in the areas of comparative public policy and political economy.

title: The New Institutionalism and Political Analysis
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the resurgence of interest in institutional analysis. Approaches based on comparative historical investigation, rational choice theory, and organizational analysis are evaluated and compared. Considers the strengths and limitations of various forms of institutional analysis for investigating empirical issues in comparative politics, especially in the areas of comparative public policy and political economy.

title: Comparative Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of several main topics and theories in comparative political economy with a focus on advanced industrial democracies. Concentrates on theories that try to explain fundamental differences in economic policy and performance across nations, seeking to establish the relative importance of institutional variables, political cleavages, partisanship and ideology with particular attention to pressures for convergence and the politics associated with ^'globalization'.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Advanced research seminar on the origins of, conditions for, operation of, and reform of democratic polities. Readings in empirically rooted democratic theory, with emphasis on issues of research strategy.

title: Analysis of the Political Economy of Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Students will attend lectures of Social Analysis 52 and then meet as a separate seminar. The readings and discussion will focus on the political economy of agriculture and industrialization; of ethnicity and political conflict; and of state formation and political collapse.

title: The Politics of Marketization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the political strategies and the political implications of introducing or fundamentally altering property rights, forms of economic organization, and capital markets in a wide range of historical and contemporary cases.

title: The Political Economy of Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Students will attend lectures of Social Analysis 52 and then meet as a separate seminar. The readings and discussion will focus on the political economy of agriculture and industrialization; of ethnicity and political conflict; and of state formation and political collapse.

title: Topics in the Political Economy of Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Topics in the political economy of development: the relationship between regime types and economic performance; links between property rights and economic performance; problems of collective action and cooperation in the rural sector; agriculture-industry linkages in development; forms of organization and industrial performance; state intervention and industrialization; cultural factors in economic development; why economies have different historical trajectories (Latin America vs. East Asia, East Asia vs. South Asia). A prior knowledge of development issues (Government 1100) is helpful but not necessary.

title: Topics in the Political Economy of Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Presents an overview of the field of political economy of development. The readings are thematically organized. Under each theme appear several country cases, taken from all parts of the developing world. The themes for the year are: the concept development; agriculture-industry linkages in development; issues in the agrarian sector _ land reforms, technical change, poverty and inequality; issues in the industrial sector _ strategies of industrialization, role of foreign capital, trade and technology; economic stabilization and structural adjustment; democracy and development; culture and development.

title: Topics in the Political Economy of Development

title: The Politics and Economics of Policy Reform
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In recent years, developing nations have liberalized their markets, balanced their budgets, and democratized. Centrally planned economies have introduced private ownership and markets. In this course, we concentrate on the politics and economics of these reforms.

title: The Politics and Economics of Policy Reform
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the politics of economic policy reform in the developing countries and former socialist economies.

title: The Politics and Economics of Policy Reform
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the politics of economic policy reform in the developing countries and former socialist economies.

title: The Politics and Economics of Policy Reform
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In recent years, developing nations have liberalized their markets, balanced their budgets, and democratized. Centrally planned economies have introduced private ownership and markets. In this course, we concentrate on the politics and economics of these reforms.

title: Transitions to Democracy in Theoretical and Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Through examination of theoretical works and case studies from Latin American, South European, and East European transitions, explores complex patterns of regime changes, their social, political, and economic causes and consequences, conditions conducive to the establishment of functioning democratic institutions, and typical dilemmas faced by collective actors during transitions.

title: Democracy and Its Problems: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the development of modern democracy and the relations between democratization and democracy, on the one hand, and economic development, economic reform, socioeconomic equity, and political stability on the other. Major theories are discussed in the light of recent experience.

title: Political Corruption (Graduate Seminar in General Education)
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Addresses the definition, causes, patterns, consequences, and control of political corruption, and its relationship to political and economic development. The seminar will design and develop a General Education course on these themes for undergraduates.

title: Democracy and Its Problems: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the development of modern democracy and the relations between democratization and democracy, on the one hand, and economic development, economic reform, socioeconomic equity, and political stability on the other. Major theories are discussed in the light of recent experience.

title: The Iranian Revolution and Its Impact on the Middle East: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: First, examines the social, intellectual, and political origins of the Islamic revolution in Iran. Then focuses on Lebanon, Iraq, and Afghanistan, and analyzes the impact of the revolution on these countries, especially on developments in their Shi'ite communities. Emphasis on the interplay between international and transnational relations.

title: Civil Wars: Theory and Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to the theoretical and comparative study of civil wars. The course aims to provide students with solid analytical and historical foundations and highlight the policy dilemmas associated with civil wars. Open to junior and senior undergraduates with instructor's approval. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-409. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Seminar on Political Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the literature on political development. Beginning with modernization theory, it moves through the study of political culture to the study of political economy, both Marxian and neoclassical. Highlighting the debates between the approaches, it also strives for synthesis and integration.

title: Religion and Global Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Religion is clearly a force to be reckoned with in global politics. Yet, its connection is not well understood. This course examines the conditions under which religion contributes to conflict or cooperation in international politics. Open to junior and senior undergraduates with permission of instructor. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as IGA-121. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Governance in Developing Countries
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This graduate seminar provides an overview of the research frontier on governance in developing countries, including democracies, electoral autocracies, and authoritarian regimes. Topics include democratization and democratic erosion, voting behavior, clientelism, accountability, the bureaucracy, and the role of foreign aid. While including some foundational readings, the syllabus puts emphasis on recent work. Readings primarily draw from comparative politics, political economy, and development economics. In addition to theory and empirics, the course focusses on the nuts and bolts of implementing governance-related fieldwork in developing countries.

subject: GOV

title: Democracy and Authoritarianism in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores theoretical explanations of democracy and authoritarianism in Latin America in the 20th century. Particular emphasis on the Southern Cone and Mexico. Critically examines the role of historical structural factors, political economy, leadership, social movements, culture, and institutions in explaining the origins, consolidation, and breakdown of democratic and authoritarian regimes in the region.

title: Challenges and Change in the Developed Political Economies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How do countries develop different varieties of capitalism and types of welfare states and what drives their evolution over time? How are the developed political economies responding to the principal challenges they face today, associated with the rise of services, technological change, inequality, high debt loads and competition from emerging economies? What does this imply for theories of institutional change? We will look at some classic works and recent approaches to these issues with some emphasis on the OECD countries.

title: Church and State: Global Perspectives
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Liberal democracies around the world are asked to balance religious freedom and state neutrality, and to do so in an increasingly diverse and socially explosive world. What are the competing models of secularism for today's democracies? What are the possibilities, and limits, of religious liberty in increasingly diverse polities? These questions are examined by engaging historical developments in American and European legislation and jurisprudence. Offered Jointly with the Law School as LAW-90455A. Meets at the Law School.

title: Church and State: Global Perspectives
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Liberal democracies around the world are asked to balance religious freedom and state neutrality, and to do so in an increasingly diverse and socially explosive world. What are the competing models of secularism for today's democracies? What are the possibilities, and limits, of religious liberty in increasingly diverse polities? These questions are examined by engaging historical developments in American and European legislation and jurisprudence. Offered Jointly with the Law School as LAW-90455A. Meets at the Law School.

title: Democratic Transitions, Breakdowns, Stagnations, and Advances
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong:
The first part of this course will examine the conditions that help make democracies and authoritarian regimes stable or that, conversely, give rise to democratic breakdowns and transitions to democracies. These questions have long been of central interest to social scientists, historians, and democracy advocates. And they sometimes have huge consequences for the world, as was tragically demonstrated by the aftermath of the breakdown of democracy in Germany in 1933.

The second half of the course will analyze patterns of democratic stagnation and deepening after transitions to democracy. In the wave of democratization that began in 1974, despite a large number of transitions to electoral democracy (well over 100 according to the Varieties of Democracy coding), few countries have been able to develop high-quality liberal democracies, with solid protection of citizen and opposition rights and solid mechanisms of accountability. What accounts for the success cases? Why have few countries been able to develop deeper quality democracies? Why so many stagnations and breakdowns?

title: History, Institutions, and Political Analysis
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A recent trend in political science has been the turn to history, as analysts ask what the investigation of earlier events and processes can tell us about the nature of contemporary politics. Course examines this body of research to clarify the pitfalls and possibilities of studying politics as a process which takes place over time. Among the themes to be explored are: ideas of path dependence and critical junctures in political development; techniques for studying the significance of timing and sequence in politics; and role of actors' time horizons_which may be long or short_in shaping political processes. Places considerable emphasis on recent theories of institutional origins, development and change, because institutions are perhaps the principal instruments through which previous politics shape current politics. Readings will include a wide range of empirical and theoretical writings drawn from all the subfields of political science.

title: Civil Society, West and East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores the rise of civil society in states worldwide. It examines the debates over what civil society is, the notion of ``public space,'' and the idea of ``civic engagement,'' and looks at the complex relationship between civil society and the state, on the one hand, and markets, on the other. After tracing the emergence of civil society in Western Europe, the seminar looks at the forms civil society is taking in other settings, from Eastern Europe to the Asia-Pacific. It examines how a wide range of factors, from wars to the internet to the rise of international NGOs, affects the nature and quality of civic life, and democratic transitions, in different countries.

title: Politics and Economics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Covers the political economy of policymaking and institutional change. Readings include a mixture of foundational approaches and recent research, covering a variety of methodological perspectives. The topical emphasis is on democracy, accountability, inequality, redistribution, and growth.

title: Politics and Economics
subject: GOV

title: Electoral Systems and Electoral Behavior
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the interaction of electoral institutions and social forces in the production of electoral outcomes, as revealed principally by the empirical literature but with some consideration of theory. Evidence comes mainly from countries with a serious body of survey research. The relative emphasis on the U.S. and other countries is yet to be determined. Students planning to enroll should consult the instructor during the fall term.

title: Perspectives on Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A microperspective on various topics in political economy, including the emergence and development of institutions, property rights, agency relationships, the effects of time on politics, and the role of politicians (^'^'putting the politicians back in'').

title: Perspectives on Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A microperspective on various topics in political economy. This year, the focus will be on demography (the size and composition of populations and the structure of the family); its impact and politics; and the impact of politics on it.

title: The Problem of Money in Electoral Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course looks at the (mostly American) literature on campaign and party finance in comparative perspective, addressing the ways in which political funding might affect political representation and governance in both developed and newer democracies.

title: The Problem of Money in Electoral Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course looks at the (mostly American) literature on campaign and party finance in comparative perspective, addressing the ways in which political funding might affect political representation and governance in both developed and newer democracies.

title: Topics in Comparative Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines new theories in comparative political economy with applications to advanced democracies, past and present. Topics include the politics of economic performance, inequality and redistribution, macroeconomic policies, and the economic origins of political institutions.

title: Topics in Comparative Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines new theories in comparative political economy with applications to advanced democracies, past and present. Topics include the politics of economic performance, inequality and redistribution, macroeconomic policies, and the economic origins of political institutions.

title: Constitutional Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The breakup of authoritarian regimes, the growth of ethno-linguistic conflicts, and other factors have led to an explosion of constitution-writing and amendment in a wide variety of modern societies. This course will examine the forces that give rise to demands for constitutional change, the ways in which the process of constitution-making and constitutional change differ from ^'^'normal'' politics, including the factors making for ^'success' or ^'failure,' and the issues, outcomes, and consequences of constitutional debates. Special attention will be given to multilevel governance in federal and quasi-federal systems. Cases will include Canada as a central focus, along with countries such as Spain, Belgium, South Africa and one or more countries from Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.

title: Constitutional Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The breakup of authoritarian regimes, the growth of ethno-linguistic conflicts, and other factors have led to an explosion of constitution-writing and amendment in a wide variety of modern societies. This course will examine the forces that give rise to demands for constitutional change, the ways in which the process of constitution-making and constitutional change differ from ^'^'normal'' politics, including the factors making for ^'success' or ^'failure,' and the issues, outcomes, and consequences of constitutional debates. Special attention will be given to multilevel governance in federal and quasi-federal systems. Cases will include Canada as a central focus, along with countries such as Spain, Belgium, South Africa and one or more countries from Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.

title: Comparative Constitutionalism and Judicial Review
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of pertinent jurisprudential and political aspects of the international migration of constitutional ideas and the global expansion of judicial review; constitutional transformation; comparative legal institutions and judicial behavior; and the judicialization of politics worldwide.

title: Comparative Constitutionalism and Judicial Review
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of pertinent jurisprudential and political aspects of the international migration of constitutional ideas and the global expansion of judicial review; constitutional transformation; comparative legal institutions and judicial behavior; and the judicialization of politics worldwide.

title: Individual Opinion Formation and Societal Choice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar focuses upon how individuals form opinions when confronted with consequential political choices, notably in debates over constitutional change or international economic integration. First, the course surveys theories of individual choice, drawing on works in economics, sociology, philosophy and political psychology. Second, we will review the empirical literature about opinion formation on constitutional change (with an emphasis on Quebec and Canada) and on economic integration initiatives (NAFTA and the EU). Third, students will prepare and present an empirical study of opinion formation, relying on the statistical analysis of survey data. Some knowledge of multivariate statistical methods is expected.

title: Individual Opinion Formation and Societal Choice

title: Sexual Violence
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar analyzes sexual violence (e.g., rape, sexual slavery, enforced sterilization) from a comparative and interdisciplinary perspective. The seminar aims to explain and understand variation among cases. Cases are drawn from countries engulfed in collective violence.

title: Sexual Violence
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar analyzes sexual violence (e.g., rape, sexual slavery, enforced sterilization) from a comparative and interdisciplinary perspective. The seminar aims to explain and understand variation among cases. Cases are drawn from countries engulfed in collective violence.

title: State-Building
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates state-building in comparative perspective. With focus on developing and developed worlds, topics include: What is the state? What theoretical approaches best explain strong and weak states? What are consequences of these variations?

title: State-Building
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates state-building in comparative perspective. With focus on developing and developed worlds, topics include: What is the state? What theoretical approaches best explain strong and weak states? What are consequences of these variations?

title: The Political Economy of Globalization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines changes in the international economy and their effects on domestic politics, economy and society from a broad comparative and historical perspective with attention to their impact on the state, social groups, and politics. Taught cooperatively with an MIT seminar led by Professor Suzanne Berger.

title: The Political Economy of Globalization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines changes in the international economy and their effects on domestic politics, economy and society from a broad comparative and historical perspective with attention to their impact on the state, social groups, and politics. Taught cooperatively with an MIT seminar led by Professor Suzanne Berger.

title: Nationalism and Democracy in Europe (and beyond): Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines theoretical approaches to and empirical cases of nationalist movements and politics in their interactions with modern state building and democracy. Topics include functions of nationalism(s) in multi-ethnic states, in democratic transitions, and vis-á-vis supranational integration.

title: Nationalism and Democracy in Europe (and beyond): Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines theoretical approaches to and empirical cases of nationalist movements and politics in their interactions with modern state building and democracy. Topics include functions of nationalism(s) in multi-ethnic states, in democratic transitions, and vis-á-vis supranational integration.

title: Comparative Politics of the Welfare State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the factors leading to distinctive patterns of social policy across the advanced industrial societies. Particular attention paid to the impact of contemporary pressures for austerity on national welfare states, and to an exploration of the linkages between systems of social provision and distinctive national ^'^'models'' of economic development.

title: Varieties of Capitalism and Social Inequality
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores economic and social inequality in the affluent democracies. How do institutional arrangements reconcile efficiency and equality and affect the dynamics of redistribution? How is institutional change best understood? Taught with Kathleen Thelen of MIT.

title: Social and Political Change in the Political Economies of Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the transformation of the west European democracies since World War II. How did the distinctive couplings of an open economy, government activism, and welfare regimes create and change an `embedded liberalism'? How did the globalization of capital markets, technology, women in the labor market, postindustrialization, and electoral systems influence the policy response and allocate the costs of adjustment in Europe and the US?

title: Politics of Social Inequality in the Developed Democracies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers competing perspectives on the social well being of nations and its determinants. Topics include: the politics of inequality in the development of democracy, the electoral causes and consequences of inequality, change in varieties of capitalism, the impact of culture and institutions on inequalities of income and health, with a focus on Europe and the OECD countries.

title: Politics of Social Inequality in the Developed Democracies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers competing perspectives on the social well being of nations and its determinants. Topics include: the politics of inequality in the development of democracy, the electoral causes and consequences of inequality, change in varieties of capitalism, the impact of culture and institutions on inequalities of income and health, with a focus on Europe and the OECD countries. //

courseDescriptionLong: Explores economic and social inequality in the affluent democracies. Meets at MIT room E51-390.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the transformation of the west European democracies since World War II. How did the distinctive couplings of an open economy, government activism, and welfare regimes create and change an `embedded liberalism'? How did the globalization of capital markets, technology, women in the labor market, postindustrialization, and electoral systems influence the policy response and allocate the costs of adjustment in Europe and the US?

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers competing perspectives on the social well being of nations and its determinants. Topics include: the politics of inequality in the development of democracy, the electoral causes and consequences of inequality, change in varieties of capitalism, the impact of culture and institutions on inequalities of income and health, with a focus on Europe and the OECD countries. //

title: Varieties of Capitalism and Social Inequality
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the political economies of the affluent democracies with some emphasis on Europe. How do welfare states and other institutional arrangements affect the dynamics of redistribution? What is the relationship between changes in electoral politics and the political economy? How is institutional change best understood?

title: Cohesion and Competitiveness of the Enlarged European Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course covers economic developments in the Enlarged European Union but will also refer to `Wider Europe'. Emphasis is on issues of `cohesion' and `competitiveness', the two areas which have dominated the policy debate within the European Union. Offered jointly through the Kennedy School as IGA-326. IGA-326 meets at the Kennedy School RG 20.

title: Cohesion and Competitiveness of the Enlarged European Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course covers economic developments in the Enlarged European Union but will also refer to `Wider Europe'. Emphasis is on issues of `cohesion' and `competitiveness', the two areas which have dominated the policy debate within the European Union. Offered jointly through the Kennedy School as IGA-326. IGA-326 meets at the Kennedy School RG 20.

title: Contemporary Welfare Capitalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines different approaches to the study of welfare capitalism in its distinct national forms across advanced democracies. Emphasis is placed on explaining differences in social institutions, policies, and outcomes across countries, and on exploring how these institutions, policies, and outcomes are affected over time by globalization and other forces of change. What are the trade-offs between policy goals such as equality and economic growth, and how are the choices over these trade-offs affected by national political institutions, the organization of production, and partisan politics?

title: Contemporary Welfare Capitalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines different approaches to the study of welfare capitalism in its distinct national forms across advanced democracies. Emphasis is placed on explaining differences in social institutions, policies, and outcomes across countries, and on exploring how these institutions, policies, and outcomes are affected over time by globalization and other forces of change. What are the trade-offs between policy goals such as equality and economic growth, and how are the choices over these trade-offs affected by national political institutions, the organization of production, and partisan politics?

title: Contemporary Welfare Capitalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines different approaches to the study of welfare capitalism in its distinct national forms across advanced democracies. Emphasis is placed on explaining differences in social institutions, policies, and outcomes across countries, and on exploring how these institutions, policies, and outcomes are affected over time by globalization and other forces of change. What are the trade-offs between policy goals such as equality and economic growth, and how are the choices over these trade-offs affected by national political institutions, the organization of production, and partisan politics?

title: Institutional Innovations for Liberal Democracies: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Citizens' disaffection and policy elites' ineffectiveness are key complaints about the working of Western democracies, sometimes dubbed "post-democracies". The course will review institutional remedies as suggested by "deliberative" theorists and "participatory" practitioners of liberal democracy.

title: Institutional Innovations for Liberal Democracies: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Citizens' disaffection and policy elites' ineffectiveness are key complaints about the working of Western democracies, sometimes dubbed "post-democracies". The course will review institutional remedies as suggested by "deliberative" theorists and "participatory" practitioners of liberal democracy.

title: Democracy and Accountability in the New Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a ``democratic deficit'' in Europe? Political decisions are increasingly delegated to insulated, non-majoritarian institutions, national bureaucracies, constitutional courts, central banks, and international organizations. In what sense are administrators, judges, diplomats, and chief executives democratically accountable? What are the political consequences? The course looks to positive and normative theory, as well as empirical material drawn from European integration, Central European democratic transitions, and West European political development, with assistance from visiting senior European scholars.

title: State and Society in Western Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers problems in the political development of Western Europe with emphasis on the application of social and political theory to historical cases. Topics include: the character of feudal society, the rise of absolutism, determinants of state formation, democratic revolutions, working-class organizations, and the development of mass politics and party systems. Focuses on Britain, France, and Germany, 14th-19th centuries.

title: Democracy and Accountability in the New Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a ``democratic deficit'' in Europe? Political decisions are increasingly delegated to insulated, non-majoritarian institutions, national bureaucracies, constitutional courts, central banks, and international organizations. In what sense are administrators, judges, diplomats, and chief executives democratically accountable? What are the political consequences? The course looks to positive and normative theory, as well as empirical material drawn from European integration, Central European democratic transitions, and West European political development, with assistance from visiting senior European scholars.

title: Civil Society and Political Culture in Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Deals with the history and several theoretical traditions of civil society, particularly in modern and contemporary times; the debate on the role and limits of the state; the links between theories of civil society and the liberal tradition. Explores topics on the relation between civil society and political culture in different national settings.

title: European Political Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Concentrates on the close reading of classics in the field by, among others, Tocqueville, Marx, Weber, Hintze, and Rokkan, as well as more recent works by Luebbert, Baldwin, and Putnam.

title: The New Institutionalism and European Political Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines recent "new institutionalist" contributions to the literature on European political development by Anderson, Mann, Luebbert, and Putnam, as well as older institutionalist analyses by Tocqueville, Hintze, and Weber.

title: European Studies: Perspectives on Democratization West and East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the process of building and rebuilding democratic institutions in societies emerging from authoritarian and totalitarian rule. Considers the impact of various domestic and international factors on initiations and trajectories of democratic transition. Emphasizes difficulties and dilemmas of developing effective institutions and procedures for stable competitive politics. Cotaught with visiting scholars from Europe.

title: European Studies: Perspectives on Democratization West and East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the process of building and rebuilding democratic institutions in societies emerging from authoritarian and totalitarian rule. Considers the impact of various domestic and international factors on initiations and trajectories of democratic transition. Emphasizes difficulties and dilemmas of developing effective institutions and procedures for stable competitive politics.

title: European Studies: Perspectives in European Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the functioning of the principal political economies of Europe, including those of Germany, France, Italy, Scandinavia, and Britain, with an emphasis on how the institutional frameworks of the labor market, business, government, and the macroeconomy affect economic policy and performance. Cotaught with visiting professors from Europe.

title: European Studies: The Domestic Politics of Trade and Integration
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the effects of increased trade and financial integration in the European Community and EMS especially on domestic political processes and structures. Cotaught with visiting European professors.

title: European Studies Seminar: The State in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In the context of the modern and contemporary history of Germany, France, Italy, and Spain, the course considers the traditions of state-building in the 18th and 19th centuries; the rise of the welfare state in more recent times: and the condition and role of the state today. Open to qualified undergraduates. Knowledge of either French or German.

title: European Studies Seminar: The State in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In the context of the modern and contemporary history of Germany, France, Italy, and Spain, the course considers the traditions of state-building in the 18th and 19th centuries; the rise of the welfare state in more recent times: and the condition and role of the state today. Open to qualified undergraduates. Knowledge of either French or German.

title: Politics in the New Germany: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores and examines politics and society in the New Federal Republic of Germany after unification. Emphasis is on the transformations in East Germany, changes in the political culture, recasting of political parties, the political economy of unification, and Germany's role in Europe. Reading knowledge of German desirable.

title: Comparative Political Economy and International Integration
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the impact of increased trade and financial integration across the industrialized nations, with special reference to Western Europe, on domestic institutions, politics and policies.

title: African Political Systems: Power and Society in African States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Comparative analysis of selected features of African states. Special attention given to the processes of predatory governance within African states during the past 30 years (e.g., coercion dynamics, elite cooptation of ethnic blocs, regulation of elite cleavages, etc.). Attention also given to rebirth of participatory politics and evaluation of its prospects. Case studies are emphasized (e.g., Zambia, Nigeria, Zaire, Ghana, Kenya, Uganda, Malawi, Togo, Gabon).

subject: GOV

title: The Politics of Africa and Southeast Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The countries of Africa and Southeast Asia have many characteristics in common, including similar resource endowments, ethnic diversity, colonial heritage (in some cases), and high levels of nonproductive rent-seeking. Yet there is considerable diversity within and between regions in rates of economic growth and the character of economic policy. The politics of these two regions are introduced, to explain patterns in policy outcomes and performance.

title: Topics in the Political Economy of Africa
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews theoretical debates and cases germane to three topics: agrarian protest, interest formation in the African informal sector, and the implementation of structural adjustment programs. Topics will change each year.

title: Political and Economic Development in Africa
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Students will attend lectures with SA52 and then meet for a two hour seminar. Reading and discussion will focus on the political economy of development in Africa, viewed from an historical perspective.

title: Global Islam
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the emergence, development and increasing influence of contemporary forms of Islamic engagement and thinking such as the Muslim Brothers, or Al Qaeda, that are not limited to a particular country or ethnic/cultural group. title: Radicalization of Islam in the Former Communist World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines rise of radical Islamism in the former Communist Bloc from Tsarist rule to al-Quaeda. Covers Islamist ideologies, conditions promoting radicalism, and comparative theories of Islamic mobilization, in Afghanistan, Chechnya, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Xinjiang.

title: Radicalization of Islam in the Former Communist World

title: Collective Actions, Protest Movements, and Politics: Eastern Europe in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews the contemporary literature on collective action, protest, and social movements. Focuses primarily on political factors facilitating protest, repertoires of contention, the rose of cultural factors and the construction of identities through collective action, and methods of studying collective action. Analyzes protest movements in Eastern Europe both under communist rule and after 1989 within the framework of this literature.

title: Collective Actions, Protest Movements, and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews the contemporary literature on collective action, protest, and social movements. Focuses primarily on political factors facilitating protest, repertoires of contention, the role of cultural factors and the construction of identities through collective action, and methods of studying collective action. Cases will be drawn from different regions and historical periods.

title: Democracy and Its Prospects in the Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the historical, cultural, institutional, and socioeconomic factors shaping the prospects for democratization in the region.

title: Approaches to the Study of Soviet Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews the major analytical approaches to Soviet political life, weighing their strengths and weaknesses, and explores the ways of doing research that will adequately test old theories and build new and better ones.

title: Political Economy of the Post-Socialist Transition
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the effort to build market economies in Eastern Europe and the states of the former Soviet Union.

title: Political Economy of the Post-Socialist Transition

title: Comparative Politics of the Post-Soviet States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Soviet politics from Lenin to Gorbachev, and the transition to market economy and competitive elections in, and the territorial dissolution of, the Soviet Union are covered at first. Constitutional design and political parties; ethnicity, nationalism, and secessionism; varieties of political economic configurations; international relations; social structure and civil society; questions of "stateness" and state breakdown; religion and politics; and the quest for national identities in the post-Soviet states are among the topics to be discussed.

title: Comparative Political Institutions
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This is a graduate-level introduction to the comparative study of political institutions and their impact on various aspects of political behavior. Topics include regime types, presidential and parliamentary forms of government, federalism, electoral systems, parties, and coalitions. Students will gain an understanding of the main concepts, approaches, and analytical tools needed to carry out their own independent research in this field.

title: Comparative Political Institutions

title: Party System Institutionalization, Decay, and Collapse
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine the building, decay, and collapse of political parties and party systems, as well as the consequences of these processes.  In 1942, the well known political scientist E. E. Schattschneider famously wrote that “Political parties created modern democracy and modern democracy is unthinkable save in terms of the parties.” When we survey the world’s democratic and semi-democratic polities, however, outside of the advanced industrial democracies, many have weak parties and inchoate party systems. In many countries, once powerful parties have disappeared. In other third and fourth wave democracies, solid parties underpin solid democracies, just as Schattschneider expected. What accounts for successful party building and for the institutionalization of a party system? What accounts for the collapse of major parties and even entire party systems? Why do parties remain weak in some democracies and semi-democracies? How does the institutionalization of parties under authoritarian rule affect the political regime? These are some of the questions we will grapple with.

title: Politics and Political Economy in Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores major issues in Japanese politics and political economy in historical and comparative perspective, including the role of the ruling party, bureaucracy, and big business in policymaking; the trade-offs of a ^'^'one-party dominant'' political system; the role of an opposition in such a system; and the international, sociocultural, economic, and political determinants of domestic policy choices. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Politics and Political Economy in Japan
subject: GOV

subject: GOV

title: Politics and Reform in the Giants: India and China Compared
subject: GOV

subject: GOV

title: Political Science and China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the major theories and issues found in the most important Western analyses of contemporary Chinese politics. Among the questions considered are different conceptualizations of conflict and change; the nature of political control and elite mass relations; political participation, influence, and the pursuit of interest; policy making and policy implementation; and the nature of bureaucratic politics.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on primary sources for the study of Chinese politics: archives, documents, gazetteers, yearbooks, interviews, etc. Students write a major research paper, using primary sources. Government 2285 required.
