title: Chinese Elite Politics: The End of the Yenan Round Table, 1959-1966
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the political crises that engulfed and finally sundered the Chinese leadership in the years between the Lushan plenum and the Cultural Revolution. A major objective of the seminar is to introduce students to new materials. A good reading knowledge of Chinese and previous course work in Chinese politics.

title: Research Seminar on Chinese Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on primary sources for the study of Chinese politics: archives, documents, gazetteers, yearbooks, interviews, etc. Students write a major research paper, using primary sources. Government 2285 required.

title: Chinese Elite Politics: Besides Mao
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the careers of senior Chinese communists in order to explore perspectives on the Chinese revolution other than Mao Zedong's.

title: Elections and Congress: Forecasts and Institutions
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The focus is the electoral connection to Congress. Why do candidates win or lose? Can the outcome of congressional contests be predicted in advance? What institutional features influence the tie of representatives to the people?

title: Race and Federalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine "the oldest question in constitutional law," how we divide power between the states and the national government, from the perspective of race and racial minorities. We will read historical articles, legal articles, empirical articles, and cases to understand how and whether federalism works for racial groups.

title: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Designed to acquaint PhD candidates in Government with a variety of approaches that have proved useful in examining important topics in the study of American government and politics.

title: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Designed to acquaint Ph.D. candidates in Government with a variety of approaches that have proved useful in examining important topics in the study of American government and politics. title: Frontiers in American Political Research
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Presents a free-flowing examination of important recent work in American politics including bureaucratic behavior and the increasing use of field experiments. The professors will propose seven to eight topics and students are invited to proposes others.

title: Frontiers in American Political Research
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will engage in a free-flowing examination of important recent work in American politics, with an eye toward pointing students in rewarding research directionsd. Professors Dickinson and Fiorina will each propose three or four topics and students are invited to propose several others. Proposed topics include contemporary racial attitudes, knowledge in the America electorate, hierarchy and other structures in bureaucracy, the public presidency, do parties matter.

title: Frontiers in American Political Research
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Presents a free-flowing examination of important recent work in American politics including bureaucratic behavior and the increasing use of field experiments. The professors will propose seven to eight topics and students are invited to proposes others.

title: Social Capital and Public Affairs: Research Seminar

title: Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class examines key questions in the study of public opinion, such as the role of knowledge and information, the stability of attitudes, and how public opinion shapes political decision making of leaders. The class also teaches students how to design and analyze public opinion surveys. During this class we will design, conduct and analyze 3 national sample surveys, using a professional survey firm.

title: Public Opinion and Public Choice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relationship between public opinion and public policy. Studies macroeconomic, health, and technology policy development. Also explores nontraditional method. Qualified undergraduates are welcome.

title: Public Opinion and Public Choice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the theoretical and empirical issues involved in understanding modern public opinion and its relationship to public choices. Investigates the role public opinion plays in influencing public policy decisions. Examines the positive political economy approach, among others. Although the main focus is on the United States, some other developed countries are studied.

title: Topics in American Political Behavior
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Course surveys field of political behavior, emphasizing recent developments in literature. Topics include uncertainty; opinion change and learning; partisanship and ideology; salience of race and social identity; participation; links between public opinion, elections, and policy.

title: Legislative and Popular Constitutionalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will study American constitutionalism as it is expressed in legislative and popular fora. We will survey the rapidly growing body of literature in law, political science, and history that explores the life of the Constitution outside the courts, and we will consider the relationship between judicial and extra-judicial constitutional interpretation. Paper required. Offered jointly with the Law School as 96825A. Meets at the Law School.

title: Legislative and Popular Constitutionalism
subject: GOV

We will survey the rapidly growing body of literature in law, political science, and history that explores the life of the Constitution outside the courts, and we will consider the relationship between judicial and extra-judicial constitutional interpretation. Paper required. Offered jointly with the Law School as 96825A. Meets at the Law School.

title: American Politics: Power, Structure, Behavior
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar covers empirical and theoretical research on power, structure, and behavior in American politics, emphasizing what we know and how we present research to various audiences, especially through textbooks, legal cases, and media. Statistics and/or game theory recommended.

title: American Politics: Power, Structure, Behavior
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar covers empirical and theoretical research on power, structure, and behavior in American politics, emphasizing what we know and how we present research to various audiences, especially through textbooks, legal cases, and media. Statistics and/or game theory recommended.

title: Working with Legislatures
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What do lobbyists, social activists, business executives, and political advocates have in common? Whether you are involved in non-profit, for-profit, or issue-related causes, you will have to cope with the legislative process. Your ability to understand legislatures and influence legislative decisions will give you a major advantage in achieving your goals. This course is an in-depth exploration of legislatures, how legislators make their decisions, and how citizens can best influence those decisions. The syllabus blends Political Science theories with case studies and a semester-long legislative simulation. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as PAL-210. There is a Ph.D. section, offered through the Government Department. Only Ph.D. students may sign up for this course using the Government Department number. Ph.D. students will participate in all classroom exercises, complete a publishable research paper, and meet for one extra hour per week at the Government Department. Otherwise, course sessions will be held at the Kennedy School. Ph.D section is TBA.

title: The U.S. Congress and Lawmaking
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How does the U.S. Congress really work? This course blends theory and practice to train anyone who may someday work in or lobby the U.S.Congress. The course is an in-depth exploration of legislative rules and procedures, how legislators make their decisions, and how citizens can best influence those decisions. Students practice what they are learning through a simulation, then analyze their experiences in a term paper. Dozens of current legislative staffers and several elected officials first learned about legislatures through this course, though it now also includes an optional Ph.D.-level component, offered through the Government Department. Ph.D. students write a publishable piece of original research evaluating a current set of theories. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as PAL-210. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: American Constitutional Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: American Constitutional Development highlights American constitutional developments from ratification until the twenty-first century. The seminar will focus on both judicial decisions and constitutional developments outside of the courts.

title: American Constitutional Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: American Constitutional Development highlights American constitutional developments from ratification until the twenty-first century. The seminar will focus on both judicial decisions and constitutional developments outside of the courts.

title: American Political Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys debates about research on the historical development of U.S. government and politics, 1890 to the present. Persistent and changing governmental institutions, party regimes, and public policies analyzed in relation to markets, elections, issue agendas, war, and the social identities and groups involved in successive phases of 20th century American politics. Particular attention paid to the critical analysis of the research methodologies that underpin this literature.

title: American Political Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys debates and research about the historical development of U.S. government and politics, 19th century to the present. Persistent and changing governmental institutions analyzed in relation to elections and party systems, issue agendas and patterns of public policy, and the social identities and groups involved in successive phases of modern American politics.

title: American Political Development and Contemporary Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the US polity since World War II, making explicit the theoretical and methodological underpinnings of an institutionalist and developmental approach sensitive to processes and structural transformations. Examines state capacities; relations of business, labor, and the state; public policies (including ``the rights revolution''); and civic engagement and interest intermediation. Taught cooperatively with an M.I.T. seminar led by Professor Daniel Kryder.

title: Electoral Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines the politics of U.S. elections, with emphasis on theoretical models of electoral competition and empirical research of voting behavior and election outcomes.  The first third of the seminar examines voter behavior, the second third of the seminar electoral competition among parties and candidates and aggregate election results, and the final third of the seminar examines electoral institutions and laws.  Specific topics include party competition, incumbency advantages, electoral districts, campaign finance, issue and economic voting, and electoral accountability.  Understanding of statistics strongly recommended.  Open to qualified undergraduates with permission of instructor.

courseDescriptionLong: A theoretically driven examination of the role of market-government relations. title: American Political Thought: Different Paths from Pluribus to Unum
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Overview of American political thought revolving around the question "What does it mean to be an American?" Through readings ranging from the Federalists/Anti-Federalists to Walzer and Taylor we explore the different contexts in which this question has been posed and answered.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Combines American political thought and popular ideologies--canonical works (Federalist Papers, Tocqueville, Lincoln) are read for their explicit philosophy as well as assumptions about power and status. Also examines the social, economic, and political context of the writings.

courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the origins, evolution, political functions, and value of American federalism, with emphasis on the causes and consequences of centralization. What preserves federalism? Is it worth preserving?

title: The New Political Economy of Federalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Seeks to integrate political and economic approaches into a new political economy of federalism. Theories about state and local politics and policy making in a federal system are critically analyzed. Presentations by visiting scholars supplement seminar discussions.

title: The New Political Economy of Federalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Seeks to integrate political and economic approaches into a new political economy of federalism. Theories about state and local politics and policy making in a federal system are critically analyzed. Presentations by visiting scholars supplement seminar discussions.

title: Constitutionalism in the Administrative State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the constitutional status of administrative power by comparing 18th-century theories of constitutionalism with 20th-century debates about bureaucracy. Particular attention given to changing notions of political authority and human nature that seem to be associated with the rise of bureaucratic power.

title: Issues, the Economy, and Elections
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the factors influencing choices made by voters in United States elections at the national level. Research on elections in the United States has demonstrated a robust empirical relationship between the state of the macro-economy and the willingness of voters to re-elect the party in power, and it has also demonstrated the importance of the issue positions of candidates and the preferences of the voters. We consider in detail the mechanisms by which issues and the economy operate to shape choices made by voters. There will be some cross-national consideration of these forces.

title: Issues, the Economy, and Elections

subject: GOV

subject: GOV

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores American political economy in comparative perspective, focusing on research about varieties of capitalism, group influence in politics, inequality, public opinion, and patterns of public policy.  Jointly offered by MIT.

title: Political Change in the Urban Ghetto
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Emphasizes the politics of inclusion that has characterized Black urban communities since early 1970s. Attention given to character of Black political class, especially the interplay between its "public-regarding'' and "private-regarding'' patterns. The range and quality of public policy outcomes of Black governance is treated. Case studies undertaken.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a survey of some of the major issues in urban politics over the past thirty years. Begins with a theoretical consideration of power and its definition, and then uses this theoretical insight to guide discussions. Explores the pluralist view of ethnic succession, the revisionist account of political machines, an argument for elite-driven politics, and the importance of race and class. Talks about changes in the city through regionalism, suburbanization, and reform and how these complicate the discussions of urban politics. Lastly, explores where urban politics is headed today, examining coalition-building and the ^'post-modern' city.

title: The Presidency and the Constitutional Order
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the American Presidency from a constitutional and historical perspective. Begins with the American Founding and the debate about the proper relationship between republican government and executive energy. Studies the historical evolution of the Presidency into its modern form. Topics to be examined include the organization of the Presidency, presidential selection, the relationship of the presidency to other branches of government and to political parties, presidential war-making, presidential budgeting, the imperial presidency, and the presidency in comparative perspective.

title: Courts and Public Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines various approaches to studying the judiciary and its effect on public policy. title: Political Geography
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class explores the influence of space on political behavior. The course will explore the theoretical underpinnings of spatial analysis, read current literature that focuses on geography and politics, and provide applied resources of technology and data for using spatial analysis in research. The class will focus mostly on American politics, but will also use examples from comparative studies.

title: Gender, Movement Politics, and Public Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the influence of grassroots politics, feminist social movements and women's organizations on the policymaking process and policy outcomes. It focuses on women as political actors in contemporary politics (e.g., as voters, activists and leaders) covering such issues as the gender gap and women's leadership style. Finally, the course explores a number of policy areas relevant to gender and politics, including reproductive issues, workplace issues, education issues, women in the military and social welfare policy. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as PAL-237. Meets at the Kennedy School.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A research-oriented course focused on African-American politics. A central theme is how the intersection of structures of gender, class, and race influence black politics. Both quantitative and qualitative approaches considered.

title: Racial and Ethnic Politics in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course begins with the history and structure of the classic Black-White binary, then addresses ways in which it must be rethought to include other groups, mainly Asians and Latinos. Issues include racialization, immigrant incorporation, political coalitions and conflict, racial mixture, and links between race, class, gender, and ideology. Focuses on the United States but includes comparisons with Europe, Latin America, and South Africa.

title: Identity: Ethnicity, Nationalism and Race
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course proposes to explore such questions as: How should we go about describing ethnicity, nationalism, and race? Should we treat them as primordial or as social constructions? Much of the recent literature suggests the latter. If they are constructed, then by whom (or by what)? What constrains/structures these constructions? What purposes do these constructions serve? Whom do they serve? Are some constructions better representations of identity than others, and what does this mean? Readings will be drawn from various fields across political science as well as other related social sciences.

title: Race, Ethnicity, and Identity
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An in-depth discussion of identity in contemporary ethnic and racial politics in the United States, and the manner in which identity issues play out in urban politics, redistricting, and other settings.

title: Identity: Ethnicity, Nationalism and Race
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course proposes to explore such questions as: How should we go about describing ethnicity, nationalism, and race? What constrains/structures these constructions? What purposes do these constructions serve? Whom do they serve? Are some constructions better representations of identity than others, and what does this mean? Readings will be drawn from various fields across political science as well as other related social sciences.

title: Ethnicity, Nationalism, and Race
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A theoretical introduction to three principal fields of investigation in the area of identity politics. The course has two objectives. The first is methodological: to discuss different approaches in the social sciences to 'soft' concepts like 'ethnicity,' 'nationalism,' etc. What are the strengths and weaknesses of cultural, instrumental, institutional, structural, and historical approaches to these concepts? The second is theoretical: to discuss these approaches in relation to three fields of study-ethnicity, nationalism and race.

title: United States Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A critical survey of major approaches in the analysis of U.S. foreign policy. The extent to which structural-institutional, political, cultural, ideological, bureaucratic, and cognitive approaches help illuminate the shaping of U.S. foreign policy is assessed. Cases include the Cold War, foreign economic policy, the Cuban missile crisis, Vietnam, the Persian Gulf conflict, and post-Cold War policy.

title: Special Topics in International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This is a graduate level reading course on international relations. The purpose is to both continue preparation for general exams, and to encourage students to develop their dissertation prospectus. Special attention is given to reading book length projects in preparation for designing and organizing the PhD dissertation. Permission of instructor required.

title: The Politics of International Monetary and Financial Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Covers two interrelated topics. The first is the political economy of international finance: sovereign lending, international banking, international financial integration. The second is the politics of international monetary relations: monetary regimes, inter-state monetary interactions, national macroeconomic policy.

title: Psychology and International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A critical survey of psychological approaches to international relations. Topics include the psychology of deterrence, groupthink, defensive avoidance, bolstering, cognitive maps, self-perception, and schema theories. Special attention given to the empirical applications of these concepts.

title: European Studies: Nationalism in Contemporary Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The historical origins, development, and current manifestations of national consciousness and nationalism in Britain, France, Germany, and Central Europe, as well as the external effects of these manifestations.

title: Politics of International Trade
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines theories of trade and protectionism, emphasizing relations among advanced industrial states. Topics include endogenous tariff theory, the politics of nontariff barriers, the prospects for regional economic integration, the novelty of the new trade theory, and the future of GATT.

title: European Studies: Europe-American Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The recent issues and tensions in the relations of the US with France, the UK, Germany, and the European Union. Specialists from Europe participate throughout.

title: European Studies: Comparative West European Responses to the end of the Cold War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative analysis of the foreign policies of major West European governments in response to the collapse of Communism, German reunification, and the intensification of European integration. Special emphasis will be placed on transatlantic relations, the choice of security and economic regimes, the diplomacy of German reunification, and the Europeanization of national foreign policies. Co-taught with visiting European professors. Meets at the Center for European Studies.

title: European Studies: Europe-American Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The recent issues and tensions in the relations of the US with France, the UK, Germany, and the European Union. Specialists from Europe participate throughout.

title: The Use of Force: Political and Moral Criteria
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine normative discourse about the use of force. Primary attention will be paid analytically and historically to the ^'^'Just-War/Just-Defense'' ethic. Readings and lectures will assess the ethic in light of challenges to it from the tradition of non-violence and from the nature of modern warfare. The Just-War ethic will then be assessed in light of three cases: nuclear strategy, hi-tech conventional war, and interventions. Open to qualified undergraduates. Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 2853, and with the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-340. Meets at FAS.

title: Nationalism and National Identity: An Exploration Through Film
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course addresses contemporary issues of nationalism through the medium of films as well as traditional scholarship. The course explores the fine line between the celebration of national identity as a source of pride, creativity and exchange, and the explosion of nationalism as a source of exclusion, destruction and war. It also seeks to uncover some of the similarities and differences between alternative national contexts and historical periods. By understanding how official stories, personal memories and collective myths interact in shaping the real and imaginary boundaries of nations around the globe, students can become better able to confront the challenges of foreign policy making. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-307. Meets at the Kennedy School.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In-depth research on cases including human rights, the International Criminal Court, the Kyoto Protocol, and weapons of mass destruction, in which the US has failed to cooperate with other nations. Offered jointly with the Law School as 90110-31. Meets at the Law School.

title: Theories of International Conflict
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes theories of international conflict at a variety of levels of analysis, beginning with international structural theories and then moving on to institutional theories and the role of regimes, dyadic theories such as deterrence, domestic political or economic theories of war, and finally individual level theories such as those based on cognitive or motivated misperceptions.

title: Critical Perspectives on Critical IR Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Whether one likes it or not, there is a growing interest in the field in approaches that have been placed under the rubric of ^'^'critical'' IR theory. These have tended to provoke polarized and ill-informed debates in the field. This course hopes to turn a more sober eye on new and marginalized approaches. What is ^'^'New'' about this literature? What criteria should one use to assess the theoretical and empirical contributions of these literatures? How do scholars do empirical research? Is this all a dead-end? The course will look at constructivism, feminist IR theory, ^'^'post-modernism,'' cultural/ideational analyses among approaches. Government 2710 or equivalent.

title: European Studies Seminar: European Terrorism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will look back to the demise of European Social Revolutionary terrorist movements and analyze their place in post-war European history. It will examine contemporary terrorist movements operating in Europe and European efforts to develop a joint strategy in response. It will also look to the future role of Europe in the development of transnational terrorist movements. Prominent European scholars will participate in the seminar.

title: Strategic Models in International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course focuses on canonical and recent theoretical models of conflict, cooperation, and exchange in international relations.  We asses how these theories have successfully (or unsuccessfully) generated empirically accurate predictions about conflict and cooperation.  We also ask how theories formalized with game theoretic models differed from their non-formal counterparts.  This course focuses on theory, though we will also consider some empirical applications and the relationship between theoretical and empirical arguments.  Formal I or an equivalent class is strongly recommended.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of approaches in international political economy and discussion of their strengths and weaknesses in explaining major developments in the world economy since the age of mercantilism. Topics include the role of economic analysis in international political economy, realism vs. institutionalism, and the relationship between domestic politics and international economic affairs.

title: International Organization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The number and scope of international organizations continues to expand so that there are few areas of international politics that are not regulated in some way by an international institution, whether informal norms or a formal organization. Why do states establish institutions and what determines their design and evolution?  Do these institutions merely reflect underlying power and interests? These are some of the questions we will be asking in this course. It is an advanced research seminar that will introduce theories of international institutions, evaluate critical perspectives, and examine applications in security, economic, and environmental policy areas.

title: International Organization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: International politics increasingly means institutionalized interaction among states. This course examines the sources and effects of international institutions. It draws on institutional theories from many fields: international relations, American politics, economics. The purpose is to generate topics for research.

title: International Organization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: International politics increasingly means institutionalized interaction among states. We examine the sources and effects of international institutions. title: The New Economics of Organization and International Institutional Change
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: International relations is characterized by serious contracting problems. The seminar's goal is to analyze how the recent literature on contracting theory and the new economics of organization, especially as applied in international economics and political science, can help understand these issues and how international institutions are designed to respond to them.

title: National Policy and International System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the effects of change in the international system on national policy, and examines the interaction between the forces that shape national policies and the international balance of power. Compares the way in which Britain and France responded to the major changes in the structure of the international system in the 19th and 20th centuries.

title: European Studies: The Foreign Policies of European States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The foreign policies of France, West Germany, Italy, and Britain, with special reference to East-West relations and to West European integration.

title: International Institutions: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the role played by international institutions in 20th-century world politics, examining the functions of international institutions, their comparative performance, and the relationship between international institutions and the structure of world politics.

title: Japan and the Third World: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers Japan's role in Third World development in context of changes in the international order and as a case for studying Japan's evolving world role. Topics include: prewar imperialism and colonial rule; current aid, trade, investment, and debt-relief initiatives; the U.S.-Japan-Third World triangle; Japan's economic impact in Asia, Latin America, and Africa Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Japan and the Third World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers Japan's role in Third World development in context of changes in the international order and as a case for studying Japan's evolving world role. Topics include prewar imperialism and colonial rule; current aid, trade, investment, and debt-relief initiatives; the U.S.-Japan-Third World triangle; Japan's economic impact in Asia, Latin America, and Africa. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: U.S.-Japan Relations: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores issues and problems in U.S.-Japan economic, political, and security relations since 1945. Cases to be analyzed include export friction (agricultural trade, autos), access friction (semiconductors, construction contract bidding), the debates over "burden-sharing'' and defense coproduction, and U.S.-Japan conflict and cooperation vis-à-vis third areas, including the Soviet Union, the Third World, and the Persian Gulf.

title: Japan in the New World Order
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores theories about the "new world order" and the possible scenarios for Japan's future international role, the nexus between diplomacy and domestic politics, and the sources of political and economic conflict and cooperation in Japanese foreign relations.

title: Japan and East Asian Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How does Japan's remilitarization impact upon East Asia? Topics include: Japan's strategy and policy-making; JSDF military power; the US-Japan alliance; Japan and North Korea, China and Southeast Asia; defense production; Japan's nuclear policy; and multilateral security.

title: Japan and East Asian Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How does Japan's remilitarization impact upon East Asia? Topics include: Japan's strategy and policy-making; JSDF military power; the US-Japan alliance; Japan and North Korea, China and Southeast Asia; defense production; Japan's nuclear policy; and multilateral security.

title: War and Cinema
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Academic study of war focuses on strategies of states, leaders and armies. What are war's effects on civilians and soldiers? This course concentrates on films, examining the dilemmas and plight of individuals caught in interstate and civil wars. Open to qualified upper classmen. Limited enrollment.

title: War, Peace, and Global Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of conflict and cooperation in contemporary global politics: relations among the major powers; economic, military, and ^'^'soft'' power; weapons proliferation; ethnic conflicts; neo-realism, the end of history, transnationalism, and the clash of civilizations.

title: War, Peace, and Global Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of conflict and cooperation in contemporary global politics: relations among the major powers; economic, military, and ^'^'soft'' power; weapons proliferation; ethnic conflicts; neo-realism, the end of history, transnationalism, and the clash of civilizations.

title: Global Politics in the Post-Cold War World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews the emerging patterns of conflict in post-Cold War global politics, focusing on the relations among the major powers, the roles of economic, military, and ^'^'soft'' power, weapons proliferation, and ethnic conflicts. An effort will be made to evaluate to what extent post-Cold War global politics can be explained by such theories as neo-realism, the end of history, economic integration, transnationalism, and the clash of civilizations. Open to qualified undergraduates.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The historical and contemporary roles of religious beliefs and religious organizations with respect to war and peace, civil conflict, national identities, legitimacy of governments, human rights, democracy, conflict management, conceptions of world order. Case studies. Open to qualified undergraduates. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-432 and with the Divinity School as 2816. Meets at FAS.

title: The Post-Cold War World: Chaos, Convergence, and the Politics of Civilizations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores sources of conflict and cooperation in the post$Cold War world and alternative paradigms for understanding that world. Considers the chaos and convergence paradigms and then explores the strengths and weaknesses of a civilized approach focusing on culture as a source on conflict and cooperation, the relations among major civilizations (Western, Islamic, Orthodox, Sinic, Japanese, Hindu, Latin American, African), particularly those between the ^'^'West and the rest'', and the rise of intercivilizational issues such as proliferation, human rights, and immigration. Also explores the relation between Westernization and modernization and the rise of religious fundamentalism. Open to qualified graduate and undergraduate students.

title: The Post-Cold War World: Chaos, Convergence, and the Politics of Civilizations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores sources of conflict and cooperation in the post$Cold War world and alternative paradigms for understanding that world. Considers the chaos and convergence paradigms and then explores the strengths and weaknesses of a civilized approach focusing on culture as a source on conflict and cooperation, the relations among major civilizations (Western, Islamic, Orthodox, Sinic, Japanese, Hindu, Latin American, African), particularly those between the ^'^'West and the rest'', and the rise of intercivilizational issues such as proliferation, human rights, and immigration. Also explores the relation between Westernization and modernization and the rise of religious fundamentalism. Open to qualified graduate and undergraduate students.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of central issues of American foreign policy today. For each issue, analysis of the international environment, identification of specific policy options, consideration of pros and cons, reflection on processes for choice and action. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-202. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of central issues of American foreign policy today. For each issue, analysis of the international environment, identification of specific policy options, consideration of pros and cons, reflection on processes for choice and action. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-202. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV

Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-202. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of central issues of American foreign policy today. What developments pose principal challenges and opportunities for U.S. policy? What are priority U.S. national interests? In foreign policymaking, how are national, domestic, and bureaucratic interests and perspectives adjudicated and amalgamated? Course examines a dozen issues at the top of the current international agenda_from ``loose nukes'' in Russia, potential confrontation with China over Taiwan, and peacekeeping in Rwanda to trade disputes with Japan and the IMF reform_and analyzes the international environment, identifies specific policy options, considers pros and cons, and reflects on processes for choice and action. Course seeks to combine operational assignments and conceptual/theoretical writings that help clarify choices. Students learn both about current issues and how to analyze issues and present them in option memos. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-202. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: U.S. Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the domestic setting, international structure, and institutional constraints that determine major foreign policy choices. Places special emphasis on management of the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as S-247.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of central issues of American foreign policy today. What developments pose principal challenges and opportunities for U.S. policy? What are priority U.S. national interests? In foreign policymaking, how are national, domestic, and bureaucratic interests and perspectives adjudicated and amalgamated? Course examines a dozen issues at the top of the current international agenda_from ``loose nukes'' in Russia, potential confrontation with China over Taiwan, and peacekeeping in Rwanda to trade disputes with Japan and the IMF reform_and analyzes the international environment, identifies specific policy options, considers pros and cons, and reflects on processes for choice and action. Course seeks to combine operational assignments and conceptual/theoretical writings that help clarify choices. Students learn both about current issues and how to analyze issues and present them in option memos. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-202. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes, through lectures and cases specific foreign policy issues the United States currently faces: the relationship between the United States and Russia; nuclear proliferation; US-European relations; the Middle East; Japan; China. Offered jointly with, and meets at, the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-340.

title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Grappling with the hardest U.S. national security challenges of the decade ahead-nuclear terrorism, Iran, North Korea, Afghanistan and Pakistan, the rise of China-while the endless cycle of leaks and press analysis complicates the process of developing sound policy and strategy. Students will learn to devise strategies and write strategic options memos as part of the policymaking process, all while balancing the need to communicate to major constituencies to sustain public support, while coping with a world where a pervasive press makes solitary secrecy a luxury of the past. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as IGA-201. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: U.S. Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the domestic setting, international structure, and institutional constraints that determine major foreign policy choices. Places special emphasis on management of the relationship between the United States and the former Soviet Union. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as S-247.

title: Central Challenges of American Foreign Policy

What are priority US national interests? In foreign policymaking, how are national, domestic, and bureaucratic interests and perspectives adjudicated and amalgamated? Course seeks to combine operational assignments and conceptual/theoretical writings that help clarify choices. For a dozen central issues at the top of the post-Cold War agenda, analysis of the international environment, identification specific policy options, consideration of pros and cons, reflection on processes for choice and action. Course seeks to combine operational assignments and conceptual/theoretical writings that help clarify choices. Students both learn about current issues and how to analyze issues and present them in option memos. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as ISP-202. For this year only, students who plan to take this course must cross-register under the Kennedy School number, ISP-202.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar is designed for advanced students with a serious professional interest in international security. It presumes prior coursework and/or experience in foreign and national security policymaking. The primary objective of the course is to enhance participants' capabilities to analyze and strategize about foreign and national security policy challenges. These challenges will be addressed primarily at the international level in terms of real-world threats and opportunities and strategic options for the U.S. government as if it were a unitary, rational chess master. In addition, however, the course will examine challenges of strategic analysis at two further levels: (1) inside the government's policymaking process; and (2)within a larger democratic political system that requires communication to major constituencies to sustain public support. The course combines concepts and theories with operational assignments. While the seminar will cover a number of current central challenges of American foreign policy, these will be used primarily as examples for the purpose of developing analysis and strategies. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as IGA-201. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of central issues of American foreign policy today. For each issue, analysis of the international environment, identification of specific policy options, consideration of pros and cons, reflection on processes for choice and action. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as ISP-202. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: Central Issues of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar is designed for advanced students with a serious professional interest in international security. It presumes prior coursework and/or experience in foreign and national security policymaking. The primary objective of the course is to enhance participants' capabilities to analyze and strategize about foreign and national security policy challenges. These challenges will be addressed primarily at the international level in terms of real-world threats and opportunities and strategic options for the U.S. government as if it were a unitary, rational chess master. In addition, however, the course will examine challenges of strategic analysis at two further levels: (1) inside the government's policymaking process; and (2)within a larger democratic political system that requires communication to major constituencies to sustain public support. The course combines concepts and theories with operational assignments. While the seminar will cover a number of current central challenges of American foreign policy, these will be used primarily as examples for the purpose of developing analysis and strategies. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as IGA-201. Meets at the Kennedy School.

title: American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes through lectures and cases specific foreign policy issues the United States currently faces. Special emphasis placed on management of the relationship between the United States and Russia, and on nuclear proliferation. Offered jointly with, and meets at, the Kennedy School of Government as IPI-202.

title: American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the domestic setting, international structure, and institutional constraints that determine major foreign policy choices. Places special emphasis on management of the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union. Offered jointly with the Kennedy School of Government as S-247.

title: Comparative Foreign and Security Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focus is on the theory, methods, and data used in the empirical analysis of the foreign security policies of states. Examines the sources of state preferences, the structural and domestic constraints on state action, and foreign policy change. Prior training in international relations theory strongly recommended.

title: Comparative Foreign and Security Policies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Theories, methods, and data useful for studying the foreign policy behavior of states, with focus on how to apply theories and analytic tools to particular states and regions. title: International Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar reviews major theoretical approaches in security studies and examines important substantive issues in the field. It covers the traditional theoretical literature in security studies-such as that on arms races, the security dilemma and the offense-defense balance, civil-military relations, deterrence, and the balance of power-as well as political economic and (advanced) game-theoretic approaches. The course also grounds theoretical discussions with analysis of important empirical issues-particularly the two world wars and the Cold War-to give students an understanding of some of the most prominent historical issues in the political science literature and of the historiography of the 20th-century great-power system. The seminar is centered around four themes in particular: linking theory and history; the links between domestic and international politics; the relationship between economic and security factors; and the use of a strategic logic and/or game theory.

title: Field Experiments for Policy and Program Evaluation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The aim of the course is to provide students with training in how to design and implement randomized controlled trials to test causal models and evaluate policies and programs based on those models. We will discuss working with government and non-government partners, ethics, sampling, blocking, statistical power, online platforms, and communicating findings. Examples will be drawn from research on political campaigns, business programs, economic development, public health, education, employment, welfare, taxation, discrimination, and criminal justice.

title: International Security Studies
subject: GOV

title: Advanced Seminar on China's International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive reading and research course in the application of social science theories and methods to the study of Chinese foreign policy. Topics will include structural, economic, normative, domestic, political, and psychological theories, research methods and data sources, and their use in the analysis of China’s bilateral and multilateral international relations. For graduate students only. Ability to read Chinese documents is required. Prior course work in international relations theory and in Chinese foreign policy strongly recommended.

title: Chinese Strategic Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines key texts in traditional and contemporary Chinese strategic thought. The organizing questions concern what the texts have to say about the nature of warfare, about perceptions of the enemy, about the role and efficacy of violence for achieving state security, and the implications of answers to these issues for operational choice.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the interaction between domestic interest and international pressures in Brazil's current foreign policy. Provides an overview of Brazil's main course of action in 20th-century international affairs. Focuses upon current economic and political challenges for Brazil in global and regional affairs. Focuses on Brazil's approach toward specific topics such as environmental and human rights diplomacy, multilateralism, regional integration, and international security.

title: Brazil's Foreign Policy in the Post-Cold War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the interaction between domestic interest and international pressures in Brazil's current foreign policy. Provides an overview of Brazil's main course of action in 20th-century international affairs. Focuses upon current economic and political challenges for Brazil in global and regional affairs. Explores the influence of state and non-state actors in the shaping of the Brazilian national agenda. Focuses on Brazil's approach toward specific topics such as environmental and human rights diplomacy, multilateralism, regional integration, and international security.

title: Brazil's Foreign Policy in the Post-Cold War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the interaction between domestic interest and international pressures in Brazil's current foreign policy. Provides an overview of Brazil's main course of action in 20th-century international affairs. Focuses upon current economic and political challenges for Brazil in global and regional affairs. Explores the influence of state and non-state actors in the shaping of the Brazilian national agenda. Focuses on Brazil's approach toward specific topics such as environmental and human rights diplomacy, multilateralism, regional integration, and international security.

title: The Iranian Revolution and Its Impact on the Middle East: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: First, examines the social, intellectual, and political origins of the Islamic revolution in Iran. Then focuses on Lebanon, Iraq, and Afghanistan, and analyzes the impact of the revolution on these countries, especially on developments in their Shi'ite communities. Emphasis on the interplay between international and transnational relations.

title: Jihad: From Classical Islam to Bin Laden
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes meanings, theories and uses of jihad in the Islamic tradition, and traces its evolution from its origins into political, cultural and historical contexts, from anti-colonial jihad to hams hixbollah and al quaeda. Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3865. Meets at the Divinity School.

title: Jihad: From Classical Islam to Bin Laden
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes meanings, theories and uses of jihad in the Islamic tradition, and traces its evolution from its origins into political, cultural and historical contexts, from anti-colonial jihad to hams hixbollah and al quaeda. Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3865. Meets at the Divinity School.

title: The Prevention and Management of Conflicts in the Middle East: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines conceptual models of conflict prevention and management and explores their applicability to the Middle East. Students analyze the European-East/West and Middle Eastern experiences and attempt to derive policy-relevant conclusions for current and prospective conflicts in the region. Previous courses on Middle Eastern politics, international relations, and/or American foreign policy.

title: American Government: A New Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an overview of contemporary American politics. It analyses the way in which recent changes in elections and media coverage have helped shape key aspects of American government, including the courts, Congress, and the Presidency, the workings of interest groups and political parties, and, also, the making of public policy. Permanent political campaigns have altered governmental institutions and processes. The course explains how and why.

title: American Government: A New Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an overview of contemporary American politics, showing how recent changes in elections and media coverage have helped shape key aspects of American government. From the courts, Congress, and the Presidency, to the workings of interest groups and political parties, and, also to the making of public policy, the pressure on political leaders to run permanent campaigns has altered governmental institutions and processes. The course explains how and why. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for United States in the World. This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engages substantially with Study of the Past.

title: Introduction to American Government
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to American government and politics, emphasizing how citizens and institutions (the Congress, executive, courts, political parties, interest groups, public opinion, and the electorate) interact in the formation of public policies, and how this interaction has changed over time. The political process studied primarily through examination of several historical and contemporary cases, in areas such as civil rights, foreign policy, economic regulation, and electoral behavior.

title: Teaching and Communicating Political Science
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This is a required course for Government PhD students who are teaching in the department for the first time (typically G3s).  The course meeting five times in the fall semester.  Between meetings, you will have the chance to apply what you learn through peer observation, having your section videotaped, and watching your section with the Departmental Teaching Fellow.  The ultimate goal of this course is to help you to become a good teacher and an effective speaker.

title: Teaching and Communicating Political Science

title: Dissertation Workshop in European Studies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A workshop for those planning or writing a doctoral dissertation in political science, history, or economics or sociology related to Europe. If space permits, others in comparative politics will be admitted. Topics include the formation of a prospectus, research design, research methods, and dissertation writing. Open to graduate students in all years.

title: Dissertation Workshop in European Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A workshop for students planning or writing a dissertation in the social sciences related to Europe. Topics include formulating a prospectus, research design, research methods, and dissertation writing. Includes collective discussion of work in progress. Students planning to enroll should contact the instructor during the fall term.

title: Dissertation Workshop in European Politics

title: Research Workshop in Japanese Politics
subject: GOV

title: Research Workshop in Japanese Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A workshop for graduate students planning or writing a dissertation in the social sciences related to Japan. Topics include formulating a prospectus, research design, field methods, and dissertation writing. Students make oral presentations of work in progress.

title: Seminar on Law and Political Science
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This interdisciplinary seminar, offered jointly with the Harvard Law School, will provide students and faculty with an opportunity to engage with scholarship at the intersection of law and political science. Seminar meetings will feature invited speakers presenting their current research. The seminar is intended primarily for students interested in pursuing academic careers, particularly those enrolled in or considering a joint JD-PhD program. Offered jointly with the Law School as 2553.

title: Research Workshop in Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The workshop offers advanced graduate students an opportunity to present their work-in-progress, benefit from critiques of it, and discuss theoretical and methodological issues. Doctoral students from other departments and faculties admitted if space permits.

title: Research Workshop in Comparative Politics: The Performance of Democracies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This dissertation workshop will assess the performance of democracies and of other ^'^'open polities'' in various parts of the world, including in the United States. Faculty will present their ongoing research. Other Government Department faculty, faculty from other Harvard departments and schools, and faculty from outside the university will also make presentations from time to time. Depending on their stage toward the Ph.D., graduate students will be expected to present their ideas toward the dissertation, or a draft prospectus, or a dissertation chapter in progress. There will also be some common readings.

title: Research Workshop in Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This workshop deals with key topics, issues, and concepts in comparative politics. Participants present their own work, including drafts of thesis proposals, thesis chapters, articles, and conference papers, for detailed discussion and comments. Students at all stages of the research process, from preliminary prospectus drafting to thesis completion, are welcome.

title: Safra Graduate Fellowship Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines how moral and political theories should be brought to bear on institutional and policymaking choices. Special attention will be given to the relation between ideal and nonideal theory. This full year course is not repeatable.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is an introduction to the analysis of the causes and character of international conflict and cooperation. Theories of international relations are presented and then applied to historical cases to test those theories of international politics and to expand our understanding of the range of possible forms of international behavior.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is an introduction to the analysis of the causes and character of international conflict and cooperation. Theories of international relations are presented and then applied to historical cases to test those theories of international politics and to expand our understanding of the range of possible forms of international behavior.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is an introduction to the analysis of the causes and character of international conflict and cooperation. The course begins with a foundational review of the different levels at which states interact and the primary theoretical paradigms in the field. It then addresses how states achieve cooperation in the face of international anarchy. The course next addresses basic bargaining theory, which uses insights from economics to explore how bargaining breakdowns, commitment problems, and incomplete information can lead to war. Thereafter we examine three popular topics in contemporary international relations research: the roles that psychology, leaders, and domestic politics play in explaining international conflict and cooperation. We will also look at international organizations/law, terrorism, trade, foreign aid, international development, and climate change.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is an introduction to the analysis of the causes and character of international conflict and cooperation. The course begins with a foundational review of the different levels at which states interact and the primary theoretical paradigms in the field. It then addresses how states achieve cooperation in the face of international anarchy. The course next addresses basic bargaining theory, which uses insights from economics to explore how bargaining breakdowns, commitment problems, and incomplete information can lead to war. Thereafter we examine three popular topics in contemporary international relations research: the roles that psychology, leaders, and domestic politics play in explaining international conflict and cooperation. We will also look at international organizations/law, terrorism, trade, foreign aid, international development, and climate change.

title: International Conflict and Cooperation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why do states wage war? Why do they cooperate? Have the answers changed historically? Are economic globalization, ecological interdependence, and global civil society eroding traditional state sovereignty? Or do nationalism, protectionism, and power politics firmly limit the spread of world order? The course begins with the Peloponnesian War, the European state system, imperialism, the spread of free trade, and the two World Wars. It continues after 1945 with the spread of democracy and human rights, trade liberalization, international law, and ecological cooperation, as well as enduring sources of conflicts like the Cold War, nuclear weapons, civil strife, and rogue states. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Societies of the World or the Core area requirement for Historical Study A. This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engages substantially with Study of the Past.

title: Introduction to Political Science Research Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class will introduce students to techniques used for research in the study of politics. Students will learn to think systematically about research design and causality, how data and theory fit together, and how to measure the quantities we care about. Students will learn a `toolbox' of methods---including statistical software---that enable them to execute their research plans. This class is highly recommended for those planning to write a senior thesis.

Students will learn to think systematically about research design and causality, how data and theory fit together, and how to measure the quantities we care about. Students will learn a `toolbox' of methods---including statistical software---that enable them to execute their research plans. This class is highly recommended for those planning to write a senior thesis.

title: Introduction to Political Science Research Methods

title: Introduction to Political Science Research Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Can exit polls detect election fraud? What are the determinants of political corruption? Is Islam incompatible with open government? In what sense (if any) does democracy reduce the probability of war? This course introduces basic statistical techniques used in quantitative political methodology to give scientifically rigorous answers to these questions and many others. Topics covered include descriptive statistics, sampling, estimation, hypothesis tests, and applied linear and logistic regression. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the Core requirement for Quantitative Reasoning. This course, when taken for a letter grade, meets the General Education requirement for Empirical and Mathematical Reasoning.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis for Political Scientists
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to probability and statistics designed primarily for undergraduates in government and related social sciences with little or no previous statistical training. Descriptive and inferential statistics and explanatory interpretations of experimental and observational studies. Practical experience in the several steps required to carry out quantitative research for projects such as senior theses, including finding archived data, using computer statistical analysis programs, and applying data analysis strategies and probability and statistical theory.

title: Research Practice in Quantitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class introduces students to a variety of statistical methods used to investigate political phenomena. We will address the principles behind these methods, their application, and their limitations. The course will be useful to those undertaking a quantitative methods thesis in Government, but not solely. Indeed, the course aims to provide anyone interested in political science with a proficient understanding of the intuitions behind several of the methods used to analyze political data and identify causal paths. By the end of the course, students will have acquired important analytical and practical skills and will be able to evaluate the quality and reliability of scholarly and journalistic work done using quantitative methods. Students will learn statistical software skills (STATA). For the course’s final assignment, students will be given the choice between writing a research paper using data and writing a different kind of project more suitable to those who are not interested in writing a quantitative research paper.

title: Research Practice in Quantitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course focuses on the application of quantitative methods to the study of political phenomena. It is appropriate for students interested in quantitative approaches to political research, and is especially relevant for students who wish to conduct quantitative research for senior theses. We will discuss the formulation of research questions, fundamental principles of research design, and the practical application of quantitative methods for questions in all fields of political science. The course will culminate with students preparing an original research prospectus that applies the methods and tools discussed in the course and provides the foundation for senior thesis research.

title: Research Practice in Quantitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Class introduces students to statistical methods and practice commonly used in political science and likely to be of utility to those undertaking a quantitative methods thesis in Government. Topics will include techniques for dealing with binary or ordinal dependent variables, time series and 'survival' models, along with applications of more complicated approaches. Students will learn new statistical software skills, and be expected to both gather and work on their own data throughout the semester.

title: Research Practice in Quantitative Methods

title: Research Practice in Qualitative Methods
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: With the goal of preparing students to undertake original research, this course introduces students to basic principles and tools of qualitative research in the social sciences. Focus is on comparative research design and the principal tools of qualitative research. Topics examined include the pitfalls of selection bias, the logic of causal inference, measurement and conceptualization, and the potential of mixed methods. Research techniques covered are process tracing, analytic narratives, natural experiments, archival research, interviews, and ethnography.

title: Topics and Resources in Political Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to the most important debates in contemporary English-language political theory, centered on questions of justice, equality and rights. We then turn to topics that reflect the individual interests of students who enroll. The course is designed to help participants to make the transition from being critical readers of political thought to being independent contributors to debate. It will be especially useful for those considering writing a thesis in political theory.

title: Topics and Resources in Political Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to some of the methodological approaches in contemporary political theory-philosophical and historical-by looking at analyses of the "just war." We then turn to other topics reflecting the individual interests of students who enroll. Designed to help participants to make the transition from being critical readers of political thought to being independent contributors to debate, the course will be especially useful for those considering writing a political theory thesis.

title: Topics and Resources in Political Theory

title: Topics and Resources in Political Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course introduces students to philosophical and historical approaches used by contemporary political theorists. In particular, we will examine theories of political dissent, from disobedience to revolution. We then turn to other topics reflecting the interests of those who enroll. Designed to help participants make the transition from being critical readers of political thought to being independent contributors to debate, the course will be especially useful for those considering writing a thesis in political theory

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of some central themes of recent work in English-language political philosophy, including Rawls and his critics, egalitarianism, and the nature of rights. Other topics will reflect the individual interests of students who enroll. This course is designed to help participants to make the transition from being critical readers of political thought to being independent contributors to debate.

title: Contemporary British Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on changes in economy, society, and politics in the transition from empire to small country. Topics include the evolving party system, electoral behavior, and a range of policy questions involving economic management, the welfare state, the European Community, race relations, and Northern Ireland.

title: Freedom of Association
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on freedom of association and its limits, with readings drawn from the history of political thought, contemporary theory, and law. What are the reasons for outlawing groups or regulating their practices? What are the reasons for providing groups with public support? We will discuss freedom of association for religious groups, political parties, and a range of ``voluntary associations'' (the Boy Scouts, the Jaycees) and ``identity groups.''

title: Freedom of Association
subject: GOV

We will discuss freedom of association for religious groups, political parties, and a range of ``voluntary associations'' (the Boy Scouts, the Jaycees) and ``identity groups.''

title: Politics of Latin American Economic Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Interaction of politics and economics in Latin America.

title: Politics of Latin American Economic Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Interaction of politics and economics in Latin America.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Uses readings focused on three cities_Los Angeles, New York, and Miami_to look at ongoing changes in urban politics. A major theme of the course will be how cities have dealt with rapid demographic change_white (and sometimes black) flight, the influx of immigration, and the rise of the multi-racial city. How do different urban institutions deal with these structural changes? How are new actors incorporated into existing (or new) political institutions? What are the preconditions for conflict and cooperation among different ethnic groups?

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Uses readings focused on three cities-Los Angeles, New York and Miami-to look at ongoing changes in urban politics. How do different urban institutions deal with these structural changes? How are new actors incorporated into existing (or new) political institutions? What are the preconditions for conflict and cooperation among different ethnic groups.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a substantive theoretical introduction to the area of urban politics, dealing with regime theory, pluralism, elite theory, rational choice, class, historical approaches, while also looking at some or all of these topics: federalism, urban coalitions - the mobilization of marginal political actors, the political economy of cities, and the phenomenon of edge cities.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
