How do different urban institutions deal with these structural changes? How are new actors incorporated into existing (or new) political institutions? What are the preconditions for conflict and cooperation among different ethnic groups?

title: The Politics of Social Policy in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines social policy in the United States and considers competing approaches to developing policy for the 21st century. Compares different perspectives on the nature and purposes of American social policy and explores how American institutions and political culture have shaped the development of social policy throughout the 20th century. Case studies will include welfare, health care, work-family policy, and social security.

title: The Politics of Social Policy in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines social policy in the United States and considers competing approaches to developing policy for the 21st century. Compares different perspectives on the nature and purposes of American social policy and explores how American institutions and political culture have shaped the development of social policy throughout the 20th century. Case studies will include welfare, health care, work-family policy, and social security.

title: The Politics of Social Policy in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines social policy in the United States and considers competing approaches to developing policy for the 21st century. Compares different perspectives on the nature and purposes of American social policy and explores how American institutions and political culture have shaped the development of social policy throughout the 20th century. Case studies will include welfare, health care, work-family policy, and social security.

title: The Politics of Social Policy in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the past, present, and possible futures of social policies in the United States. Members will consider how cross-national theories can be applied or modified to explain U.S. patterns; and they will analyze contemporary debates about welfare, health insurance, employment programs, and social security. Drawing on their own values and informed understandings of U.S. politics, students propose and explain possible reforms for the future.

title: The Politics of American Social Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The first half of this course focuses on the development of the American welfare state over the course of the 20th century. The second half centers on explaining recent trends in social policy, and will include more detailed examination of such events as the failed Clinton health care reform initiative, the devolution of control over important elements of anti-poverty policy, and the continuing discussion of major changes in social entitlement programs.

title: The Politics of Social Policy in the United States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines social policy in the United States and considers competing approaches to developing policy for the 21st century. Compares different perspectives on the nature and purposes of American social policy and explores how American institutions and political culture have shaped the development of social policy throughout the 20th century. Case studies will include welfare, health care, work-family policy, and social security.

title: Genocide
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores comparatively the phenomenon of genocide. Instances of mass killing discussed include that of the Armenians, the Holocaust, Cambodia, Rwanda, and Bosnia.

title: Genocide
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores comparatively the phenomenon of genocide by addressing three sets of questions. The first is conceptual: What is genocide? How is it related to other facets of politics and other forms of violence? The second pertains to the causes of genocide: How can its occurrence be explained? Why do people slaughter another group of people? The third focuses on the consequences of genocidal assaults: Why do different genocides produce different outcomes and have different features? What happens socially and politically after the killing has stopped?

title: Genocide
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores comparatively the phenomenon of genocide. Instances of mass killing discussed include that of the Armenians, the Holocaust, Cambodia, Rwanda, and Bosnia.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The modern era has seen an number of nation-states rise to ^'^'imperial'' dominance in world politics. What form can empires take? How do great powers establish and maintain spheres of influence? Why do some great powers flourish while others meet an early demise? Under what conditions do great powers resort to war to expand or maintain their empires? Draws together recent political science and historical literature to investigate the origins and exercise of imperial power. Case studies include Great Britain, Nazi Germany, Imperial Japan, the United States and Soviet Union.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers

courseDescriptionLong: The modern era has seen a number of nation-states rise to ^'^'imperial'' dominance in world politics. What form can empires take? How do great powers establish and maintain spheres of influence? Why do some great powers flourish while others meet an early demise? Under what conditions do great powers resort to war to expand or maintain their empires? The course draws together recent political science and historical literature to investigate the origins and exercise of imperial power. Case studies include Great Britain, Nazi Germany, Imperial Japan, the United States and Soviet Union.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The modern era has seen a number of nation-states rise to ^'^'imperial'' dominance in world politics. What form can empires take? How do great powers establish and maintain spheres of influence? Why do some great powers flourish while others meet an early demise? Under what conditions do great powers resort to war to expand or maintain their empires? The course draws together recent political science and historical literature to investigate the origins and exercise of imperial power. Case studies include Great Britain, Nazi Germany, Imperial Japan, the United States and Soviet Union.

title: Public Opinion and Political Culture
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The success of democratic government requires citizens with sound political preferences. Volumes of criticism and more than fifty years of polling in the United States suggest, however, that public opinion on many political issues is shallow and volatile, and perhaps easily manipulated by politicians, pundits, and peddlers. Reading, writing, and discussion in this seminar will examine the foundations of American public opinion in an effort to distinguish sustained strains of political culture from fleeting fashions in political discourse and media commentary. Evidence will be drawn primarily from patterns of continuity and change in the political preferences of ordinary Americans, as revealed by surveys conducted since World War II.

title: The Japanese Political Economy in Transition
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the constraints and possibilities for change in the Japanese political economy. To what extent have political upheaval, economic recession and the internationalization of markets transformed the Japanese model? Explores this question by looking at changes in party politics, government regulation, and corporate organization, using case studies of recent reforms.

title: Urban Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Over eighty percent of Americans live in the nation's 300 largest metropolitan regions. Within these regions, thousands of cities compete for residents and revenue through the use of taxes, zoning codes and development practices. This seminar will look broadly at the politics of local governance and the issues of concern to local communities. Topics will include municipal secession and competition, fiscal inequality, land use, and the segregation of residents by income, class, and race.

title: Urban Politics

title: Political Theory and Multiculturalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the way Greek, Roman, Christian, Liberal, Marxist, and Communitarian traditions deal with cultural differences. It also explores issues raised by contemporary multicultural societies, such as intercultural equality and fairness, national identity, citizenship, and cross-cultural political discourse.

title: Global Distributive Justice and Political Borders: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines the problem of global distributive justice in contemporary political theory. Should we conceive of justice in global (universal) terms? Do political borders have moral significance, should states (or other entities) have a right to control their borders? We discuss national self-determination, immigration, international institutions, the moral/legal status of non-state actors. Syllabus includes Rawls, O'Neill, Scheffler, Pogge, Nagel, Beitz, Blake, Risse, Singer, Wenar, Cohen and Carens.

title: The Transformation of Congressional Careers
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the rise of the modern congressional career, first exploring the roots of careerism, from realigning elections to electoral reform. Investigates the effects of careerism on the organization of the House and Senate and the policy implications of such reorganization.

title: The International Relations of the Post-Soviet States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course begins with a survey of major themes and developments in Soviet foreign policy as a way to understand the importance of history and assess continuity and change in post-Soviet international relations. The course focuses on the sources of change which brought about the demise of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, and on the foreign policies and security relations of the Soviet successor states. We will focus on relations among those states as well as their policies toward the rest of the world, the rise of Russian nationalism, prospects for international economic integration, nuclear weapons proliferation, and regional security concerns.

title: The International Relations of the Post-Soviet States
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course begins with a survey of major themes and developments in Soviet foreign policy as a way to understand the importance of history and assess continuity and change in post-Soviet international relations. The course focuses on the sources of change which brought about the demise of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, and on the foreign policies and security relations of the Soviet successor states. We will focus on relations among those states as well as their policies toward the rest of the world, the rise of Russian nationalism, prospects for international economic integration, nuclear weapons proliferation, and regional security concerns.

title: The International Relations of Post-Soviet Russia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The transformation of Russia from a centrally planned economy directed by a regime committed to the transformation of the international system into a presidential democracy reigning over a free market is still incomplete. What effects have these dramatic changes had on Russia's foreign policy? Has Putin dropped the legacy of the Soviet past? Has Moscow found a new identity? More generally, we will focus on the tensions arising from adaptation to democratic capitalism but resistance to imitation of the West. We will investigate the inter-relationship between economic transformation and foreign policy, as well as reach back into the pan-slavic past to the writings of those like Danilevskii who rejected the west as a model, in order to trace Russia's trajectory into the future.

title: North-South Trade Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In the industrialized world, trade policies toward manufactured and agricultural products have moved in opposite directions since early in this century: barriers on industrial goods have fallen by three-quarters while farm protection has climbed ten-fold. In the developing world, in contrast, trade and exchange restrictions protect manufacturers while creating enormous disincentives for farmers. Students will attempt to unravel these paradoxes.

title: Industrial and Agricultural Trade Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since the 1920s, barriers on manufactured goods have fallen by three-quarters while farm protection has climbed tenfold. Agriculture is now the most distorted part of the world economy. Why this dramatic difference between industrial and agricultural trade policies?

title: Power and Popular Protest in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys theoretical debates and explores patterns of popular resistance and protest in various social and political conditions. Emphasis on multidimensional nature of protest and its historical, social, political, and economic context. Special focus on the impact of regime type on forms and frequency of protest. Case material from Europe, Latin America, and Asia.

title: Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines modern theories of political economy and their applications to macro problems in advanced democracies. Why do some governments and countries generate better economic performance than others? Why are some economies more egalitarian than others? How do politicians manipulate the economy for partisan gain, and how are politicians constrained by institutions and the global economy? We seek to answer these questions using the most promising theories in political science and economics.

title: Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines modern theories of political economy and their applications to macro problems in advanced industrialized democracies. Why do some governments and countries generate better economic performance than others? Why are some economies more egalitarian than others? How do politicians manipulate the economy for partisan gain, and how are politicians constrained by institutions and the global economy? These are some of the questions that we will seek to answer using the most promising theories in political science and economics.

title: Political Economy of Western Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines modern theories of political economy and their applications to macro problems in advanced industrialized democracies. Focuses on the interplay between public policies, domestic institutions, and (increasingly internationalized) markets, and consequences of this interplay for macro-level outcomes. Topics include electoral business cycles, systems of wage determination, role of central banks, and effects of partisan politics on macroeconomic outcomes.

title: Presidential Transitions and the First Hundred Days
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Comparative analysis of the coming to power of new presidents from FDR to Clinton; differences in context and political time; strategies for dealing with Congress during "honeymoon" period of the first year in office.

title: Topics in Behavioral Decision-Making
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: While economic models in the rational choice tradition have long been applied to political science, behavioral models are increasingly being used to understand political behavior. Such models use psychological regularities to answer questions that have long perplexed rational choice theorists, like "Why vote in a large election when the probability of being pivotal is essentially zero?" This course provides an overview of behavioral economics and how it can be applied to politics. Economics 10.

title: Topics in Behavioral Decision-Making
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: While economic models in the rational choice tradition have long been applied to political science, behavioral models are increasingly being used to understand political behavior. Such models use psychological regularities to answer questions that have long perplexed rational choice theorists, like "Why vote in a large election when the probability of being pivotal is essentially zero?" This course provides an overview of behavioral economics and how it can be applied to politics. Economics 10.

title: Contemporary European Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course traces key issues in contemporary Europe focusing on the impact of the May 2004 expansion of the EU on the new members of the EU. How has EU expansion affected the newly admitted states? What lessons can be learned from earlier cases of EU expansion about the prospects for economic growth and political stabilization? What are and will be the political reactions to the ongoing processes of transformation?

title: Contemporary European Politics
subject: GOV

title: Contemporary Politics of Western Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the pattern of domestic politics and political change in Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, and the Scandinavian countries in the 1970s and 1980s. Topics include realignment and dealignment within the European party systems, the rise of new social movements, comparative responses to a changing world economy, and the accelerating process of European reunification.

title: Contemporary Politics of Western Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the pattern of domestic politics and political economy in the principal Western European states, from the economic crises of the 1970s through the present. Topics include: neocorporatism and neoliberalism, the rise of new right- and left-wing parties and social movements, ^'^'Eurosclerosis'' and the crisis of the European welfare state, and the likely impact on Western Europe of 1992, German reunification, and the collapse of the Soviet block.

title: Crucial Events in Chinese Elite Poltics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A critical reexamination of major events in the politics of the People's Republic and of the hitherto accepted Western analyses of them, using the new data made available in the PRC in recent years. The objective is to outline new hypotheses where necessary and more importantly, to explore what need there might be for new ways of studying Chinese politics.

title: Politics, Power, and Modernity: Readings of Machiavelli and Arendt
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the consequences for politics of the changing terms of modernity, primarily through readings of Machiavelli and Arendt. Texts include: Machiavelli's Prince and The Discourses, Arendt's The Human Condition, Between Past and Future, and On Revolution.

title: Politics of Migration and Identity in Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: As European governments are forced to acknowledge the permanent place of resident foreigners and others of non-European origin, what particular challenges do elected officials, native populations, and ``non-European'' populations face? Why do we observe cross-national differences when it comes to the inclusion or incorporation of new populations? Have these differences become less pronounced as a result of the integration process?

title: Politics of Migration and Identity in Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: As European governments are forced to acknowledge the permanent place of resident foreigners and others of non-European origin, what particular challenges do elected officials, native populations, and ``non-European'' populations face? Why do we observe cross-national differences when it comes to the inclusion or incorporation of new populations? Have these differences become less pronounced as a result of the integration process?

title: President and Congress: Choices in Domestic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A look at the modern presidency and the contemporary Congress, examining how they function together to address issues of domestic policy. Evaluates sources of conflict and cooperation between the two branches, constraints on executive-legislative decision making, and suggestions for institutional reform.

title: President and Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A look at the modern presidency and the contemporary Congress, examining how they function together to address issues of domestic policy. Evaluates sources of conflict and cooperation between the two branches, constraints on executive-legislative decision making, and suggestions for institutional reform.

title: The Political Significance of Legal Ambiguity
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the uncertainties and inconsistencies in judicial reasoning, with special attention to the political purposes that such ambiguities serve. Readings include works by legal realists and selected areas of constitutional adjudication.

title: The Political Significance of Legal Ambiguity
subject: GOV

title: Courts and Social Change
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Many commentators argue that courts, particularly the Supreme Court, have brought about non-trivial social change. This course looks at the processes by which such changes might occur and examines the empirical support for claims of court-driven social change.

title: Courts and Social Change
subject: GOV

title: Women and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides students with an understanding of the role and impact of women in American politics and society. Specifically, this course examines the history of women as activists in political movements and electoral politics, explores the challenges and opportunities women face as political candidates and public officials, and investigates how women influence public policy and the policy agenda, as well as how public policies affect women.

title: Cross-Cultural Perspectives on MainConcepts of Russian Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class deals with cross-cultural comparisons of main concepts in Russian and Anglo-American politics. It employs methods of conceptual history in order to evaluate the specificity of the Russian context of use of such familiar concepts as state, nation, the individual etc.

title: Democratization: Possibilities and Limits
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Is democratic government always better than the alternatives? What makes it possible? Can it work outside ^'^'the West''? In the contemporary world, what is the relationship between economic development, democratic politics, and political order? What kinds of justice does democracy promote? We will discuss these questions by examining political patterns and policy dilemmas in India, South Africa, and China.

title: Parties and Elections
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Broadly examines whether and how political parties and elections induce governments to be accountable to their citizens, with an emphasis on developing areas.

title: Comparative Justice: Constitutional Courts in the Modern World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: More than ever, constitutional courts are mediating and deciding questions of justice in modern democracies. Analyzing a variety of countries, including the US, Germany, and Bosnia-Herzegovina, this seminar places the trend toward judicial review in historical and comparative perspective. It asks: Should judicial review be the main mechanism for balancing individual rights, group rights, and the collective will? How do constitutional courts shape multicultural societies? Do activist constitutional courts hinder, or help, the democratic process?

title: Politics of Immigration and Citizenship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a seminar on the politics of immigration and citizenship, with an emphasis on the U.S. and Europe. It is designed to explore conceptual and methodological issues, while focusing on how immigrants influence and are shaped by the political systems of the "receiving" countries. Among the topics to be covered include the history of different immigration and naturalization policies, the rights and duties of citizenship, and the racism and xenophobia associated with immigration.

title: Politics of Immigration and Citizenship

It is designed to explore conceptual and methodological issues, while focusing on how immigrants influence and are shaped by the political systems of the "receiving" countries. title: Democratic Theory and Practice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores a related set of questions about democratic government: what are our ideals, what is possible, and what do we have now? The first section of the course considers democratic and republican conceptions of what it means for "the people" to collectively govern. The second section of the course will consider fundamental constraints imposed by the mechanics of collective decision-making. The third section of the course turns to the reality of democratic self-government: how much control do citizens have in practice?

title: Shakespeare's Rome
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Shakespeare's contribution to the political and philosophical understanding of ancient Rome, focusing on the problem of regime change (republic vs. empire). Readings include Coriolanus, Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, Titus Andronicus, and Cymbeline, with background material in Polybius, Machiavelli, Montesquieu, and others.

title: Political Violence
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines one of the central features of politics, the role of violence in maintaining order and producing change. What philosophical justifications have been offered to legitimize the use of violence, either by a political regime or against it? What types and patterns of violence have characterized different kinds of societies, historically and in the contemporary world? What conditions lead to different kinds of political violence? How effective is the use of violence in achieving a variety of political goals?

title: Legal Identities
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar is concerned with the various ways in which identities are constructed and shaped by law. Drawing on court cases from Germany, France, the UK, Turkey, the US, the European Court of Justice, and the European Court of Human Rights, this course compares the evolving impact of law on the ethnic, religious, and cultural identities of citizens in the contemporary world.

title: Legal Identities
subject: GOV

Drawing on court cases from Germany, France, the UK, Turkey, the US, the European Court of Justice, and the European Court of Human Rights, this course compares the evolving impact of law on the ethnic, religious, and cultural identities of citizens in the contemporary world.

title: Transitions to Democracy in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Through examination of theoretical works and case studies from Latin American, Southern European, and East European transitions, explores complex patterns of regime changes, their social, political, and economic causes and consequences, conditions conducive to the establishment of functioning democratic institutions, and typical dilemmas faced by collective actors during transitions.

title: Transitions to Democracy in Comparative Perspective

title: Public, Private, and the Liberal State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar probes the liberal distinction between public and private as it plays itself out in political thought, constitutional law and public policy in Canada, the US and other selected liberal democratic states.

title: Public, Private, and the Liberal State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar probes the liberal distinction between public and private as it plays itself out in political thought, constitutional law and public policy in Canada, the US and other selected liberal democratic states.

title: The Causes and Preventions of War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In this seminar, the class will discuss a wide variety of explanations for the onset of war. We begin by looking at theories of war at a variety of levels of analysis, including international structural theories, institutional theories and the role of regimes, dyadic theories such as deterrence, domestic political, and economic theories of war, and finally individual level theories such as those based on cognitive or motivated perceptions. The class will then apply these theoretical approaches to understanding the occurrence of several historical cases of wars and ^'^'near-wars'' including WWI, WWII, Korea and the Cuban Missile Crisis.

title: Markets and Morals

courseDescriptionLong: The seminar will examine controversial cases of commodification, and ask whether there are some things money cannot or should not buy. Topics to include organ sales, surrogacy, college financial aid, pollution permits, for-profit prisons, mercenary armies, and others. Some previous course work in political theory is recommended but not required.

title: Political Economy of Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the political bases of the developmental and distributive strategies pursued by several Latin American countries in the postwar period, especially import-substituting industrialization, and the relationship between economic crises in the region and political change. Examines the changing nature and degree of state intervention in the economy, foreign investment, and trade and exchange policies. What do his plays show about the grounds of authority, justifications for rule, the relation between law and discretion, the goals and manner of statesmanship, the relation between the sexes, authority within families, monarchy and freedom, the cause of tragedy, and its relation to more liberal political settings?

title: Immigration and Citizenship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: We begin the course by asking why people move. Next, we will consider the origins and implications of policies that admit some people into the United States while barring others. We will survey competing theories of immigrant incorporation -- with attention to the growing gap between immigrants' numbers and power -- and confront present-day debates about citizenship and belonging. Students will become familiar with the basic empirical tools needed for futher research in the field.

title: Elections and Democracy in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar focuses on the nature and quality of election management and party competition in the Americas: administration of elections, voting procedures, conflict management, campaign finance, access to the media and international democracy assistance. While its main focus is on the Latin American experience, it will also frequently discuss the United States and cases from Africa, Europe and Southeast Asia. Special attention will be given to the case of Mexico.

title: Human Rights in World Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the history, politics, and law of international human rights protection. The seminar analyzes the emergence, expansion, and enforcement of international norms concerning national guarantees of human rights.

title: Human Rights in World Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the history, politics, and law of international human rights protection. The seminar analyzes the emergence, expansion, and enforcement of international norms concerning national guarantees of human rights.

title: Human Rights
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzing the theory and history of human rights, this seminar provides an introduction to salient themes in foreign, comparative, and international law. Several themes are addressed: the contested meanings and conflicting imperatives of human rights, the tension between universality and cultural specificity in the application of human rights, the adjudication of human rights in courts and tribunals, the promotion of human rights by activists beyond borders, and the limits of human rights for achieving justice.

title: Human Rights in World Politics

title: Human Rights: Political and Philosophical Perspectives
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines some of the philosophical and political issues raised by human rights. The philosophical questions discussed include: do human rights need a philosophical justification? Are human rights ``ethnocentric''? Can philosophical arguments help us identify a list of human rights? Political questions include: what is the status of human rights with respect to constitutional and legal rights? What role should human rights play in an ethical foreign policy? Is the modern nation state a guarantor or a predator of human rights?

title: Reason, Passions, and Political Agency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What motivates principled civil disobedience, or heroic action on the battlefield, or tireless advocacy on behalf of the oppressed, or simple voting? What role does reason play in motivating political action and what do the passions contribute? Is self-interest the most forceful motive in politics or can altruism be a viable basis of political action, and are there other sources of political agency beyond self-interest and altruism? This course explores the moral psychology that stands behind individual agency in the political sphere and the sociological conditions that both constrain and enable it. Readings include Aristotle, Kant, Arendt, Rawls, Habermas, Charles Taylor, Jane Mansbridge, Judith Butler, Amelie Oksenberg Rorty, Dennis Chong, Cornell West, and Bernard Williams.

title: Nuclear Learning
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Some scholars point to the nonuse of nuclear weapons, progressively more restrictive arms control agreements, and certain deliberate decisions to reverse or eschew ^'destabilizing' technologies and nuclear doctrines as evidence of U.S. and Soviet learning in nuclear policy. Should we expect other present or future nuclear weapons states to experience similar nuclear learning? This course examines nuclear policy and arms control from the perspective of learning theory. What constitutes learning? How do we know it when we see it? Are there cross-national differences in nuclear learning? Focuses on evidence for or against learning in the nuclear policies of a number of nuclear weapon and near nuclear weapons states.

title: Constitutionalism in the European Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: We are witnessing a critical historical moment: members of European states are drafting a constitution for what may become ``The United States of Europe.'' But is a formal, written constitution necessary for, or even beneficial to, the European Union and its member states? If so, can Europe's experiment with large scale constitution-making provide important lessons for other regions of the world, such as the Middle East?

title: French Political Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the ideas concerning the proper organization of state and society offered by French thinkers from the 17th century to the present.

title: European Integration
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the history and politics of the European Community: What political and social forces underlie the process of European integration? What accounts for its successes and failures at specific times and in specific issue areas? How does the European experience compare with that of North America, East Asia, and the Third World?

title: The Politics of European Integration
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the history of the European Union, its institutions, key policies and concepts, and deals with major theoretical approaches to analyzing the process of integration. Topics include evolving patterns of political integration in the post Maastricht era, European identity, citizenship, and government. Emphasis is placed on the changing meaning of Europe after the collapse of communism and the interplay between economic and political integration.

title: The European Community
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the history and politics of the European Community: What political, social, and ideological forces underlie the process of European integration? What accounts for its successes and failures at specific times and in specific issues? What are the prospects for the European Monetary System, a European foreign policy, a single European market, and common social policies?

title: The European Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the history and theory of politics within the European Union: What political, social, and ideological forces have propelled the process of European integration forward toward a single European market, currency, foreign policy, regulatory policies, citizenship? What accounts for the specific successes and failures of integration at particular times and in specific matters? How can we explain political bargaining within EU institutions? What is the future of this multinational experiment?

title: Modern Political Thought: The Contract Tradition
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the device of the social contract in the political theories of Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Rousseau, Kant, Burke, and T. H. Green.

title: Politics and the Macroeconomy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores several topics of current interest in the area of political economics. Emphasis on the relationship between politics and macroeconomics from a domestic and international perspective. Topics include: political business cycles; the political economy of the government budget; international macroeconomic policy coordination; the politics of less- developed countries' debt.

title: Politics of International Trade and Finance
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Covers specialized topics in international trade and finance: trade wars, currency crises, international organizations, and exchange-rate regimes.

title: The Political Economy of Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examining the origins of law and courts, and their effects on politics and society, this seminar introduces students to the political economy of law. It explores strategic choice and collective action in the formation, deformation, and transformation of legal norms and institutions, with particular reference to nineteenth and twentieth century Africa. By analyzing the logic of law and the forces that shape it, the seminar debates law's promise_its real and imagined place in society.

title: Democracy, Alienation, and Muslims in the West
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar develops an in-depth understanding of modern democratic citizenship and political identity, examining Western Muslim communities as an evocative case study. We first consider the shifting foundations of democratic participation and political alienation in a globalizing world. We then illustrate new developments by exploring the experiences of Muslim communities' in Western democratic polities. Finally, these concepts and observations are applied to understand three contemporary socio-political phenomena - global Islam, transnational Muslim politics, and terrorist networks.

title: The Politics of Race and Ethnicity in the U.S.

courseDescriptionLong: Examines the ways in which ethnicity and race were organized into American politics in the 19th century and compares the patterns of incorporation of new immigrant groups in the 1960s-1980s. Problems of group organization and channels of political influence are examined for each period.

title: Education Politics and Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of political forces shaping elementary and secondary education governance and policy. Major contemporary issues to be discussed. Students expected to write term papers.

title: Education Politics and Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of political forces shaping elementary and secondary education governance and policy. Major contemporary issues discussed. Students expected to write term papers.

title: Media and Politics in the 1990s
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Looks at recent changes in media technologies and practices, and their effects on American politics.

title: Media and Politics in the 1990s
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Looks at recent changes in media technologies and practices, and their effects on American politics.

title: Media and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A broad overview of the role that the mass media play in American politics. Among the topics to be examined are: how the media affect our image of the world; major theories that attempt to explain the content and bias of media reporting; the impact of the media on public opinion and governance; and politics and the Internet.

title: Media and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A broad overview of the role that the mass media play in American politics. Among the topics to be examined are: how the media affect our image of the world; major theories that attempt to explain the content and bias of media reporting; the impact of the media on public opinion and governance; and politics and the Internet.

title: Egalitarianism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines equality as a social, political, and moral ideal. What, if anything, is objectionable about material and political inequalities among citizens? Does equality have any intrinsic moral significance? Should democratic institutions ensure equality of opportunity, equal outcomes, or equal social standing? Readings will integrate debates about the value of equality with studies of present inequalities in education, health care, and democratic politics.

title: Egalitarianism

Does equality have any intrinsic moral significance? Should democratic institutions ensure equality of opportunity, equal outcomes, or equal social standing? title: Political Theory and the Foreigner
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course asks whether a distinction between citizens and foreigners_in ethics and in the law_is justified. Issues examined include global redistributive justice; the ethics of immigration restrictions; refugee and asylum policy; the concept of citizenship; multiculturalism; and the implications of the war on terror.

title: Political Theory and the Foreigner
subject: GOV

Issues examined include global redistributive justice; the ethics of immigration restrictions; refugee and asylum policy; the concept of citizenship; multiculturalism; and the implications of the war on terror.

title: Contemporary Mexican Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores one of the most complex bilateral relations in the world, given that, among other factors, Mexico and the U.S. share a 2,000-mile border, the largest one between a rich and a developing country.

title: Contemporary Mexican Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores one of the most complex bilateral relations in the world, given that, among other factors, Mexico and the U.S. share a 2,000-mile border, the largest one between a rich and a developing country.

title: Democratic Transitions and European Integration in East Central Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will examine, in a comparative perspective, different patterns of transition to democracy (or authoritarian nationalism) in post-communist Europe and their implications for European integration: European Union enlargement in Central Europe, international protectorates in the Balkans. The relevance of social science theories in trying to account for these contrasting developments will be discussed as well as the geopolitical significance for the European Union and Russia of democratic changes from the Ukraine to the Caucasus.

title: Democratic Transitions and European Integration in East Central Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will examine, in a comparative perspective, different patterns of transition to democracy (or authoritarian nationalism) in post-communist Europe and their implications for European integration: European Union enlargement in Central Europe, international protectorates in the Balkans. The relevance of social science theories in trying to account for these contrasting developments will be discussed as well as the geopolitical significance for the European Union and Russia of democratic changes from the Ukraine to the Caucasus.

title: Mapping the Census
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will use mapping as a methodological technique to examine Census data. Students will be expected to use mapping software to examine Census data for a location of their choice for their final paper. Weekly discussions will be conducted in class on various mapping related topics. Topics include cartography techniques; web based mapping and recent advances in geographic information analysis.

title: The International Politics of the Environment
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since the quality of the natural environment facing citizens of any state depends in part on the policies of other states, national environmental policies are on the agenda of international relations. Seminar examines the resulting politics from the standpoint both of analytical work on international interdependence and writings on contemporary environmental politics.

title: The Rule of Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will study the "Rule of Law" as a political ideal. Unlike democracy or human rights, the Rule of Law is championed even by the most repressive and illiberal regimes. Why is the Rule of Law so widely lauded? Is the Rule of Law valuable for its own sake, or merely for the sake of other values that it safeguards? The course will tackle these questions from both a theoretical and a comparative perspective.

title: International Bargaining and Negotiation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to theories that predict and explain the outcomes of international negotations and the strategies of the parties involved. Specific problems are explored through in-class simulations and historical case studies. Topics include the Middle East, international environmental agreements, deterrence of military aggression, bargaining with multinational corporations, and economic sanctions in defense of human rights.

title: Asian Strategic Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: To what extent and in what ways have non-European strategic thinkers approached the problem of the use of force by the state differently from European strategists? Topics include Hebrew/Israeli, Arabic, Chinese, Indian, and Japanese strategists.

title: American Political Participation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In a democracy, citizens are supposed to influence government policy by participating in the political process. Seminar explores the extent to which ordinary Americans engage in political action, the reasons that some do and some do not, and the consequences.

title: American Political Participation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In a democracy, citizens are supposed to influence government policy by participating in the political process. Seminar explores the extent to which ordinary Americans engage in political action, the reasons that some do and some do not, and the consequences.

title: American Political Participation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In a democracy, citizens are supposed to influence government policy by participating in the political process. Seminar explores the extent to which ordinary Americans engage in political action, the reasons that some do and some do not, and the consequences.

title: Political Participation and Public Policy in the U.S.
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of mass political participation in the policy-making process. Discussion of what normative theory says that role should be, how the public actually behaves, and how representatives respond. Considers whether differences in participation rates by race, ethnicity, gender, age, and class lead to unequal policy treatment. Case studies will include welfare, social security, health care, agricultural subsidies, and tax policy.

title: Empires
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the problem of the rise and decline of empires as a distinct form of political organization, and how these empires have differed through history, their vulnerabilities, and the relationship between imperialism, war, and nationalism. Also examines whether, and in what sense, the United States can be considered an imperial power.

title: Interest Group Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course takes up various claims about interest groups and their role in American politics and considers ways to evaluate them systematically and rigorously. Topics include (1) the organizational politics of interest groups--their formation, their maintenance and their attractions to members; (2) the influence of interest groups on national policymakers--their attempts to lobby Congress and the bureaucracy; and (3) the place of interest groups in the conduct of American democracy.

title: Interest Group Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course takes up various claims about interest groups and their role in American politics and considers ways to evaluate them systematically and rigorously. Topics include (1) the organizational politics of interest groups--their formation, their maintenance and their attractions to members; (2) the influence of interest groups on national policymakers--their attempts to lobby Congress and the bureaucracy; and (3) the place of interest groups in the conduct of American democracy.

title: Hume, Smith, and Kant
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A reading of the major moral, political and economic writings of David Hume, Adam Smith and Immanuel Kant.

title: Hard Cases, Tough Choices
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Political life often presents us with moral dilemmas requiring hard choices. Can political philosophy help us achieve coherence in our choices? Seminar will read classic and contemporary political theory and confront issues regarding religious liberty, property rights, equality, good samaritan laws, same-sex marriage, surrogate motherhood, abortion, euthanasia, HIV, poverty and public health.

title: Hard Cases, Tough Choices
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Political life often presents us with moral dilemmas requiring hard choices. Can political philosophy help us achieve coherence in our choices? Seminar will read classic and contemporary political theory and confront issues regarding religious liberty, property rights, equality, good samaritan laws, same-sex marriage, surrogate motherhood, abortion, euthanasia, HIV, poverty and public health.

title: Representation and American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the alternative ways that public preferences are expressed and communicated in American politics. Comparison made between representation of citizen interest via elections and via interest groups, as well as via such mechanisms as town meeting government, referendum, protest, and public opinion polls. Material related to theories of democracy and social choice.

title: Religion and Politics in 20th Century Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews and analyzes the relationship between four religious faiths and the secular state in contemporary Europe. Among the topics covered are the bases for conflicts between Catholicism, Protestantism, Judaism, and Islam and the state; the terms of reconciliation and collaboration; the conditions under which religion is politicized and becomes the basis of a political movement or party; and the means by which religions seek to maintain an influence in 20th century politics and society.

title: Religion and Politics in 20th Century Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews and analyzes the relationship between four religious faiths and the secular state in contemporary Europe. Among the topics covered are the bases for conflicts between Catholicism, Protestantism, Judaism, and Islam and the state; the terms of reconciliation and collaboration; the conditions under which religion is politicized and becomes the basis of a political movement or party; and the means by which religions seek to maintain an influence in 20th century politics and society.

title: Social Identities
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to theories of social identity in political science and social psychology. Considers a range of traditional identity categories, including race, ethnicity, nationality, class, status, gender, and religion. Emphasizes techniques and strategies that have been developed to measure identity. Course readings consist mainly of empirical works on identity from a variety of geographical areas.

title: International Financial Institutions
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the evolving role of the Bretton Woods Institutions (IMF and World Bank) and (to a lesser degree), the regional development banks. Topics include the governance and purposes of these institutions; the factors that shape their programs and policies; and the economic, social and political consequences of their programs.

title: Ethnic Politics and Citizenship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Ethnic communities have often struggled over the boundaries of citizenship. Demands for national liberation, autonomy, suffrage, and civil rights are among the many issues that have generated bitter political struggles along ethnic lines. This course analyses various theoretical perspectives on the intersection of ethnicity and politics. We explore the different ways in which states have defined citizenship and structured social relations along ethnic lines. We also compare struggles that have emerged to challenge and defend the ethnic basis of these state-society relations. Examples are drawn from the industrialized and developing world, with special attention given to the Americas.

title: Globalization and American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the foreign economic policies of the United States in the context of increasing global economic integration. Topics include: globalization_benefits and costs, winners and losers; lessons from history; determinants of trade policy; political economy of multinational corporations; and reforming the international financial architecture.

title: Globalization and American Foreign Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the foreign economic policies of the United States in the context of increasing global economic integration. Topics include: globalization?benefits and costs, winners and losers; lessons from history; trade policy; multinational corporations; debt crises; labor standards; and international environmental issues.

title: The Politics of International Trade
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the political sources and consequences of international commercial relations. Topics include the domestic sources of trade policy, the role of international institutions and bargaining, North-South relations, and economic sanctions.

title: Democratic Theory and the American Political Novel, 1850-1915
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Can novels enhance our understanding of democracy? Are there aspects of democratic theory and practice that are better understood through the medium of narrative fiction? We will attempt to answer these questions through a close reading of novels by Hawthorne, Melville, Adams, Twain, Bellamy, and Gilman. Topics will include the nature of democratic power and corruption; the relationship between democracy and capitalism; race and gender; and ideals of progress.

title: Democratic Theory and the American Political Novel, 1850-1915
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Can novels enhance our understanding of democracy? Are there aspects of democratic theory and practice that are better understood through the medium of narrative fiction? We will attempt to answer these questions through a close reading of novels by Hawthorne, Melville, Adams, Twain, Bellamy, and Gilman. Topics will include the nature of democratic power and corruption; the relationship between democracy and capitalism; race and gender; and ideals of progress.

title: The Domestic Politics of War in the 20th-Century U.S.
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How have the 4 major wars of the century affected American political competition? Each was fought by a Democratic president who had apparently exhausted the public's appetite for domestic reform (Wilson in World War I, FDR in World War II, Truman in the Korean War, and LBJ in the Vietnam War). Particular attention will be paid to the effects of these presidents' war programs on prior patterns of party and ideological competition, as well as on federal, fiscal, race and social policies.

title: The Domestic Politics of War in the 20th-Century U.S.
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How have the 4 major wars of the century affected American political competition? Each was fought by a Democratic president who had apparently exhausted the public's appetite for domestic reform (Wilson in World War I, FDR in World War II, Truman in the Korean War, and LBJ in the Vietnam War). Particular attention will be paid to the effects of these presidents' war programs on prior patterns of party and ideological competition, as well as on federal, fiscal, race and social policies.

title: Health Care as a Policy-Making Problem
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the dynamics of the American policy-making process by examining health care policy, primarily but not exclusively at the federal level. Comprehensive health care reform is one of the issues considered. Processes of problem definition, agenda setting, deliberation, enactment, implementation, and oversight are reviewed. The dynamics of these features of the policy-making process are assessed with reference to politics (public values, attitudes, and electoral choices), and structure (the presidency, Congress, interest groups, and policy networks).

title: The Social Contract
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why did the social contract become such an important part of political theory and why did it disappear? Readings in Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, and Hume.

title: The Rule of Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will study the "Rule of Law" as a political ideal. Unlike democracy or human rights, the Rule of Law is championed even by the most repressive and illiberal regimes. Why is the Rule of Law so widely lauded? Is the Rule of Law valuable for its own sake, or merely for the sake of other values that it safeguards? The course will tackle these questions from both a theoretical and a comparative perspective.

title: The Rule of Law
subject: GOV

title: Are Americans Good Citizens
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How well do Americans live up to expectations for citizens in a democracy? We begin by considering different perspectives (civic republican, elitist, progressive) on what democracy demands of citizens. Then we review evidence on the actual political behavior of Americans in order to assess how it compares to expectations. In light of any gap between ideal and reality, we conclude by discussing alternative ways of dealing with this gap - education, institutional reform, revised standards, cynicism. Aspects of political behavior covered include knowledge, engagement, opinions, voting, participation, values, and tolerance.

title: The Politics of Reform in Post-Mao China
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative analysis of the impetus, process, and problems of reform in socialist states, with post-Mao China as a case study. Issues include the place of markets and private enterprise in centrally planned economies, the relationship between economic and political reforms, and problems of state control and ideology during the process of reform.

title: Political Persuasion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines political persuasion and democratic decision-making, with particular attention paid to government persuasion campaigns such as presidential elections. What is the function of political persuasion in American democracy? What techniques do political elites use to attempt to influence mass opinions and behavior? Who is most likely to be influenced by such appeals? What is the role of the mass media? Readings drawn from political communication, political psychology, and political behavior.

title: Money in Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the scholarship surrounding the topic of money in politics. We discuss the history of money in politics in the US, the available data on contributor influence, and existing research on recent legal and strategic changes in the campaign finance environment.

title: Money in Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the scholarship surrounding the topic of money in politics. We discuss the history of money in politics in the US, the available data on contributor influence, and existing research on recent legal and strategic changes in the campaign finance environment.

title: Money and Congress
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the relationships between Congressional elections, campaign contributions, and policy outcomes. The first part focuses on what money buys for candidates: does spending ``buy'' votes? If so, how effective is spending? Then course turns to what the contributors get. Are they ideologically motivated, or are they out to get favors for themselves? How important are contributors in the policy formation process? Some background in statistics helpful, but not required.

title: Money and Congress

title: Secrets and Lies in American Law and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Politics seems almost unimaginable without secrecy and lying. This course investigates how American political and legal practices are informed by the keeping and telling of secrets, and the telling and exposing of lies. We will explore the importance of secrecy in the domains of national security and law enforcement and the claims of privacy in our intimate lives. We also will examine ways secrecy and lying are treated in films about American law and politics.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Politics seems almost unimaginable without secrecy and lying. This course investigates how American political and legal practices are informed by the keeping and telling of secrets, and the telling and exposing of lies. We will explore the importance of secrecy in the domains of national security and law enforcement and the claims of privacy in our intimate lives. We also will examine ways secrecy and lying are treated in films about American law and politics.

title: Political Career Ladders in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Changing structure of political careers; decline of parties and rise of media; role of political ambition and self-starters.

title: Political Psychology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The psychology of political choices and actions is one of the oldest concerns and one of the strongest contemporary approaches to the study of politics. The course examines what this approach says about social identities (nationality, race, gender), elite decision-making (personality, perception, reasoning by historical analogy, uncertainty,) socialization, persuasion, obedience to authority, opinion formation, emotion, and other topics. Evaluates the strengths and weaknesses of this approach, as well as possibilities opened up by advances in the study of the human brain and mind.

title: Political Psychology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The psychology of political choices and actions is one of the oldest concerns and one of the strongest contemporary approaches to the study of politics. The course examines what this approach says about social identities (nationality, race, gender), elite decision-making (personality, perception, reasoning by historical analogy, uncertainty,) socialization, persuasion, obedience to authority, opinion formation, emotion, and other topics. Evaluates the strengths and weaknesses of this approach, as well as possibilities opened up by advances in the study of the human brain and mind.

title: Business and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the role of business in politics and the implications for theories of political power in modern democracies. Is business just one of many competing sources of influence in democratic politics or does it occupy a privileged position? Is business too internally fragmented to pursue collective interests? To what extent and why might business power vary over time or from issue to issue? Readings and discussion focus primarily on the United States, but comparative evidence from Japan and Western Europe is considered as well.

title: Business and Politics

Is business just one of many competing sources of influence in democratic politics or does it occupy a privileged position? Is business too internally fragmented to pursue collective interests? To what extent and why might business power vary over time or from issue to issue? Readings and discussion focus primarily on the United States, but comparative evidence from Japan and Western Europe is considered as well.

title: Morality and the American Constitution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers whether moral principles have a role to play in interpreting and applying the American Constitution and, if so, what the relevant moral principles should be. Explores the conflicting claims of democratic, liberal, conservative, libertarian, and feminist constitutional thinkers, as well as proponents of critical legal studies. Readings include Ronald Dworkin, Roberto Unger, Robert Bork, and others.

title: Sino-Soviet Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Sino-Soviet relations from several aspects: historical legacy; common interests; sources of conflict; role of personalities; influence of domestic politics. Although the subject is bilateral relations, the emphasis is on the Chinese standpoint. The course is divided into several parts: relations before 1949; cooperation; conflict; rapprochement.

title: The Politics of Insurgency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on why and how individuals come together to engage in collective action. By studying principally the civil rights/Black protest and women's movements, students review what are considered the agents of protest behavior such as relative deprivation and group consciousness.

title: Politics of Insurgency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on why and how individuals come together to engage in collective action. By studying principally the civil rights/Black protest and women's movements, students review what are considered the agents of protest behavior such as relative deprivation and group consciousness.

title: Congressional Reform and Power
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of changing distribution of influence in House and Senate, and how these have been changed by the "reform" efforts of 1910-11, 1946, and the early 1970s. Problems of intended and unintended results.

title: Jurisprudence: An Introduction to Law and Morals
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar introduces students to key themes in the philosophy of law, or jurisprudence. The problems of jurisprudence are persistent and affect societies the world over. They concern the nature of law, the appropriate role of sovereigns, the proper role of judges, law's authority, and law's role in democracy and dictatorship. Examining the work of Austin, Schmitt, Hart, Dworkin, Luhmann, Habermas and others, this seminar debates law's promise_its real and imagined place in society.

title: Jurisprudence: An Introduction to Law and Morals
subject: GOV

Examining the work of Austin, Schmitt, Hart, Dworkin, Luhmann, Habermas and others, this seminar debates law's promise_its real and imagined place in society.

title: Gender, Politics, and Markets
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Although improvements have been made during the past century, women are still treated differently within the family, workplace and in politics. Where does this difference originate? Is gender difference either necessary or desirable? Why does the status of women differ across countries?

title: Representing Gender, Race and Class
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the proposition that in all existing democracies, political representation fails to meet democratic standards. Discussion of what those standards should be, how representatives and systems of representation actually act, and what difference (if any) it makes when citizens from different gender, racial, ethnic and/or class groups appear in lower percentages in representative bodies than in the population as a whole. Reading will combine normative theory (with an emphasis on theories of representation, identity politics, and group representation) and empirical studies.

title: Representing Gender, Race and Class
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the proposition that in all existing democracies, political representation fails to meet democratic standards. Discussion of what those standards should be, how representatives and systems of representation actually act, and what difference it makes when women, African-Americans or working-class citizens appear in lower percentages in representative bodies than in the population as a whole. Reading will combine normative theory and empirical studies.

title: States and Markets in Developing Countries
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interaction of states and markets in economic development in LDCs. Readings and discussion will focus on state and market institutions and the effects of globalization.

title: States and Markets in Developing Countries
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interaction of states and markets in economic development in LDCs. Readings and discussion will focus on state and market institutions and the effects of globalization.

title: States and Markets in Developing Countries
subject: GOV

title: Democratization and Economic Liberalization in the Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will examine the processes of political and economic liberalization currently underway inthe Middle East. By comparing several countries which are liberalizing (Algeria, Egypt, Morocco, and Jordan), to two which are not (Syria and Saudi Arabia), we will consider what factors best explain political and economic openings. We will also explore the extent to which various factors such as regime type, resource endowments, the sequencing of political and economic reforms, or the role of political Islam influence the likelihood that Middle Eastern countries will eventually develop into modern democracies. No prior background in the Middle East is assumed.

title: Democratization and Economic Liberalization in the Middle East

By comparing several countries which are liberalizing (Algeria, Egypt, Morocco, and Jordan), to two which are not (Syria and Saudi Arabia), we will consider what factors best explain political and economic openings. No prior background in the Middle East is assumed.

title: Classics and Contemporaries in Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course covers some important contemporary debates in comparative politics_on such matters as democracy and economic development, social capital and governance, or class conflict and political regimes_and relates them to classic works in the discipline. Beyond an understanding of how comparative politics has evolved, students will gain insight into how to research, and participate in, an ongoing scholarly discussion.

title: Classics and Contemporaries in Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course covers some important contemporary debates in comparative politics_on such matters as democracy and economic development, social capital and governance, or class conflict and political regimes_and relates them to classic works in the discipline. Beyond an understanding of how comparative politics has evolved, students will gain insight into how to research, and participate in, an ongoing scholarly discussion.

title: Cultural Politics: Religion and State in Modern Democracies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Studies contemporary responses to the classic dilemma of church-state separation in modern democracies. Focuses on such flashpoints as the politics of veiling in France, blasphemy in England, personal status in Israel, education and prayer in the US, free speech in Iran. Analyzes the political and ideological underpinnings of diverse approaches from official secularism and the ``non-establishment'' of religion to ``equal protection'' and the state in the service of faith.

title: Cultural Politics: Religion and State in Modern Democracies
subject: GOV

title: Religion & Politics: American Exceptionalism, European Secularism?
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Contrary to what proponents of the secularization thesis predicted, religion has not lost its political salience in the developed world. Not only do "old" cleavages still matter, but new political fault lines continue to be drawn along dimensions of religious belief and identity. In this course we will examine the broad theoretical contours of religion's role in politics and analyze how religion specifically influences contemporary political discourses in the US and Europe.

title: Religion & Politics: American Exceptionalism, European Secularism?
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Contrary to what proponents of the secularization thesis predicted, religion has not lost its political salience in the developed world. Not only do "old" cleavages still matter, but new political fault lines continue to be drawn along dimensions of religious belief and identity. In this course we will examine the broad theoretical contours of religion's role in politics and analyze how religion specifically influences contemporary political discourses in the US and Europe.

title: Inequality and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the nature and dimensions of social inequality and the relevance of inequalities among groups defined by their race, gender, class, age, or caste to politics. Also considers the contrast between the formal political equality that inheres in citizenship and actual inequalities of political influence. Finally, the effects on inequality of various public policies e.g., welfare state guarantees for the aged, comparable worth pay schemes, affirmative action, and Reaganomics are considered. Although illustrative materials are drawn mainly from American politics, examples from other nations, India and China, for example, are discussed as well.

title: National Governance in a Global Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how different industrialized countries have responded to international economic trends, with particular attention to Germany and Japan. Are national systems of economic governance obsolete? How do domestic political pressures interact with international economic forces? Topics include privatization, deregulation, trade, corporate governance, telecommunications, finance, labor markets.

title: National Governance in a Global Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how different industrialized countries have responded to international economic trends, with particular attention to Germany and Japan. Are national systems of economic governance obsolete? How do domestic political pressures interact with international economic forces? Topics include privatization, deregulation, trade, corporate governance, telecommunications, finance, labor markets.

title: Civil Society in Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores the concept of civil society with a focus on Asia. It looks at the Western origins of the idea of civil society, public space, and social capital; debates over their applicability outside the West; the relation between civil society and democracy; the forms civil society takes under conditions of repression; and how civil societies arise in the first place. Special attention to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and India.

title: Civil Society in Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores the concept of civil society with a focus on Asia. It looks at the Western origins of the idea of civil society, public space, and social capital; debates over their applicability outside the West; the relation between civil society and democracy; the forms civil society takes under conditions of repression; and how civil societies arise in the first place. Special attention to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and India.

title: Civil Society in Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines civil societies in Asia, with particular emphasis on East Asia. After tracing how the concept evolved in Western and Eastern Europe, it explores: how the term applies in the Asian context; how globalization, religion, ethnic conflict, market reforms, international NGOs, corruption, the Internet, post-September 11 developments, and other forces are affecting civil societies in Asia; and the relation between developments in civil society and democratization in Asia.

title: Civil Society in Asia

Special attention to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and India.

title: Civil Society in Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar explores the concept of civil society with a focus on Asia.
