title: Civil Society in Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar looks at the concept of civil society in the Asian context, with particular emphasis on East Asia. The seminar first examines how the concept originally evolved in Western societies, looking at the debates over civil society in Western and Eastern Europe. It then explores how the term applies in the Asian context. It looks at how the Internet, globalization, religion, ethnic conflict, market reforms, corruption, international NGOs, the IMF, and other forces, internal and external, are affecting civil societies in Asia, and the relation between developments in civil society and democritization. It also looks at the evolution of international civil society and Asia's place in it.

title: Politics and Psychology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How do Americans "understand" politics? This question is addressed by reviewing work in cognitive and social psychology and its application to the development of models of human behavior and thought in political science. For example, how do voters make rational decisions; how are political opinions formed?

title: Latino Political Behavior
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Begins with an extensive review of theoretical literature on ethnicity and ethnic politics. Examines major empirical literature on American ethnic politics and relates it to the emerging literature on the Mexican, Puerto Rican, and Cuban-origin populations of the United States.

title: Contentious Issues and Policy Choices in Contemporary Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on a series of contentious issues in contemporary Japan, exploring the ideological, political, and social dimensions of each, and conflict and consensus in the Japanese approach to resolving them. Issues include constitutional revision and police power; patriotism and the role of the Empire; domestic responses to market opening pressures from abroad; agricultural subsidies, including the rice price issue; social welfare and quality of life; environmental protection; issues affecting women; problems of minorities and foreign workers; the issue of political corruption; Japan's future security role, and other questions.

title: Contentious Issues and Policy Choices in Contemporary Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on a series of contentious issues in contemporary Japan, exploring the ideological, political, and social dimensions of each, and conflict and consensus in the Japanese approach to resolving them. Issues include constitutional revision and police power; patriotism and the role of the Empire; domestic responses to market opening pressures from abroad; agricultural subsidies, including the rice price issue; social welfare and quality of life; environmental protection; issues affecting women; problems of minorities and foreign workers; the issue of political corruption; Japan's future security role, and other questions.

Issues include constitutional revision and police power; patriotism and the role of the emperor; domestic responses to market opening pressures; social welfare and quality of life; environmental protection; problems of women, minorities and foreign workers; the issue of political corruption; Japan's future security role.

title: Politics of Democratization in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the prospects for the consolidation of democracy in Latin America, and the conditions that favor democratic rule and the process of democratization. Examines the roles of various political and social actors and institutions in democratization, including the military, Catholic church, women's, labor, and ethnic movements, and political parties. Considers new dimensions of partisanship, proposals for institutional reform, and the effects of economic constraints and market-oriented policy reforms on new democracies.

title: Politics of Democratization in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the prospects for the consolidation of democracy in Latin America, and the conditions that favor democratic rule and the process of democratization. Examines the roles of various political and social actors and institutions in democratization, including the military, Catholic church, women's, labor, and ethnic movements, and political parties. Considers new dimensions of partisanship, proposals for institutional reform, and the effects of economic constraints and market-oriented policy reforms on new democracies.

title: Democratic Politics in Cosmopolitan Times
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What role do "strangers" or "foreigners" play in the constitution of the democratic nation-state? When and under what conditions is strangeness a support of national unity and when do strangers cause a rift in the regime? When and under what conditions is national unity a condition of democracy? What assumptions about sovereignty, territory, state unity and individual agency underlie various recent efforts by democratic theorists to come to terms with the effects of late modern diversities, immigration, and global capitalism? Authors include: Rousseau, Taylor, Walzer, Tocqueville, Rogin, Simmel, Connolly, Tully, Hochschild, Bourne.

title: Ethnic Conflict and Peace
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What is ethnicity? How is it different from nationalism? Why do ethnic groups fight? Under what conditions do they manage their relations peacefully? This seminar is organized around these questions. Materials from all over the world will be covered. Though the classic works on ethnicity will be included, the focus will be on the contemporary period and scholarship.

title: Ethnic Conflict and Peace
subject: GOV

This seminar is organized around these questions. Materials from all over the world will be covered. title: Elite Decision-Making
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of case studies of elite decision-making in both domestic and foreign/defense policy. Impact of "bounded rationality" on selective attention, search for alternatives and their consequences, role of analogies and of time pressure; use of cognitive maps belief systems, and history.

title: Liberalism and Its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the debate between defenders of liberalism and its many critics. Focuses on contemporary liberals and their feminist, communitarian, democratic, libertarian, post-modern and pluralist critics.

title: Liberalism and Its Critics
subject: GOV

title: Building the Activist State: American Public Policy Since 1960
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Contemporary conflicts over domestic policy play out against the backdrop of the dramatic expansion of government activity after 1960. We examine the causes and political consequences of the gradual growth of activist government, focusing on three domains: the expansion of social programs, the emergence of "new'' social regulation in areas such as the environment and consumer protection, and the expansion of protections for particular groups (often termed the "rights revolution'').

title: Building the Activist State: American Public Policy Since 1960
subject: GOV

title: Building the Activist State: American Public Policy Since 1960.
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The role of the federal government in American society is now highly controversial. These contemporary conflicts over domestic policy play out against the backdrop of a dramatic expansion of government activity that occurred over the past four decades. This course examines the causes and political consequences of the gradual growth of activist government, focusing on three domains: the expansion of social programs, the emergence of "new'' social regulation in areas such as the environment and consumer protection, and the expansion of protections for particular groups (often termed the "rights revolution'').

title: International Migration and the Political Economy of Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the economic, political and social consequences of international migration and diasporas, particularly on developing countries. Is the phenomenon of greater import in the current (and future) context than it has historically been and if so, why? When are diasporas likely to be more influential and how does this influence shape well-being in their country of origin? What are the implications of looser concepts of citizenship? Country examples include China, India, Mexico and Turkey.

title: The Indochina Conflict
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An analysis of the First, Second, and Third Indochina Wars. Special attention devoted to the United States in Vietnam. Contending theoretical explanations of and ethical arguments about the U.S. intervention in Vietnam are examined.

title: Aristotle's Politics Then and Now
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the value of Aristotle's writings on justice, property, citizenship, human nature, personal and political identity both in their own right and for contemporary democratic politics.

title: Aristotle's Politics Then and Now
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the value of Aristotle's writings on justice, property, citizenship, human nature, personal and political identity both in their own right and for contemporary democratic politics.

title: The Early Development of American Political Institutions and Organizations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of developments in the party system, social movements, Congress, the presidency and the bureaucracy from the colonial period through the Civil War. Rise of the two-party system, the mass party and changes in voting rights; congressional committees and their power; building of the Constitution and the federal judiciary; abolitionism and new social movements, the emergence of early bureaucratic institutions, and the presidency  studied using three theoretical approaches (rational choice, historical institutionalism, and critical theory).

title: The Constitutional Politics of The Federalist
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of The Federalist, with the Anti-Federalists, attendant documents, Locke, Montesquieu and Tocqueville, to consider the political science and the statesmanship of the Constitution.

title: The Constitutional Politics of The Federalist
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of The Federalist, with the Anti-Federalists, attendant documents, Locke, Montesquieu and Tocqueville, to consider the political science and the statesmanship of the Constitution.

title: Who Makes Law?
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focus on policy making in the modern administrative state. How does a statute become controlling law in a society? Examines crucial roles of legislative, executive, administrative, and judicial influence on "law making." Special attention to the process of statutory interpretation. Some comparative analysis may be included.

title: The Media Campaign
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The objective is to investigate, understand, and evaluate the processes through which potential voters encounter information about politics and government. Addresses content, causes, and effects of news coverage and paid political advertising. Focus is on presidential campaigns, but some attention given to campaigns for Congress and other offices as well.

title: Human Rights Scholars Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar is open to juniors in any concentration interested in human rights research. During the first half of the semester, we will review key theoretical concepts and discuss various disciplinary approaches to and methodologies for conducting human rights scholarship. During the second half, students will develop and workshop a research prospectus on a human rights topic in which they are interested. Preference will be given to students intending on writing a senior thesis. Preference given to juniors considering writing a senior thesis on human rights related topic (from all concentrations) or engaged in a serious research project on a human rights topic

title: Sino-US Relations in an Era of Rising Chinese Power
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Assesses theoretical arguments and empirical evidence concerning the implications of Chinese economic and military modernization for conflict and cooperation between China and the US. Some issues examined include global arms control, trade, the environment, and regional security.

title: Contemporary Issues in U.S. Defense Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In this seminar U.S. security policy in three areas will be examined. First, nuclear arms control policies towards Russia will be considered with a focus on the future of the ABM Treaty and what are the prospects for and possible security implications of further arms reductions beyond START II. Second, U.S. policy in NATO will be examined with particular attention given to assessing the rationale and security implications of NATO enlargement and the alliance's military intervention into the Balkan civil wars over the past decade. Third, the debate over U.S. grand strategy for responding to and managing the rising economic and military power of China will be assessed. For each of the three main topics covered in the seminar, general theories and empirical findings on the causes of international conflict and cooperation will be drawn upon to help assess contending positions in policy debates.

title: The Politics of International Monetary Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines some of the political issues surrounding the nature of international monetary relations, including how monetary policies are selected, the impact of international monetary problems, and rules governing international monetary flows. Monetary relations are the foundation upon which other international economic relations rest. Some of the subjects include the gold standard, the Bretton Woods system, the role of international monetary institutions such as the IMF and IBRD, floating exchange rates, international debt, EMU, and future international monetary prospects.

title: Partisanship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Partisanship has a bad name: it is often thought an expression of inherited prejudice, petty ambition, narrow interest, or dogmatic ideology. Does it merit more esteem? Readings from historical and contemporary political thinkers such as Aristotle, Hobbes, Burke, Schmidt, Shumpeter, Habermas, Rawls, Mouffe, Hampshire, and Gray.

title: Partisanship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Partisanship has a bad name: it is often thought an expression of inherited prejudice, petty ambition, narrow interest, or dogmatic ideology. Does it merit more esteem? Readings from historical and contemporary political thinkers such as Aristotle, Hobbes, Burke, Schmidt, Shumpeter, Habermas, Rawls, Mouffe, Hampshire, and Gray.

title: Partisanship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Partisanship has a bad name: it is often thought an expression of inherited prejudice, petty ambition, narrow interest, or dogmatic ideology. Does it merit more esteem? In what forms, if any, is it respectable or even admirable? Course assesses claims of partisanship in relation to its more and less defective rivals. Readings include Aristotle, Hobbes, Rousseau, Mill, Ross Perot, Ralph Nader, and selections from contemporary political science.

title: Comparative Elections and Party Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a comparative study of the role of elections and political parties in the governance of liberal democracies. Focusing on Western Europe and North America, the course seeks to understand peoples' motivations in voting, as well as the objectives of parties in attracting support and in exercising power. We will explore the historical origins of modern parties and party systems, the determinants of individual voting behavior, the internal dynamic of parties, their role in electoral competition and government formation, and the effects of partisan governments and elections on public policies and political-economic outcomes (including equality, growth, and business cycles). We will also discuss recent changes in the role of parties and elections, and whether these changes represent a fundamental transformation of party politics.

title: Comparative Elections and Party Politics

title: Japan in the Social Sciences
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar analyzes politics, society, and policy in contemporary Japan. It brings theories and approaches from political science, sociology, economics, and other disciplines to bear on basic issues and problems relating to Japan in comparative perspective over the period from 1868 to the present, focusing mainly on the past decade. It takes the measure of Japanese democracy; of the socio-political system that is emerging from the ``lost decade''; and of Japan's evolving international role.

title: International Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar reviews major theoretical and historical issues in security studies. It covers balance, civil-military relations, deterrence, the balance of power, and the political economy of security policies. The course grounds theoretical discussions with analysis of important empirical issues-particularly the two world wars and the Cold War to give students an understanding of some of the most prominent historical issues in the political science literature and of the historiography of the 20th century great-power system.

title: International Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar reviews major theoretical and historical issues in security studies. It covers balance, civil-military relations, deterrence, the balance of power, and the political economy of security policies. The course grounds theoretical discussions with analysis of important empirical issues-particularly the two world wars and the Cold War to give students an understanding of some of the most prominent historical issues in the political science literature and of the historiography of the 20th century great-power system.

title: International Security Affairs
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: In this seminar three central topics in the study of international security affairs will be examined. First, the utility of military force as an instrument of foreign policy will be considered. Policies of deterrence and compellence will be studied with the goal to try and better understand when such policies are likely to succeed or fail. Second, the security consequences of changes in the relative military power of states will be examined. Particular attention will be focused on the questions of whether arms races and power transitions are important causes of conflict and war. Third, the impact of domestic political institutions and conditions on security policy will be analyzed. Two questions will be asked: a) Do democratic political institutions and norms influence decisions by political leaders regarding the use of military force? b) Do periods of political instability and change within states increase the risks of international conflict?

title: The Politics of Regulation and Consumer Protection in America, 1900-Present
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why has consumer protection come into favor, and fallen out of favor in US politics at particular times over the twentieth century? How does consumer protection politics in the area of tangible goods (food, drugs, cosmetics, medical devices, vaccines, cars, tires, toys), differ from consumer protection politics around the environment (land, air, water), and around intangible, complicated services (health insurance, loans, credit)? How do features of the American political system help us answer these questions?

title: The Politics of Regulation and Consumer Protection in America, 1900-Present
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Why has consumer protection come into favor, and fallen out of favor in US politics at particular times over the twentieth century? How does consumer protection politics in the area of tangible goods (food, drugs, cosmetics, medical devices, vaccines, cars, tires, toys), differ from consumer protection politics around the environment (land, air, water), and around intangible, complicated services (health insurance, loans, credit)? title: The First Amendment Freedoms
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Combines a philosophic study of freedom of speech, press, and religion with constitutional law and history. We will start with the American founding (the Puritans, Madison's Memorial and Remonstrance, the framing of the Bill of Rights, the Alien and Sedition Acts and the Virginia Report). We will then read Milton's Areopagitica, Locke's Letter On Toleration and Mill's On Liberty. Then we will study the Supreme Court's treatment of the first amendment freedoms.

title: The First Amendment Freedoms
subject: GOV

title: American Social Movements
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A theoretical discussion of American social movements. Cases examined might include: temperance, suffrage, civil rights, the environmental movement, women's rights/ERA, urban community mobilization, and the anti-abortion movement. We will be looking at these movements through the theoretical lenses of symbolic, rational choice, and resource mobilization theories to look at some of the following questions: Are these movements about values or interests? How do we assess movement strategies? How do we define their ^'^'success'' or ^'^'failure?'' What kinds of changes have they introduced to U.S. politics, if any?

title: American Social Movements
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines social movements in 19th and 20th century America using theoretical material and case studies of major social movements. Topics will include how movements arise and evolve, how members determine strategy, the relationship between movements and other modes of politics, and why movements succeed or fail.

title: American Social Movements
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines social movements in 19th and 20th century America using theoretical material and case studies of major social movements. Topics will include how movements arise and evolve, how members determine strategy, the relationship between movements and other modes of politics, and why movements succeed or fail.

title: The Presidency in Historical Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This class will use case studies of past presidential leadership as a lens to gain insight into the leadership challenges confronting more recent presidents. We will examine the ways personality, skill, law, institutional structure, and norms of leadership interact with one another and try to grapple with how much each of these factors shape the president's ability to lead.

title: The Presidency in Historical Perspective
subject: GOV

We will examine the ways personality, skill, law, institutional structure, and norms of leadership interact with one another and try to grapple with how much each of these factors shape the president's ability to lead.

title: Leaders, Politicians, and Visionaries
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What is the role of leadership in US politics? Why have particular individuals_Thomas Jefferson, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Martin Luther King_had tremendous impact on the ways we think and behave politically? Can one learn effective leadership skills? Can one learn to be charismatic? What is the relationship between leaders and followers? How do leaders handle adversity? Students consider classic readings on leadership, analyses of specific US leaders, and conduct independent research.

title: After Communism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive examination of the effort to create new political, economic, and social institutions in the wake of the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.

title: The Mirror of Princes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Advice to the prince from ancient, medieval and modern readings: Xenophon, On Tyranny and Cyropaideia; Ptolemy of Lucca, On the Government of Rulers; Machiavelli, The Prince.

title: The Mirror of Princes
subject: GOV

title: Comparative Constitutionalism: Religion and State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to key constitutional concepts using a cross-national comparative examination of religious freedom issues. Topics include: processes of constitution-making, implementing and enforcing constitutions, constitutional accommodation of diversity and the relationship between societies and their constitutions. Readings emphasize contemporary debates on religious affairs: the wearing of religious headscarves, public funding for religious institutions, same-sex marriage and more.

title: Comparative Constitutionalism: Religion and State
subject: GOV

title: Oslo and After
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the post-1991 period, particularly the circumstances that facilitated the Oslo Peace Process and those which led to its collapse. Topics include the rise of radical nationalism and radical Islam; how the international politics of the Gulf area intersect with the politics of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict; the impact of the war in Afghanistan on the region; and what role is there, if any, for the outside powers today.

title: The Struggle for Palestine/Israel
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the century-long struggle over Palestine/Israel from a local perspective. Considers competing historical and moral claims to the land, the creation of political "facts'' and dispossession, the influence of regional politics, the role of local political organizations from Hamas to Gush Emunim, the nature of conditions in the West Bank and Gaza, and the possibilities for reconciliation between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: Religion and Political Theory in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the normative challenges posed by religion for modern states. How should religion be accommodated? What are the different forms of accommodation? An explicitly comparative course which includes cases from India, the US, and Europe.

title: The Politics of American Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The purpose of this seminar is to examine the sources and implications of political controversy over US foreign policy, especially since World War II. The readings and class discussion will consider explanations for disagreements on the appropriate course of action for the US in the international arena, as well as the effects these disagreements have had on policy choices, and on American society and politics more generally.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analysis of the nature of the Cold War and post-Cold War international environments and their implications for American national security. Includes discussion of the economic, political, and institutional as well as military dimensions of national security.

subject: GOV

title: Rethinking the Welfare State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The goal of the course is to challenge existing notions of the welfare state. Who shapes welfare programs? Does the welfare state help the poor? Does the welfare state treat men and women equally? Is the welfare state ``anti-market'' in nature? Does it simply place a burden on the national economy or does it promote national competitiveness? Although class readings and cases are mostly from advanced industrial societies, the course includes a unit on new trajectories from emerging economies.

title: Rethinking the Welfare State
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Compares social policy in different countries and different theories about them, while also thinking systematically about the logic of comparative study. Questions we address are: What are the main areas of welfare state activities? How can we distinguish different welfare states? What shapes them and what are their effects? How have different welfare states changed? (Empirical materials mostly?but not exclusively?cover advanced industrial societies.)

title: Women and the Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: After a historical examination of Aristotle, Locke, and Hegel on women, family, the state and law, this course will look at contemporary debates around abortion, pornography, and sexual harassment. Readings from McKinnon, Cornell, Butler, Nussbaum, Scott and others.

title: The Civil Rights and the Anti-Vietnam War Movements: The Changing Locus of Social Movements
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines the origins, goals, influences and interrelationship of two of the major social and political movements in the late 20th century: Civil Rights and Antiwar. It discusses the similarities, differences, focuses, and interconnection of these movements from the perspectives of race, class, and gender. As befits a course on social movements, students need to be active participants in the discussions and research.

title: American Political Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys the long-term development of the U.S. state and political system, and more closely examines changes since the 1960s in social policies, party politics, and social movements and citizen participation. The semester will culminate in an examination of the Obama era juxtaposed to earlier transformative eras in U.S. governance and politics, including the New Deal of the 1930s. Students will gain a critical appreciation of historical and institutionally focused research on the American polity. Limited to 16. Open to any undergraduate by application to instructor on first day of class.

title: Marriage and the State in Western Political Theory and Practice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the relationship between marriage and the state in Western political thought and practice. What role should the state have in recognizing and regulating marriage? Considers the writings of canonical thinkers (including Augustine, Locke, Hegel, Mill) and contemporary theorists (including Okin, Shanley, Galston). Also focuses on the empirical history of the relationship_in the US and other liberal democracies.

subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Covers recent writings on the politics and economics of Africa. Emphasis placed on recent writings on political reform (democratization), state disintegrations, and violence.

title: The Korean Peninsula and international Politics of East Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will examine contemporary international politics of Northeast Asia surrounding the Korean peninsula. Issues for special attention include the political and economic developments in the region, the external relations of the two Koreas with the major powers, and the emerging shape of the regional order. Two policy agenda will be the subject of intense scrutiny: the rise of China and North Korea's search for nuclear capability.

title: The Korean Peninsula and international Politics of East Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will examine contemporary international politics of Northeast Asia surrounding the Korean peninsula. Issues for special attention include the political and economic developments in the region, the external relations of the two Koreas with the major powers, and the emerging shape of the regional order. Two policy agenda will be the subject of intense scrutiny: the rise of China and North Korea's search for nuclear capability.

title: Politics, Institutions and Prosperity
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the role of politics, institutions, culture and geography in explaining why some countries are prosperous and others are not over the long-run. Key questions include: Why were the Americas so backward economically compared to Europe at the time of the conquest initiated in 1492? Why was it Europe and not China where the industrial revolution took place? What explains why African countries are so poor today?

title: Politics, Institutions and Prosperity
subject: GOV

title: Political Order in Africa
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Traces the efforts of various African leaders to secure political order in rapidly changing, plural societies. Discusses the rise of the single-party state, emergence of patrimonial rule, experiments with federal systems in both authoritarian and democratic contexts, and informal resort to "mixed" government. Concludes with arguments for party competition now current in some parts of Africa.

title: The International Politics of East Asia
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the interaction of foreign relations and domestic politics in and among the major countries of Northeast and Southeast Asia. Topics include the political and economic relations of the principal East Asian states, the sources of cooperation and conflict in the region, and an assessment of the political feasibility of a free trade agreement in East Asia. Attention is also given to the role of the United States in this most dynamic region of the world political economy.

title: Liberal Internationalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The end of the Cold War has sparked new interest in traditional liberal arguments about the effects on world politics of democratization, commerce, social and cultural interactions, and international law. This seminar examines and evaluates liberal internationalist thought from the perspectives of political philosophy, social science theory, modern history, and public policy.

title: Democracy and Dictatorship: Social and Political Explanations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers competing explanations for the widely different forms taken by national political systems, focusing especially on conditions favorable to the emergence and stability of democracy. The theories examined analyze many factors, including level of socioeconomic development, political institutions, political beliefs and ideologies, long-term patterns of social development and class relations, ethnicity, and political action itself. Special attention to transitions to democracy and explanations for the breakdown of democratic regimes.

title: Retroactive Justice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar introduces students to the theory and history of retroactive, or transitional, justice. It explores the logic of truth commissions, international criminal tribunals, reparations, and related responses to genocide, crimes against humanity, and other mass atrocities. Examining the whole array of historical and contemporary solutions to the problem of ``radical evil'' (Immanuel Kant) the seminar assesses the conditions for, and limitations to, achieving truth and justice in domestic politics and international affairs.

title: Retroactive Justice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar introduces students to the theory and history of retroactive, or transitional, justice. It explores the logic of truth commissions, international criminal tribunals, reparations, and related responses to genocide, crimes against humanity, and other mass atrocities. Examining the whole array of historical and contemporary solutions to the problem of ``radical evil'' (Immanuel Kant) the seminar assesses the conditions for, and limitations to, achieving truth and justice in domestic politics and international affairs.

title: Truth and Justice in International Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar introduces students to the theory and history of retroactive, or transitional, justice in international politics. It explores the logic of truth commissions, war crimes tribunals, reparations, and related responses to genocide, crimes against humanity, and other mass atrocities. Examining the whole array of historical and contemporary solutions to the problem of ``radical evil'' (Carlos Nino), the seminar assesses the conditions for, and limitations to, achieving truth and justice in international politics.

title: Culture, Identity and Politics in Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines contemporary European attempts to come to terms politically with rapid sociological change, increasing integration and ^'^'globalization,'' and new forms of cultural diversity. Considers what these developments suggest about the contemporary practice and meaning of democracy. Focuses on France and Germany, with frequent reference to the United States.

title: Culture, Identity and Politics in Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines contemporary European attempts to come to terms politically with rapid sociological change, increasing integration and ^'^'globalization,'' and new forms of cultural diversity. Considers what these developments suggest about the contemporary practice and meaning of democracy. Focuses on France and Germany, with frequent reference to the United States.

title: Terrorist Movements
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the philosophical and historical antecedents of contemporary terrorism. We will compare different types of terrorist movements, the strategies they adopt, and the threat they pose to the modern state.

title: Civil Society and the Public Sphere
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Addresses two of the most influential_and contested_concepts in recent political thought. To what extent is the sphere of associational life (membership in churches, unions, clubs, etc.) supportive or even identical with the public sphere (the realm of politics, citizenship, and the common good)? To what extent should these spheres be viewed as distinct or in tension? Readings from Hegel, Marx, Tocqueville, Mill, Arendt, Habermas, Sennett, Fraser, Gellner, Walzer, Rosenblum and Putnam.

title: Civil Society and the Public Sphere
subject: GOV

To what extent should these spheres be viewed as distinct or in tension? Readings from Hegel, Marx, Tocqueville, Mill, Arendt, Habermas, Sennett, Fraser, Gellner, Walzer, Rosenblum and Putnam.

title: Domestic Politics and International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the domestic sources of international relations among the United States, Europe, and Japan. Cases chosen from both the economic and security fields, including such problems as macroeconomic coordination, trade, East-West relations, defense policy, and European integration.

title: Domestic Politics and International Relations in the Trilateral World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the domestic sources of international relations among the United States, Western Europe, and Japan. Cases chosen from both the economic and security fields, including such problems as macroeconomic coordination, trade, East-West relations, defense policy, and European integration.

title: Domestic Politics and International Relations in the Trilateral World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the domestic sources of international relations among the United States, Western Europe, and Japan. title: Political Theory and Legal Reasoning
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the relationship between law and politics, focusing on the ways in which legal structures and principles help make different kinds of politics possible. Theories connecting law to natural rights, sociopolitical context, class struggle, and power/knowledge are considered. These different approaches to law are used to analyze selected decisions of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Supreme Court and the Politics of Minority Representation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the formulation of public policy by the Supreme Court on issues of race. Particular emphasis placed on the way in which Justices have framed and understood the questions of representation posed by the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The general consequences of delegating policymaking power to the Court are explored. Government 1340 or another law-related course would be helpful.

title: International Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the theory and practice of international law. Topics include international economic regulation; international environmental law; the United Nations and other international organizations; domestic enforcement of international obligations; unilateral and multilateral intervention.

title: Law and Morality
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Problems in the legal enforcement of morality, considered from the perspective of political theory. Emphasis is on the role of the state in legislating on issues such as abortion, capital punishment, euthenasia, pornography, and surrogacy. Readings in both historical and contemporary sources.

title: Law and Morality
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Problems in the legal enforcement of morality, considered from the perspective of political theory. courseDescriptionLong: Problems in the legal enforcement of morality, considered from the perspective of political theory. Emphasis is on the role of the state in legislating on issues such as abortion, homosexuality, euthanasia, pornography, and surrogacy. Readings in both historical and contemporary sources.

title: Law and Morality

title: The Politics of Economic Policy Reform
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Recession and the debt crisis rendered the 1980s a decade of lost development. Inspired by the exceptional performance of the Asian NICS, governments throughout the world attempted to create market-based economies. All face internal challenges; they encountered as well external pressures from the IMF, the World Bank, private creditors, and the donor community. The political repercussions included the downfall of socialist governments and the rise of new democracies. Readings, discussion, and student research projects focus on the political efforts of governments in the Third World and Eastern Europe to adjust and reform.

title: Plato's Political Dialogues
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A reading of Plato's Protagoras and Gorgias.

title: Topics in Jurisprudence
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: From within the Anglo-American and Continental legal traditions, and by way of premodern and postmodern approaches to law, this seminar studies the nature of obligation, what it is to follow a rule of law, justifications for imposing sanctions when rules of law are breached, and the process of adjudication.

title: Politics and Aesthetics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the relationship between political institutions and aesthetic practices in the works of Plato, Aristotle, Rousseau, Nietzsche, Adorno and Horkheimer. The central question of the course will be whether and how the arts play a role in moral and political education and/or corruption. More specifically, we will try to determine which aspects of the arts are important for a democratic politics and which aspects are dangerous for such a politics.

title: Politics and Aesthetics

title: The Politics of Immigration and Immigrant Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses issues and problems in contemporary and historical immigration policies (primarily in the United States and Western Europe) from the perspectives of both the state, and the immigrants targeted by these policies.

title: Crisis Bargaining Strategies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the major bargaining strategies that have been forwarded as methods for the successful and nonviolent resolution of international crises. First part examines the logic behind traditional theories of deterrence and coercion, cooperative bargaining strategies such as tit-for-tat, signaling games and the role of norms in crisis bargaining, and psychologically based theories such as GRIT and reassurance theory. In the latter part, these theories are applied to the analysis of crises in several issue areas, such as conventional deterrence, nuclear deterrence and proliferation, and the use of international sanctions.

title: Crisis Bargaining Strategies

title: Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Students will read a variety of classic and contemporary studies of democratic government. Readings will draw on all four subfields, with a special emphasis on comparing alternative institutions. Statistics and game theory will be introduced as needed.

title: Democracy and Dictatorship in 19th- and 20th-Century Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What conditions are necessary for the creation of durable democratic parties? Why do democracies sometimes break down and how can such breakdowns be reversed? These questions are explored through an analysis of political development in 19th- and 20th-century Europe, including the recent transitions to democracy in both halves of the continent. Readings include both theoretical and historical works.

title: Supreme Court and the Politics of Minority Representation
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers the formulation of public policy by the Supreme Court on issues of race. Particular emphasis placed on the way in which justices have framed and understood the questions of representation posed by the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Liberalism and Its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reading and discussion of writings by contemporary defenders and critics of liberal political theory. Topics to include toleration, civic virtue, group rights, and the relation of politics to religion, morality, and law.

title: Liberalism and Its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reading and discussion of writings by contemporary defenders and critics of liberal political theory. Topics to include toleration, civic virtue, group rights, and the relation of politics to religion, morality, and law.

title: Congress and Representative Government
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the behavior of members of Congress and the expectations of American citizens in order to gain an understanding of the contemporary representational relationship. The effects of U.S. institutional structure are analyzed and contrasted with European alternatives. An underlying theme is the implication of the evolving representational relationship for governing and public policy making.

title: Congress and Representative Government
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the behavior of members of Congress and the expectations of American citizens in order to gain an understanding of the contemporary representational relationship. The effects of U.S. institutional structure are analyzed and contrasted with European alternatives. An underlying theme will be the implications of the evolving representational relationship for governing and public policy making.

title: Congress and Representative Government
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the behavior of members of Congress and the expectations of American citizens in order to gain an understanding of the contemporary representational relationship. The effects of U.S. institutional structure are analyzed and contrasted with European alternatives. An underlying theme is the implication of the evolving representational relationship for governing and public policy making. Government 30 or equivalent.

title: Mexico: Problems and Prospects for Development and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course would assess recent problems, policies and decisions in Mexico as a way to discuss the concepts of state capacity, leadership and democratic governance. The first two sections will discuss such concepts, some general Latin American patterns and recent Mexican history. A third section will discuss the administrations of Zedillo and Fox. A fourth one will deal with the current administration of Calderon, review the original theoretical discussion and discuss some possible national scenarios.

title: Mexico: Problems and Prospects for Development and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course would assess recent problems, policies and decisions in Mexico as a way to discuss the concepts of state capacity, leadership and democratic governance. The first two sections will discuss such concepts, some general Latin American patterns and recent Mexican history. A third section will discuss the administrations of Zedillo and Fox. A fourth one will deal with the current administration of Calderon, review the original theoretical discussion and discuss some possible national scenarios.

title: Poverty and American Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews the evolution of antipoverty policies in the U.S., beginning with the New Deal. The first half of the course focuses on the politics of policy formation: why have certain programs (and not others) been adopted, and what does this historical record reveal about the nature of American politics? The second half is an exercise in policy analysis: how can American government best respond to the problem of poverty? Materials covered in the first half are used to stress that effective policy analysis requires attention to the problem of political feasibility.

title: The Problem of Socrates
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What is political philosophy as it was originated by Socrates, and what is its relation to political life? We study Plato's portrayal of Socrates in such dialogues as Gorgias, Symposium, and Euthyphro, as well as modern challenges to political philosophy by critics of Socrates such Hegel, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche.

title: Politics and Markets in Modern Capitalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration, through reading and discussion of classic works and contemporary analyses, of the relationship between representative democracy and markets in modern capitalist society. Readings include works by Adam Smith, Karl Marx, Max Weber, Joseph Schumpeter, Karl Polanyi, Albert Hirschman, Charles Lindblom, and Fred Hirsch. The last third of the course focuses on the effects of the internationalization of world markets on domestic politics in the 1990s.

title: The Problem of Socrates
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What is political philosophy as it was originated by Socrates, and what is its relation to political life? We study Plato's portrayal of Socrates in such dialogues as Gorgias, Symposium, and Euthyphro, as well as modern challenges to political philosophy by critics of Socrates such Hegel, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche.

title: Elections and Party Politics in Western Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the comparative study of voting and political parties in Western Europe. Examines the historical development of European party systems, as well as the dynamics of party competition, voting behavior, and internal party politics. Sociological, institutional, and rational choice theories of change and stability are critically examined against the comparative evidence. Concludes by asking whether party government makes a difference for public policy.

title: Topics in Law and Political Theory: The Jury and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores issues that lie at the intersection of law and political theory such as: what it means to call the jury a "representative" body? Do jurors divide along racial, gender, and ethnic lines? Are ordinary persons competent to do justice? Should jurors be permitted to disregard the law in order to render "verdicts according to conscience?" Other topics to be covered include civil disobedience, law versus justice, and the ethics of the adversary system.

title: Topics in Law and Political Theory: The Jury and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores issues that lie at the intersection of law and political theory such as: what it means to call the jury a "representative" body? Do jurors divide along racial, gender, and ethnic lines? Are ordinary persons competent to do justice? Should jurors be permitted to disregard the law in order to render "verdicts according to conscience?" Other topics to be covered include civil disobedience, law versus justice, and the ethics of the adversary system.

title: Topics in Contemporary Liberalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the foundations of contemporary liberalism. Focuses on key concepts associated with it: autonomy, justice, self-ownership, rights, neutrality, equality, etc. Discusses how feminist critiques, and issues such as cultural rights, and secession fit into the liberal framework. Readings include Rawls, Raz, Dworkin, Iris Young, Kymlicka, Tamir, Larmore, Connolly.

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the political philosophy of Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville with particular attention to their views of liberty and equality, history and human nature, the advantages and characteristic dangers of modern democratic politics, and the relationship between political institutions and their extrapolitical supports_all with an eye to the implications for contemporary liberal democracy.

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relationship between liberalism and democracy through the political writings of three thinkers who regarded modern liberalism to be in some measure at odds with the tenets and practices of democracy. We consider the meaning, foundations, purposes, and practices of both liberalism and democracy, examine the relationship between them, assess the merits and the dangers of each, and reflect on the nature of their union in contemporary American public life.

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relationship between liberalism and democracy through the political writings of three thinkers who regarded modern liberalism to be in some measure at odds with the tenets and practices of democracy. We consider the meaning, foundations, purposes, and practices of both liberalism and democracy, examine the relationship between them, assess the merits and the dangers of each, and reflect on the nature of their union in contemporary American public life.

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relationship between liberalism and democracy through the political writings of three thinkers who regarded modern liberalism to be in some measure at odds with the tenets and practices of democracy. We consider the meaning, foundations, purposes, and practices of both liberalism and democracy, examine the relationship between them, assess the merits and the dangers of each, and reflect on the nature of their union in contemporary American public life.

title: Liberalism and Democracy in Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the regimes of liberalism and democracy through the writings of three thinkers who regarded the tenets and practices associated with modern liberalism to be in some measure at odds with the tenets and practices of democracy. Montesquieu was a liberal suspicious of democracy; Rousseau was a democrat scornful of key features of liberalism; and Tocqueville, committed to both, sought to reconcile them even as he articulated the fragility of such a reconciliation. We investigate the relationship between liberalism and democracy, assess the merits and dangers of both, and consider the nature of their union in contemporary American public life. Readings drawn from major works of Montesquieu, Rousseau, and Tocqueville.

title: Democracy and Dictatorship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines different approaches to explaining why some countries develop and maintain democratic political institutions, and others do not. To what extent must certain social "preconditions" be met before democracy can succeed, and to what extent is the establishment and maintenance of democracy an act of will, of political creation? Do national cultures matter for the success of democracy? What are the actual conditions under which democratic institutions have come into being, and why have they then endured or failed?

title: Democracy and Dictatorship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines different approaches to explaining why some countries develop and maintain democratic political institutions, and others do not. To what extent must certain social ^'^'preconditions'' be met before democracy can succeed, and to what extent is the establishment and maintenance of democracy an act of will, of political creation? Do national cultures matter for the success of democracy? What are the actual conditions under which democratic institutions have come into being, and why have they then endured or failed?

title: Athenian Democracy and its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the ancient Athenian experience of democracy through the writings of some of its staunchest supporters and fiercest critics. Topics covered include Athenian democratic ideals in theory and practice; the relationship between democracy and tyranny; Athenian democracy and imperialism; and the role of rhetoric in democracy. Readings include Athenian historians, philosophers, dramatists, and rhetoricians, as well as modern scholars.

title: Athenian Democracy and its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course investigates the ancient Athenian experience of democracy through the writings of some of its staunchest supporters and fiercest critics. Topics covered include Athenian democratic ideals in theory and practice; the relationship between democracy and tyranny; Athenian democracy and imperialism; and the role of rhetoric in democracy. Readings include Athenian historians, philosophers, dramatists, and rhetoricians, as well as modern scholars.

title: Competing Classics: Great Works in Comparative Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines competing explanatory frameworks in comparative politics through a close reading of works that privilege different causal factors. Factors considered include: culture, institutions, class conflict, and ^'^'great men.'' Substantive puzzles include the rise of fascism in Germany and the persistence of democracy in India.

title: Racial and Ethnic Politics in the US
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is a seminar on racial and ethnic politics in the US, focusing primarily on African Americans, Latinos, Asian Americans, and Caucasians. It is designed to explore conceptual and methodological issues, while focusing on how racial and ethnic groups shape and are shaped by the American political system. Among the topics to be covered include the meaning of race and ethnicity, the history of racial and immigration politics, prejudice, group participation, and mobilization, political representation, and public opinion.

title: Ethics and International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar explores normative approaches to international relations. Topics include liberalism, realism, nationalism, cosmopolitanism, utilitarianism, feminism, Marxism, postmodernism, and multiculturalism.

title: Ethics and International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar explores normative approaches to international relations. Topics include liberalism, realism, nationalism, cosmopolitanism, utilitarianism, feminism, Marxism, postmodernism, and multiculturalism.

title: Classical Theories of International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The theoretical underpinning of International Relations is a historical construct made up of philosophical parts. Ignorance of this past dooms the theorist to re-inventing the wheel. The course will highlight the roots of such key principles as liberal universalism (including the belief that free trade makes for peace and democracies do not fight one another), the notions of Reasons of State and Realpolitik, the concept of the Balance of Power and more. We will then proceed to place current theorists in their historical and philosophical contexts. Thinkers addressed include Aquinas, Machiavelli, Guicciadini, Botero, Grotius, Hobbes, Kant, Bolingbroke, and, latterly, Carr, Spykman, Morgenthau, Tucker, Hoffmann, Waltz, Keohane, and others.

title: Classical Theories of International Relations

title: Election Polling and Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Political polls and other survey methodologies are frequently used to understand and explain both voter intentions and public opinion. This course will examine the theoretical and practical issues involved in using polls and surveys. We will explore the normative assumptions involved in polling, study possible sources of error in survey measures, and discuss the prospective implications of polling for policy and governance.

title: Election Polling and Public Opinion

This course will examine the theoretical and practical issues involved in using polls and surveys. We will explore the normative assumptions involved in polling, study possible sources of error in survey measures, and discuss the prospective implications of polling for policy and governance.

title: U.S. Electoral Behavior and Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the ways in which individual Americans form opinions about political issues and actors and express their opinions through voting. Examines the foundations of public opinion and political orientation, factors that affect the decision to vote, determinants of the choices that voters make, and the interpretation of electoral outcomes.

title: U.S. Electoral Behavior and Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to theoretical/empirical studies of American elections, political participation, voter decisions, candidate evaluations, and mass political attitudes.

title: American Political Development: Politics of Taxation and Entitlements, 1933-1995
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the politics of Social Security and related entitlement programs and struggles over tax policy and the deficit. Emphasis on the policy innovations of the Roosevelt regime (1930's) and the Reagan regime (1980's).

title: American Political Development: New Deal Politics Meets Deficit Reduction and Resurgent GOP
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Selected readings on establishment of New Deal programs and post-war pattern of Keynesian synthesis; OPEC disruptions and tax revolts; supply-side tax cuts and entitlement programs in age of deficits; role of the South and of public opinion; Contract with America.

title: American Political Development: Realignment, Policy Change, and State Development
subject: GOV

title: American Political Development: Realignment, Policy Change, and State Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Process of American political development viewed from rival perspectives of party realignment and of state-building.

title: North-South Relations
subject: GOV

title: 19th-Century Political Philosophy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the main currents in political philosophy flowing out of the tradition of German Idealism. Focus on the writings of Kant, Hegel, and Marx, with lesser attention to Goethe, Kierkegaard, and Nietzsche. Discusses such topics as the foundations of moral autonomy, philosophical status of law and the rights of man, the form of the rational state, the notion of historical progress, the economic analysis of capitalism, and the revolt against politics in the name of the individual.

title: Inequality and American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The ``rights revolutions'' of the 1960s and 1970s removed barriers to full citizenship for African Americans, women, and other formerly marginalized groups. But inequalities of wealth and income have grown since the 1970s. How do changing social and economic inequalities influence American democracy? This seminar explores empirical research and normative debates about political participation, about government responsiveness to citizen preferences, and about the impact of public policies on social opportunity and citizen participation.

title: Inequality and American Democracy
subject: GOV

But inequalities of wealth and income have grown since the 1970s. How do changing social and economic inequalities influence American democracy? This seminar explores empirical research and normative debates about political participation, about government responsiveness to citizen preferences, and about the impact of public policies on social opportunity and citizen participation.

title: Inequality and American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The ``rights revolutions'' of the 1960s and 1970s removed barriers to full citizenship for African Americans, women, and other formerly marginalized groups. But inequalities of wealth and income have grown since the 1970s. How do changing social and economic inequalities influence American democracy? This seminar explores empirical research and normative debates about political participation, about government responsiveness to citizen preferences, and about the impact of public policies on social opportunity and citizen participation.

title: The Politics of Inequality
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines why some countries exhibit high and increasing inequality in terms of income and poverty, while other countries are characterized by high and growing unemployment and labor market exclusion. To what extent can these cross-national differences be explained by the organization of labor markets, welfare state institutions, competition from low-wage countries, the rise of low-skilled services jobs, or deliberate public policies? What are the trade-offs that governments face in seeking to reduce any particular form of inequality? In seeking answers to these questions, we will compare the experiences of countries in western Europe and north America.

title: The Politics of Inequality

title: Race and Ethnic Conflict in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines historical and contemporary cases of overt intergroup conflict (i.e. protest and riots) in order to understand the nation's tradition of contentious race and ethnic relations. The main thrust will be to investigate the role of political institutions in shaping and mediating conflict.

title: Race and Ethnic Conflict in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines historical and contemporary cases of overt intergroup conflict (i.e. protest and riots) in order to understand the nation's tradition of contentious race and ethnic relations. The main thrust will be to investigate the role of political institutions in shaping and mediating conflict.

title: Law and Politics in Multicultural Democracies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of law in the governance of cultural diversity drawing on examples from the USA, Western Europe, India and Israel. Central themes at the intersection of law and politics will be explored, including: the impact of courts on rights protections, law's function as a venue of conflict resolution, and courts' relationship with other political institutions. Specific attention will be given to contemporary controversies such as Islamic veiling, abortion and same sex marriage.

title: China and the International System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys the rise of China as a major actor in the international system. Four sets of questions lie at the core of the seminar: (1) To what extent is China's diplomatic and strategic experience unique, or does it display features common to the experience of other countries? (2) What do general debates about international politics, economics, and security say about China, and what does China say about them? (3) How does China actually make its foreign policy, and are the individual personalities of its leaders, other domestic factors, or strategic concerns most important? (4) What challenges does China pose for the United States, and how might we handle key policy issues?

title: China and the International System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys the rise of China as a major actor in the international system. Four sets of questions lie at the core of the seminar: (1) To what extent is China's diplomatic and strategic experience unique, or does it display features common to the experience of other countries? (2) What do general debates about international politics, economics, and security say about China, and what does China say about them? (3) How does China actually make its foreign policy, and are the individual personalities of its leaders, other domestic factors, or strategic concerns most important? (4) What challenges does China pose for the United States, and how might we handle key policy issues?

title: Election Forecasting
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course evaluates different methodologies for forecasting democratic election results, including those of prognosticators, pundits, politicians, pollsters, modelers, marketers, and citizens. Special attention will be given to forecasting US presidential elections.

title: International Organization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the changing role of both political economy and security institutions in the international system. Discusses theory about the effect of international organizations on cooperation and governance. Then applies these theoretical tools to practical issues. Particular attention to international organizations and current topics such as human rights, security and economic cooperation. Analyzes present developments such as NATO enlargement, European integration, EU enlargement and UN reform.

title: International Organization

Discusses theory about the effect of international organizations on cooperation and governance. Then applies these theoretical tools to practical issues. title: Democracy, Interdependence, and Peace
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of whether the international system is changing fundamentally, with zones of peace among many countries, through forces of democratization, economic linkages, and international organizations. Consideration of how classical and contemporary theories of international relations may illuminate these questions and what the empirical evidence may be.

title: Democracy, Interdependence, and Peace
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examination of whether the international system is changing fundamentally, with zones of peace among many countries, through forces of democratization, economic linkages, and international organizations. Consideration of how classical and contemporary theories of international relations may illuminate these questions and what the empirical evidence may be.

title: Black Political Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An intensive introduction to black political thought. Texts considered during the first part of the course are from key authors such as W. E. B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, Malcolm X, Martin Luther King, Jr., and Patricia Hill Collins. The second part of the course considers selected examples of how political discourse between blacks and whites has mutually shaped what is known as ``black'' political thought and ``American'' political thought.

title: The Politics of Culture in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the dynamic interplay between culture and politics in comparative perspective. Based on an understanding of culture as a realm of political conflict, explores themes including the state's organization of cultural life, the role of intellectuals in constructing a new "socialist culture,'' political ritual and the development of a "parallel'' culture expressed in fields such as literature and music (especially rock and roll). Readings include both Western studies of cultural processes and works produced by Soviet/ East European cultural figures.

title: The Politics of Culture in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the dynamic interplay between culture and politics in comparative perspective. Based on an understanding of culture as a realm of political conflict, explores themes including the state's organization of cultural life, the role of intellectuals in constructing a new "socialist'' culture, women and the gendering of social oppression, political ritual and political language, socialist realism and the development of a "parallel'' culture expressed in fields such as literature and music. Readings include both Western studies of cultural process and works produced by Soviet/ East European cultural figures.

title: Seminar on Mexican Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Mexico's post-Revolutionary political development and political economy. Central themes include construction of the post-Revolutionary presidentialist regime and its remarkable stability, state-led economic modernization, ruling party hegemony and political liberalization, economic crises and political instability, the rise of the technocrats, neoliberal market reforms, democratic transition, and Mexican-US relations. The seminar probes these issues using historical, contemporary, and theoretical literature, toward the goal of explaining political and economic outcomes.

title: Seminar on Mexican Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Mexico's post-Revolutionary political development and political economy. Central themes include construction of the post-Revolutionary presidentialist regime and its remarkable stability, state-led economic modernization, ruling party hegemony and political liberalization, economic crises and political instability, the rise of the technocrats, neoliberal market reforms, democratic transition, and Mexican-US relations. The seminar probes these issues using historical, contemporary, and theoretical literature, toward the goal of explaining political and economic outcomes.

title: Rights, Natural Law, and Their Discontents
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: We will consider and contextualize seventeenth-century natural law theories (including works by Grotius, Pufendorf, Locke and Hobbes) and then eighteenth- century philosophers (Hutcheson, Hume, Bentham) who expanded and criticized these theories to accommodate new political and social situations: animal rights, race and abolition, and women's rights. We will conclude by reading post-French Revolution rights critics: Wollstonecraft on the rights of man, Godwin's attacks on marriage and property, and Oswald's call for animal revolution.

title: Rights, Natural Law, and Their Discontents
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: We will consider and contextualize seventeenth-century natural law theories (including works by Grotius, Pufendorf, Locke and Hobbes) and then eighteenth- century philosophers (Hutcheson, Hume, Bentham) who expanded and criticized these theories to accommodate new political and social situations: animal rights, race and abolition, and women's rights. We will conclude by reading post-French Revolution rights critics: Wollstonecraft on the rights of man, Godwin's attacks on marriage and property, and Oswald's call for animal revolution.

title: Political Philosophy, Theory, and International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A discussion of the main political philosophies of International Relations: realism, liberalism, Marxism; of contemporary theoretical approaches derived from them: neo-realism, institutional neo-liberalism, dependency theories; and of moral philosophies - from communitarianism to cosmopolitanism - applied to such issues as human rights, self-determination, migrations, and distributive justice.

title: Electoral Politics in America and Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of elections in the US and Japan that explores their similarities and differences in a broader comparative perspective. Much is paid to the effects of electoral laws on candidates, parties, and voters. Other topics include party systems, incumbency, strategic voting, and corruption.

Much attention will be paid to the effects of electoral laws on candidates, parties, and voters. Other topics include party systems, incumbency, strategic voting, and corruption.
