subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of elections in the US and Japan that explores their similarities and differences in a broader comparative perspective. Much is paid to the effects of electoral laws on candidates, parties, and voters. Other topics include party systems, incumbency, strategic voting, and corruption.

title: Electoral Politics in America and Japan
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of elections in the US and Japan that explores their similarities and differences in a broader comparative perspective. Much is paid to the effects of electoral laws on candidates, parties, and voters. Other topics include party systems, incumbency, strategic voting, and corruption.

title: Hobbes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the philosophy of Thomas Hobbes. The course will move chronologically through his works, paying particular attention to the three major iterations of his political theory (The Elements of Law, De Cive, and Leviathan). Themes to be discussed include: Hobbes on sovereignty, representation, property, religion, humanism, and international relations.

title: Hobbes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the philosophy of Thomas Hobbes. The course will move chronologically through his works, paying particular attention to the three major iterations of his political theory (The Elements of Law, De Cive, and Leviathan). Themes to be discussed include: Hobbes on sovereignty, representation, property, religion, humanism, and international relations.

title: Comparative Study of Civil-Military Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of the military in politics. Among the topics covered are the nature and extent of civilian control; the causes and consequences of military coups and governments; the military's role in democratic transitions, strategic doctrine and innovation, and militarist aggression. To develop a comparative understanding of civil-military relations, the course will also draw on the experiences of a range of countries including Argentina, Indonesia, Japan, the Soviet Union, and the United States.

title: Comparative Study of Civil-Military Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of the military in politics. Among the topics covered are the nature and extent of civilian control; the causes and consequences of military coups and governments; the military's role in democratic transitions, strategic doctrine and innovation, and militarist aggression. To develop a comparative understanding of civil-military relations, the course will also draw on the experiences of a range of countries including Argentina, Indonesia, Japan, the Soviet Union, and the United States.

title: The Chinese Revolution in Comparative Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The course will cover general theories of revolutionary change as well as specific studies of revolutionary movements in China, from the 19th century Taiping rebels to the present. We will examine the causes and consequences of these movements for Chinese politics, and consider their similarities and differences to revolutionary uprisings elswhere around the world. Preference given to Government concentrators.

title: The Police State: Power, Politics, and Authority
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines what can be characterized as `police state policies.' We will develop an analytical framework for understanding why different regime types adopt such policies, the international and domestic limitations to their adoption, and how these policies spread globally. Three categories of police state policies will be considered: detention regimes; enhanced interrogation techniques; responses to protest and insurgency. The final two weeks will consist of in-depth case studies of the U.S. and Iran.

title: The Police State: Power, Politics, and Authority

title: Democracy and Authoritarianism in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the origins of democratic and authoritarian rule in Latin America with an emphasis on Mexico, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Brazil, and Chile. Critically examines the role of leadership, institutions, culture, popular movements, and political economy in explaining the developments, consolidation, and breakdown of democratic and authoritarian regimes.

title: German Unification
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the process of German unification. Topics include: the postwar division of Germany; Ostpolitik and detente; the collapse of the communist regime in East Germany; current problems of social, economic, and political integration; national identity.

title: Contemporary Ethnic Politics in the USSR
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an opportunity for in-depth comparative analysis of contemporary ethnic conflicts in the Soviet Union. Various theoretical approaches to the study of nationalism and ethnic politics serve to orient analysis of the development of Soviet ethnic institutions and political practices. Emphasis placed on the use of Soviet sources (in translation) as a basis for student research projects.

title: US - Latin American Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of political and economic relations between the United States and Latin American countries, and of the international relations of Latin America since 1945. Attention also given to foreign policy decision making in the United States and Latin America, and to alternative approaches to the study of international relations and foreign policy.

title: Community in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Has the social fabric of America's communities and the civic engagement of its citizens changed over the last generation? Why? Does it matter? What lessons might we find in American history? These questions are at the focus of this seminar.

title: International Human Rights and International Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores the political conditions_international and domestic_that influence the creation, acceptance, operation, and effectiveness of the international rules governing individual human rights. The course addresses international human rights law and practice in theoretical terms; considers social science methodologies for studying human rights law and practice; and examines in detail the international human rights regime itself. Four meetings are reserved to allow for individual and small group presentation of research projects and findings. Preference given to students who have completed Government 1740.

title: The National Socialist Regime in Germany
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the origins and nature of the Nazi regime. Topics include German anti-Semitism, the character of the Weimar democracy, the roots of Hitler's appeal and competing explanations of the Holocaust. Readings include recent works by Kershaw, Klemperer, Browning and Goldhagen.

title: The National Socialist Regime in Germany

title: Nationbuilding and Nationalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the process of nationbuilding and the origins of nationalism with special reference to 19th- and 20th-century Europe. Considers competing explanations for the divergent paths followed by France, Germany and Britain as well as for the ongoing conflict in the Balkans. Readings include works by Anderson, Gellner, Brubaker and Haas.

title: Nationbuilding and Nationalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the process of nationbuilding and the origins of nationalism with special reference to 19th- and 20th-century Europe. Considers competing explanations for the divergent paths followed by France, Germany and Britain as well as for the ongoing conflict in the Balkans. Readings include works by Anderson, Gellner, Brubaker and Haas.

title: Nationbuilding and Nationalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the process of nationbuilding and the origins of nationalism with special reference to 19th- and 20th-century Europe. Considers competing explanations for the divergent paths followed by France, Germany and Britain as well as for the ongoing conflict in the Balkans. Readings include works by Anderson, Gellner, Brubaker and Haas.

title: Liberalism, Communitarians and Federalism: the Politics of Constitutional Design
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The courses analyses the origin of federalism, its different articulations (republic, communitarian, liberal) in the US and Europe. The concepts of sovereignty and subsidiarity are discussed as well as the implications for fiscal federalism. Finally, lessons for the European Union and its constitution are drawn.

title: International Law: Theory and Research
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Addresses advanced issues on the links between international law and international politics. Focus is on theories of international law creation and diffusion, theories of commitment (international law's signaling role) and theories of compliance. Empirical literature includes case studies and quantitative studies in a range of issue areas. Research design and methods are stressed. Grades are based on participation and an individual research paper. Gov 1740

title: Liberalism, Communitarians and Federalism: the Politics of Constitutional Design
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The courses analyses the origin of federalism, its different articulations (republic, communitarian, liberal) in the US and Europe. The concepts of sovereignty and subsidiarity are discussed as well as the implications for fiscal federalism. Finally, lessons for the European Union and its constitution are drawn.

title: Theories of Peace and War in Western Political Thought: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines arguments for war and arguments for peace in western political thought. Related topics, such as just war theory, collective security, and religious pacifism, will be treated as well. Readings will include Augustine, Grotius, Kant, and Carl Schmitt.

title: Theories of Peace and War in Western Political Thought: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines arguments for war and arguments for peace in western political thought. Related topics, such as just war theory, collective security, and religious pacifism, will be treated as well. Readings will include Augustine, Grotius, Kant, and Carl Schmitt.

title: International Relations Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Critical evaluation of modern theories of international relations, with an emphasis on the consistency and logic of theoretical argument as well as the relevance of evidence brought to bear on the question at hand. Subject matter covers, in part, systemic theories, conflict and cooperation, international institutions, domestic institutions and foreign policy, and individual decision processes, with applications in international security, international political economy, and human rights.

title: Democracy and the Information Technology Revolution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The revolution in information technologies has serious implications for democratic societies. We examine which populations have the most access to technology-based information sources, and how identities are being forged online. Severe tension between national security and individual privacy rights in the U.S will be explored. Attention will also be paid to examining the relationship between the IT revolution and changing understandings of property rights. We analyze both works on the IT revolution as well the work of democratic theorists.

title: Women and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An analysis of liberal, conservative, socialist, and feminist theories about the modern state and policies concerning women. Emphasizes comparisons between the United States and Europe.

We analyze both works on the IT revolution as well the work of democratic theorists.

title: New Social Movements and Political Power in Western and Eastern Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews competing theoretical approaches to studying contemporary social movements. Through selected case studies examines the character of new social movements, their impact on traditional political institutions, repertoires of collective action, patterns of political conflict, and changing relations between the state and civil society in Europe.

title: New Social Movements and Political Power in Western and Eastern Europe
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews competing theoretical approaches to studying contemporary social movements. Through selected case studies examines the character of new social movements, their impact on traditional political institutions, repertoires of collective action, patterns of political conflict, and changing relations between the state and civil society in Europe.

title: Law and Society: Classic Debates: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The general purpose of the course is to show that the history of jurisprudence and political theory cannot be separated from their social contexts but that these disciplines evolved as part of a broader discussion on law and society. We will read and discuss texts by Marx, Bentham, Weber, Habermas, Luhmann and Hart but also have a look at a number of contemporary cases.

title: Law and Society: Classic Debates: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The general purpose of the course is to show that the history of jurisprudence and political theory cannot be separated from their social contexts but that these disciplines evolved as part of a broader discussion on law and society. We will read and discuss texts by Marx, Bentham, Weber, Habermas, Luhmann and Hart but also have a look at a number of contemporary cases.

title: Foreign Policy and the New World Order
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines many of the various issues in U.S. foreign policy since the end of the Cold War. In seminar discussions and in writing assignments, students will analyze the determinants of foreign policy in the 1990s and articulate policy prescriptions.

title: Foreign Policy and the New World Order
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines many of the various issues in U.S. foreign policy since the end of the Cold War. In seminar discussions and in writing assignments, students will analyze the determinants of foreign policy in the 1990s and articulate policy prescriptions.

title: Foreign Policy and the New World Order
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar examines many of the various issues in U.S. foreign policy since the end of the Cold War. In seminar discussions and in writing assignments, students will analyze the determinants of foreign policy in the 1990s and articulate policy prescriptions.

title: Comparative Constitutional Engineering
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course critically examines when, and how, institutional design affects the performance and stability of democracy. Topics include the manipulation of party systems via electoral systems; incentive structures in the presidential, parliamentary, and semi-presidential constitutional types: the ``problems'' of divided government, minority government and divided minority government; the increasingly important role of constitutional courts; and the challenge of engineering in deeply divided societies. Examples are drawn from a variety of world regions and historical periods.

title: Economics and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: General topics include economic conditions and election outcomes; the political business cycle; economic development and democratic performance; the political impact of globalization; the political economy of third-party dissent; economic and public policy issues.

title: Economics and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: General topics include economic conditions and election outcomes; the political business cycle; economic development and democratic performance; the political impact of globalization; the political economy of third-party dissent; economic and public policy issues.

title: The Political Economy of Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examining the origins of law and courts, and their effects on politics and society, this seminar introduces students to the political economy of law. It explores strategic choice and collective action in the formation, deformation, and transformation of legal norms and institutions, with particular reference to nineteenth and twentieth century Africa. By analyzing the logic of law and the forces that shape it, the seminar debates law's promise-its real and imagined place in society.

title: The Political Economy of Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examining the origins of law and courts, and their effects on politics and society, this seminar introduces students to the political economy of law. It explores strategic choice and collective action in the formation, deformation, and transformation of legal norms and institutions, with particular reference to nineteenth and twentieth century Africa. By analyzing the logic of law and the forces that shape it, the seminar debates law's promise-its real and imagined place in society.

title: Social Justice and the Varieties of Capitalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is both normative and empirical. It examines normative arguments for social justice and the institutional implications of those arguments.

title: Social Justice and the Varieties of Capitalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course is both normative and empirical. It examines normative arguments for social justice and the institutional implications of those arguments.

title: Culture and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the increasingly emphasized role of culture in domestic and international politics. Among the topics covered are: the meanings and usefulness of the concept of culture in the social sciences; the extent to which a global culture is emerging; ethnicity, nationalism, and ethnic conflict; strategic culture, foreign policy, and military effectiveness; the role of religion in world politics; the impact of culture on political and economic development; "the clash of civilizations" in the post-Cold War world; and the rise of multiculturalism in the United States.

title: Topics in Russian Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will consider different ways of conceptualizing the economy and economic change in contemporary Russia. Students will be exposed to the central theoretical traditions in political economy and economic sociology. Theoretical literature will be complemented by an empirical examination of the transformation of the Russian economy since 1991.

title: Topics in Russian Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will consider different ways of conceptualizing the economy and economic change in contemporary Russia. Students will be exposed to the central theoretical traditions in political economy and economic sociology. Theoretical literature will be complemented by an empirical examination of the transformation of the Russian economy since 1991.

title: Topics in Agent-Based Modeling
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An agent-based model is a tool used by social scientists to study how large-scale social dynamics result from micro-level individual behavior. This course provides an introduction to the use of computational agent-based modeling and its application to political science. Class time will consist of discussions, student presentations of work-in-progress, and the hands-on programming of the student's own model. While no prior programming experience is necessary, students should arrive enthusiastic about learning to program.

title: Topics in Agent-Based Modeling
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An agent-based model is a tool used by social scientists to study how large-scale social dynamics result from micro-level individual behavior. This course provides an introduction to the use of computational agent-based modeling and its application to political science. Class time will consist of discussions, student presentations of work-in-progress, and the hands-on programming of the student's own model. While no prior programming experience is necessary, students should arrive enthusiastic about learning to program.

title: Southeast Asia in World Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An analysis of how various Southeast Asian states, especially ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations), have sought to provide for their security and prosperity in a turbulent world. The approach is explicitly comparative, with special emphasis on the interaction between economic and security concerns.

title: Ethics and Biotechnology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar will explore the moral and political implications of recent advances in biotechnology. Topics to include cloning, stem cell research, genetic engineering, eugenics, and the patenting of life forms. A previous course in moral reasoning or political theory is recommended but not required.

title: The Future of War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Topics: the function of war in the traditional international system and today; the devaluation of military force; democracy and deterrence. Addresses the question: Has war become obsolete and are we approaching a "paradigm change'' in international relations?

title: Ethics and Biotechnology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar explores the moral and political implications of recent advances in biotechnology. Topics include cloning, stem cell research, genetic engineering, eugenics, and the patenting of life forms. A previous course in moral reasoning or political theory recommended.

title: The Wealth of Nations: Adam Smith in Enlightenment Context
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What was Adam Smith's own political and moral theory as opposed to the ones associated with his name today? Was he a liberal, a libertarian or a conservative? A critic or defender of modernity? A visionary market theorist or a timid and piecemeal reformer? The seminar examines the complex structure of the most celebrated foundational text of economics in the context of what Albert Hirschman famously called ^'^'political arguments for capitalism before its triumph.'' Topics will include Smith's advocacy of mass production, his four stages theory of history, his explanation of the origins of modern liberal Europe, his theory of moral sentiments, his relationship to fellow thinkers in the Scottish Enlightenment and his controversy with Jean-Jacques Rousseau and the French Physiocrats.

title: Political and Social Movements in the Modern Middle East
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The Middle East has witnessed significant socio-cultural, political, and economic transformations in recent decades. This seminar will explore the role of both state and non-state actors in these processes. In the face of globalization, liberalization, democratization, conflicts, and regional instability, what social movements have emerged and in what specific contexts? Additionally, how have civil society, the mass media, global discourses, and Islamist institutions and ideologies shaped the contemporary reality? What are the prospects for peace, prosperity, and pluralism in the region? These are central questions we will attempt to address in this course.

title: Political and Social Movements in the Modern Middle East

title: Public Law and American Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Public law structures the institutions of American democracy, while also providing a terrain in which substantive debates over policy-from civil rights to economic regulation-play out in democratic politics. The class explores major topics in public law, focusing on this dual role of law as a creator of institutions, and as a catalyst for moral and political debate. The seminar also highlights different approaches to the study of public law: historical, institutional, and normative.

title: Strategic Behavior of Tyrants
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will explore the literature from political theory and political psychology in order to identify what may be recurring issues involving tyrannies and war, strategic communication, and deterrence.

title: Public Law and American Democracy
subject: GOV

The class explores major topics in public law, focusing on this dual role of law as a creator of institutions, and as a catalyst for moral and political debate. The seminar also highlights different approaches to the study of public law: historical, institutional, and normative.

title: Enlightenment and Its Critics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will trace the vicissitudes of Enlightenment ideals of reason, critique, and autonomy in the 19th and 20th centuries. It will examine the ways in which the arguments of the Enlightenment's contemporaries (including Hamann, Burke, and Hegel) have been taken up by such 20th-century thinkers such as Max Horkheimer, Theodor Adorno, Hans-Georg Gadamer, and Michel Foucault.

title: Enlightenment and Its Critics

title: Domestic Politics and the Use of Force
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the domestic politics of international engagement. Examines how legislatures, courts, and public opinion define the range of options available to the executives who coordinate a military response or otherwise to perceived foreign crises. Also considers whether different kinds of crises are more or less likely to attract the attention of the federal government. While many readings focus on US foreign policymaking, connections are made to other systems of government.

title: Why Americans Love God and Europeans Don't
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The United States is one of the most religious countries in the developed world. Why? What explains the growing religious divide between the United States and Western Europe? What are the implications of American religiosity for US Constitutional Law, US presidential politics, and transatlantic relations? Readings include: David Hume, Adam Smith, Max Weber, Emile Durkheim, and Friedrich Nietzsche. This course requires a rudimentary knowledge of statistics.

title: The Future of War
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What, if any, are the possible causes and characters of the wars that might occur over the next 20 years that could affect the interests of the United States? Topics include the U.S. domestic political context and its impact on the U.S. conduct of war; cultural, resource, and demographic problems that may be the cause of wars; the problem of regional nuclear wars; possible wars involving great powers in Asia; the spread of low-intensity wars; and the revolution in warfare involving new technologies. Emphasis given to developing the research skills necessary for the rigorous treatment of national security policy questions.

title: The Politics of International Monetary Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the political issues surrounding international monetary relations from the 19th century to the present. Subjects include the gold standard, the Bretton Woods system, floating exchange rates, international debt, the EMS, and future international monetary prospects.

title: The Politics of International Monetary Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the political issues surrounding international monetary relations from the 19th century to the present. Subjects include the gold standard, the Bretton Woods system, floating exchange rates, international debt, the EMS, and future international monetary prospects.

title: Politics and Nationality in the Soviet Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the institutional origins and historical development of ethnic politics in the Soviet Union. Provides a theoretical and practical overview of the relation between nationality and state formation in the Soviet federal system. From this perspective, turns to the varieties of historical developments in the country's most important cultural-geographic regions, including Russia, Ukraine, the Baltics, Transcaucasia, and Central Asia.

title: Canadian Political Leadership
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Canada is alone in having wedded a variant of the national convention of American parties to a parliamentary system, based on the British model. The impact that this unique system of choosing leaders has had on Canada's parties, parliament, representative system, political recruitment, and authority patterns is examined. As appropriate, British and American experience with leadership selection is analyzed.

title: Topics in Elections and Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A detailed examination of the electoral arena during the Reagan era. Attention to campaigns, the media, public opinion, and voting behavior. Some original analysis required. In the event of an oversubscription, preference given to students who have taken Government 1000 or equivalent.

title: Elections and Public Opinion
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A detailed examination of the contemporary electoral arena. Attention to campaigns, the media, public opinion, and voting behavior. Some original analysis required. title: U.S. Political Parties
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the nature of party politics in the United States and its significance for American democracy. Central issues include: what parties are; how they have emerged; how the rules of the game and the distribution of power in society affect the number of parties and the types of policies they propose; and the relative influence of voters, activists, interest groups, the media and money.

title: Parties and Party Coalitions
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to formal models of the process of party formation, competition between parties, the role parties play in legislatures and the process of coalition bargaining between them, with examples from the US, Europe, and elsewhere.

subject: GOV

title: Comparative Leadership Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Do political leaders make a difference? Under what conditions do they matter more or less? How are leaders and leadership qualities formed? The course considers these questions, as played out in a variety of societies and political regimes.

title: Positive Theories of International Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the principle sourses of order and cooperation in world politics, including the perspectives of neorealism, liberal institutionalism, and constructivism. Sources analyzed include individual leadership, democratic and democratizing politics, bargaining and negotiation, major powers, international law and organization, and the structure of the international system.

title: American Political Ideologies
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the development and change of American political ideologies, starting with the Puritans and considering the Revolution and constitution-writing, Jacksonian democracy, the Gilded Age, gender-based and race-based social movements, Progressivism, and contemporary liberal and conservative ideologies.

title: American Political Ideologies
subject: GOV

title: Adorno
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Theodor Adorno (1903-1969) was a thinker of extraordinary breadth: at once a philosopher, social theorist, musicologist and critic. His writing is dense, complex and allusive. The aim of this course is to take some of Adorno's best-known writings and to see them as part of the thinking of someone who, however much he moved from field to field, had a consistent underlying vision of politics, art and society.

title: Tocqueville: Political History and Political Philosophy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Tocqueville was a profound political thinker but only ambiguously a political philosopher. Through an analysis of his major writings, this course will explore Tocqueville's decidedly "historical" approach to political theorizing. The course will examine Tocqueville's understanding of democracy, his comparative analysis of English, the American, and French political life, as well as his political and literary efforts on behalf of " liberty and dignity" of human beings. Tocqueville's relevance for contemporary political analysis will also be explored.

title: Tocqueville: Political History and Political Philosophy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Tocqueville was a profound political thinker but only ambiguously a political philosopher. Through an analysis of his major writings, this course will explore Tocqueville's decidedly "historical" approach to political theorizing. The course will examine Tocqueville's understanding of democracy, his comparative analysis of English, the American, and French political life, as well as his political and literary efforts on behalf of " liberty and dignity" of human beings. Tocqueville's relevance for contemporary political analysis will also be explored.

title: International Justice and War Crimes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the politics and ethics of the laws of war. What are war crimes and crimes against humanity, and is war itself a crime? Do states have the right to punish war criminals, and what makes such efforts succeed or fail? What are the moral and legal responsibilities of leaders and followers? Considers Nuremberg and other cases from World War I, World War II, the Cold War era, and ex-Yugoslavia.

title: International Justice and War Crimes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the politics and ethics of the laws of war. What are war crimes and crimes against humanity, and is war itself a crime? Do states have the right to punish war criminals, and what makes such efforts succeed or fail? What are the moral and legal responsibilities of leaders and followers? Considers Nuremberg and other cases from World War I, World War II, the Cold War era, and ex-Yugoslavia.

title: Constitutionalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This research and writing seminar explores the conceptual and political foundations of constitutionalism, and examines constitutional theory and practice in a variety of world regions. The focus will be on students' close reading of actual constitutional texts and judicial decisions, in both established and developing democracies.

title: Contemporary Arab Political and Social Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course focuses on the development of political and social thought in the Arab world since the end of the nineteenth century. It examines the various attempts at achieving reform or an "Arab awakening," and the social and political contexts that gave rise to several competing ideologies. Discussions will cover the Islamic ideology, early reform movements, intellectual encounters with the West, Islamic modernism, regional nationalism, Arab nationalism, radical ideologies, and Islamic revival.

title: Religion and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar introduces students to the major social science theories of religion. We look at the explanatory value of these theories for various aspects of politics: institutions and structures, political parties, civil society and social movements, conflict, and economic development. What effect does religion have on politics within and across societies? How effective are current theories in accounting for the interplay between religion and political life?

title: The Role of Religion in Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar introduces students to the major social scientific theories of religion. We look at the explanatory value of these theories for various aspects of politics: institutions and structures, political parties, civil society, conflict, and economic development. What effect does religion have on politics across societies? How effective are current theories in accounting for the interplay between religion and political life?

title: Nature, Virtue, and Happiness in Ancient Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The key concepts of ancient ethics include `nature,' `virtue,' and `happiness.' But what are the different ways in which Plato, Aristotle, and the Stoics put these concepts into relation? And how do they rely on these concepts in evaluating political arrangements? This course explores the ethical foundations of ancient political thought by situating our thinkers in debates of philosophical scholarship and also by examining contemporary thinking inspired by reflection on ancient ethics.

title: Nature, Virtue, and Happiness in Ancient Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The key concepts of ancient ethics include `nature,' `virtue,' and `happiness.' But what are the different ways in which Plato, Aristotle, and the Stoics put these concepts into relation? And how do they rely on these concepts in evaluating political arrangements? This course explores the ethical foundations of ancient political thought by situating our thinkers in debates of philosophical scholarship and also by examining contemporary thinking inspired by reflection on ancient ethics.

title: Foundations of Liberal Political Thought
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to some philosophical problems of liberal political thought. Not intended for political theorists alone, but rather to provide students of government generally with the opportunity to examine the underlying assumptions of some classic liberal texts. Explores such questions as: What is liberal political thought? What are its limits? What concept of the individual actor is presupposed by liberal thinkers? Must liberal theories give priority to individual rights? How do liberal theorists conceive of the external world and of man's capability to obtain the type and certainty of knowledge necessary to construct a science of politics?

title: Classics of Rational Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines some of the important works in rational choice theories of politics: Downs, An Economic Theory of Democracy; Olson, The Logic of Collective Action; Axelrod, The Evolution of Cooperation. With this foundation we proceed to examine where theoretical inquiry in political science is heading. The class engages in some experiments, illustrating in hands-on fashion some important political principles. This seminar is especially recommended for those thinking about graduate work in political science or political economy.

title: U.S.-European Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The U.S. and Western Europe from the Marshall Plan to the Maastricht Treaty. Examines the major issues in U.S.-West European relations, including decolonization, integration, German reunification, and relations with the East. Crises in the relationship (Suez, energy, trade, nuclear defense) are analyzed for the light they shed on the evolving role of the Western Alliance in the foreign policies of both partners.

title: U.S.-European Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The U.S. and Western Europe from the Marshall Plan to the Maastricht Treaty. Examines the major issues in U.S.-West European relations, including decolonization, integration, and relations with the East. Crises in the relationship (Suez, energy, trade, nuclear defense) are analyzed for the light they shed on the evolving role of the Western Alliance in the foreign policies of both partners.

title: U.S.-European Relations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The United States and Western Europe from the Marshall Plan to 1992. Examines the major issues in U.S.-European relations, including decolonization, integration, and relations with the Soviet Union. Crises in the relationship (Suez, energy, nuclear defense) analyzed for the light they shed on the evolving role of the Western Alliance in the foreign policies of both partners.

title: Conflict Resolution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The post Cold War world is characterized by continuing international and civil conflicts. Some take place along ethnic lines, some along religious lines, some reflect a total breakdown of the state. Some conflicts persist, while others are seemingly resolved. This course will cover the main approaches to conflict resolution and study some of the salient cases. Topics covered include: theories of conflict and conflict resolution, negotiation, the role of external powers, mediation, and peacekeeping.

Some take place along ethnic lines, some along religious lines, some reflect a total breakdown of the state. Some conflicts persist, while others are seemingly resolved. We cover the main approaches to conflict resolution and study some of the salient cases. Topics include: theories of conflict and conflict resolution, negotiation, the role of external powers, mediation, and peacekeeping.

title: Conflict Resolution
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The post-Cold War world is characterized by continuing international and civil conflicts. Some take place along ethnic lines, some along religious lines, some reflect a total breakdown of the state. Some conflicts persist, while others are seemingly resolved. We cover the main approaches to conflict resolution and study some of the salient cases. Topics include: theories of conflict and conflict resolution, negotiation, the role of external powers, mediation, and peacekeeping.

title: Topics in Law and Political Theory: The Jury, Trial Ethics, and Justice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focusing primarily on the jury, this seminar will explore key contemporary debates about trial justice: What does it mean for the jury to be a "representative'' institution? Is there one justice to represent in the U.S. or only the different views of the different races, sexes, etc.? Are there circumstances where doing justice justifies jurors in disregarding the law? Beyond the jury, the seminar will discuss the ethics of the adversary system and how judges, as well as jurors, know where to find the law.

title: The Politics of Democratization
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How can we understand the process of transition from authoritarian to democratic governance? To examine this question, students will select a country that has undergone or is undergoing democratic transition and explore the relevance of a range of approaches used to explain observed political outcomes. Class reading, discussion, and papers will be organized around students' research projects.

title: The Politics of Democratization

To examine this question, students will select a country that has undergone or is undergoing democratic transition and explore the relevance of a range of approaches used to explain observed political outcomes. title: Democratization and Democracy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Considers theories and practice of democratization, the problems of consolidating new democracies, the relations between economic and political reform, and the comparative performance of democratic and nondemocratic regimes. Social Analysis 24 or equivalent.

title: Congress and the Electoral Connection
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines changing patterns of House and Senate recruitment and election in the 20th century; changing role of "marginal" states and districts; impact of incumbency and money. Some use of empirical data required.

title: American Political Parties: Past and Present
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews current theories of the role and position of political parties in American politics. The development of the two-party system, third-party challenges, and the rise and fall of the parties are the major topics of this course. In addition, the public's attitude toward and support for both the Republican and Democratic parties are examined.

title: Civic Engagement in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Has the United States become a less civically engaged society than it once was? Starting with Alexis de Tocqueville and his times, this seminar considers arguments and evidence about political participation, voluntary associations, interest groups, and democratic governance.

title: Civic Engagement in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Has the United States become a less civically engaged society than it once was? Starting with Alexis de Tocqueville and his times, this seminar considers arguments and evidence about political participation, voluntary associations, interest groups, and democratic governance.

title: Civic Engagement in America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Has the United States become a less civically engaged society than it once was? Starting with Alexis de Tocqueville and his times, this seminar considers arguments and evidence about political participation, voluntary associations, interest groups, and democratic governance.

title: The Politics of Macroeconomic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Deals with the politics of macroeconomic policy, i.e., monetary and fiscal policies and their effects on inflation, unemployment, and income growth. Considers electoral cycle and partisan theories, and the nature of incentives that voters provide for macroeconomic policymaking. Although concrete choices and quantifiable economic performance are considered, the seminar is designed to address broad and abstract questions of democratic theory.

title: State and Society in a Changing Germany
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Germany's social market economy and its underlying ideologies in their European context. Examines the historic foundations of recent economic developments and policies in Germany and how policy-making has changed over time. Its interdisciplinary approach draws on political science, economics, philosophy and sociology. Topics covered include: labor markets, corporate governance and federalism, privatization in East Germany and the implications of European integration.

title: State and Society in a Changing Germany
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A study of Germany's social market economy and its underlying ideologies in their European context. Examines the historic foundations of recent economic developments and policies in Germany and how policy-making has changed over time. Its interdisciplinary approach draws on political science, economics, philosophy and sociology. Topics covered include: labor markets, corporate governance and federalism, privatization in East Germany and the implications of European integration.

title: European Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Deals with a range of topics concerning the interplay of collective identities, socioeconomic interests, and public authority in contemporary European politics: the avatars of regionalism and nationalism; the dilemmas of socioeconomic policy and the changing role of labor; the emergence and stability of democratic institutions; and some of the basic issues to be confronted by the European Community.

title: International Law: Theory and Research
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Addresses advanced issues on the links between international law and international politics. Focus is on theories of international law creation and diffusion, theories of commitment (international law's signaling role) and theories of compliance. Empirical literature includes case studies and quantitative studies in a range of issue areas. Research design and methods are stressed. Grades are based on participation and an individual research paper. Government 1740.

title: International Law: Theory and Research
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Addresses advanced issues on the links between international law and international politics. Focus is on theories of international law creation and diffusion, theories of commitment (international law's signaling role) and theories of compliance. Empirical literature includes case studies and quantitative studies in a range of issue areas. Research design and methods are stressed. Grades are based on participation and an individual research paper. Government 1740.

title: The Concept of Power in International Relations: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Power is a key concept in the study of international relations, yet it is far from self-evident what power exactly is. This course provides a survey of significant conceptualizations of power from a variety of different theoretical perspectives in IR theory, political thought and sociology, ranging from classical texts of IR theory to current debates about forms of power, the meaning of power and its role in world politics.

title: The Concept of Power in International Relations: Seminar
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Power is a key concept in the study of international relations, yet it is far from self-evident what power exactly is. This course provides a survey of significant conceptualizations of power from a variety of different theoretical perspectives in IR theory, political thought and sociology, ranging from classical texts of IR theory to current debates about forms of power, the meaning of power and its role in world politics.

title: Islam in Central and South Asia: Comparative Hegemonies and Liberations
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the histories and current situations of Muslims in Central and South Asia. After sessions on Islam as a religion and as a civilization, it first compares their stories before and during British and Russian/Soviet rule. After a session on today's Middle East and its Islamist extremisms, it then follows the two cohorts to the our complex present. Concluding sessions on the prospects for Islamist extremism among them and the key variables we have discovered.

title: Islam in Central and South Asia: Comparative Hegemonies and Liberations
subject: GOV

title: Democratic Theory and Electoral Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the theoretical dimensions of contemporary controversies about the electoral process in the U.S. Among the topics considered are the right to vote, the regulation of campaign finance, equality in racial districting, free choice in a two-party system, and majoritarianism in the governance of elections. Readings in political theory and election law.

title: Democratic Theory and Electoral Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the theoretical dimensions of contemporary controversies about the electoral process in the U.S. Among the topics considered are the right to vote, the regulation of campaign finance, equality in racial districting, free choice in a two-party system, and majoritarianism in the governance of elections. Readings in political theory and election law.

title: Nationalism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since the rise of the modern era, nationalism has been a powerful force in politics. It has taken several forms, reflecting a variety of principles of national belonging _ language, race, religion, political ideology, geography and shared history. When did nationalism emerge as a force in human history and why? Has it always been a destructive force? Would it disappear in an increasingly global economy? This seminar seeks to answer these questions. Materials will be drawn from Europe, North America, Asia and the former Communist Bloc. Classics of nationalism will be covered.

Among the topics considered are concepts of representation in racial districting, the meaning of free choice in a two-party system, and the limits of majoritarianism in the governance of elections. Readings in political theory and election law.

title: Edmund Burke and Modern Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine the writings of Edmund Burke. Topics to be discussed include: liberty, representation, revolution, imperialism, commerce, and constitutionalism. Readings will include Burke's writings and selected contemporary texts.

title: The Voting Rights of African Americans
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the conflict over extending to African Americans the right to vote. Examines the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment, the efforts of southern whites to deny the rights the Amendment affirmed, and the institution of a one-party system in the South; the subsequent struggle for civil rights and voting rights, culminating in the federal Voting Rights Acts; and the continuing debate over the meaning of political equality and its institutional implications.

title: The Voting Rights of African Americans
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the conflict over extending to African Americans the right to vote. Examines the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment, the efforts of southern whites to deny the rights the Amendment affirmed, and the institution of a one-party system in the South; the subsequent struggle for civil rights and voting rights, culminating in the federal Voting Rights Acts; and the continuing debate over the meaning of political equality and its institutional implications.

title: Ethics and International Relations: Timeless Questions and Modern Dilemmas
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The study of ethics, broadly defined, enables us to assess the means, ends, and consequences of international policy. This seminar explores what is meant by ethics in international relations: Whose ethics - individual human beings, peoples, or states? Which ethics - universal truths or those of the powerful? Both classical thinking (such as Thucydides, Kant, and Mill) and modern writing are used to draw out the 'timeless questions,' which are applied to several contemporary case studies or 'modern dilemmas.'

title: Courts and Public Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of courts and public policy. Emphasis on courts as political institutions, rather than on doctrine. Government 1340 or another law-related course would be helpful.

title: Courts and Public Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of courts and public policy. Emphasis on courts as political institutions, rather than on doctrine. Government 1340 or another law-related course would be helpful.

title: Comparative Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relationship between politics and economics with an emphasis on the way in which institutions condition differences in economic policy and performance across nations. Most cases will be drawn from the nations of Western Europe but some attention will be devoted to other developed polities such as those of the U.S. and Japan.

title: Comparative Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the relationship between politics and economics with an emphasis on the way in which institutions condition differences in economic policy and performance across nations. Most cases will be drawn from the nations of Western Europe but some attention will be devoted to other developed polities such as those of the U.S. and Japan.

title: Comparative Economic Policy Making
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the challenges facing economic policy makers and the process of economic policy making in comparative perspective, focusing on the nations of Western Europe with some reference to other nations. Topics include: alternative analyses of growth and decline; the role of institutions, interests, and ideas in the policy process; explaining change in policy over time; the impact of social organization on policy and performance; alternative conceptions of the impact of politics on the economy.

title: Alliances
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What factors cause the formation, sustain the maintenance, and occasion the breakdown of alliances? The theoretical literature on alliances will be considered against a historical background of alliances from the Athenian and Peloponnesian leagues to NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: Ethics and Biotechnology
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The seminar explores the moral and political implications of recent advances in biotechnology. Topics include cloning, stem cell research, genetic engineering, eugenics, and the patenting of life forms. A previous course in moral reasoning or political theory is recommended.

title: Ethics and Biotechnology
subject: GOV

title: Mexican Politics in Transition
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Overview of the Mexican political system and the social and economic environment (domestic and international) in which it operates. How the modern Mexican political system has developed, competing explanations for the breakdown of the system (1968-present), and how it may continue to evolve along alternative paths. The challenges of rebuilding mass support for a "failed" regime, reforming the electoral system, controlling schisms within the ruling elite, establishing new patterns of government/opposition and state/society relations, and creating an economic development model more consistent with unmet social needs.

title: Mexican Politics in Transition

title: Law and Politics of Affirmative Action
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the origins and development of affirmative action in education and employment. Particular emphasis placed on the political theories courts have used to justify and critique racial preferences.

title: Philosophy and Citizenship
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Ever since the trial and condemnation of Socrates, philosophy and citizenship have been viewed as fundamentally opposed ways of life. Is the kind of open-ended, radical questioning characteristic of the philosopher compatible with allegiance to a particular (and inevitably parochial) moral-political community? Is it possible to be a philosophical citizen, as Socrates proposed? We will consider these and other questions through readings from Thucydides, Plato, Machiavelli, Rousseau, Mill, Nietzsche, Weber, Arendt, Strauss and Walzer.

title: Justice and Work
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Explores understandings of justice as they bear on work. Topics include consent, moral desert, just pay, self-fulfillment, the work ethic, and alienation. Readings drawn from Aristotle, Locke, Marx, Mill, Weber, and contemporary political theorists.

title: Strategies of Tyrants
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will study the writings of ancient and modern political philosophers about tyrants, and use those analyses to develop ideas about the distinctive strategies of tyrants for war. Those ideas will then be tested against historical examples of tyrants engaged in war.

title: Strategies of Tyrants
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course will study the writings of ancient and modern political philosophers about tyrants, and use those analyses to develop ideas about the distinctive strategies of tyrants for war. Those ideas will then be tested against historical examples of tyrants engaged in war.

title: The Political Development of the U.S. South in Cross-National Perspective
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Since World War II, the U. S. South has undergone a remarkable transformation. Once undemocratic, racist, and economically backward, it now features party competition, a new racial politics, and rapid economic growth. This course investigates the political development of the U.S. South in order to grapple with larger questions: How does authoritarianism work? When does democratization occur? How do racial, class, and other identities become politically salient? What special challenges face racially diverse democracies?

title: State and Development
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative examination of the forms, mechanisms, and consequences of different types of state intervention in the process of economic development. Case materials may be drawn from East Asia, Eastern Europe, Russia, Africa, or Latin America.

title: State and Development

title: Democratic Theory in the 20th Century
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Looks at major attempts to examine the nature and problems of mass democracy in the 20th century, including readings from Michels, Schumpeter, Wilson, Lippmann, and Dahl.

title: Economics and Security
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the major theoretical literature relating international security and international political economy. Topics also include markets and national power, economics and security in foreign policy, burden sharing in alliances, and the debate over U.S. decline. A few meetings are devoted to case studies in which the theories are applied to empirical cases.

title: Democracy and the European Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Among the questions we will address: How are decisions made in the EU? What influence do interest groups, voters, and member state legislators have on EU decision-making? What is the 'democratic deficit' and does the EU suffer such a deficit? How are we to compare the EU to other democratic systems? What are the implications of recent EU expansion?

title: Democracy and the European Union
subject: GOV

What is the 'democratic deficit' and does the EU suffer such a deficit? How are we to compare the EU to other democratic systems? What are the implications of recent EU expansion?

title: The State and Economic Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of competing theoretical views of the effects of state intervention in the economy with special emphasis on reconciling these views with empirical case studies of the state's role in economic development and reform.

title: The State, Economic Intervention, and Efficiency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of competing theoretical views of the effects of state intervention in the economy with special emphasis on reconciling these views with empirical case studies of the state's role in economic development and reform.

title: Technology and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Deals with problems of the promotion, management, and transfer of technology and the role of technology in international, political, economic, and security matters.

title: International Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: International law has been variously described as the first step toward the creation of a global society and as a feeble mask for power politics. Some scholars have lauded it as a rational means by which to smooth international conflicts; others have criticized it as a naive attempt to impose order on that which is inherently chaotic. This seminar addresses two overarching questions: (1) How successful has international law been in mediating or resolving conflicts in the international realm? (2) To what extent do considerations of international law affect the foreign policy decisions of modern states?

title: Soviet Policy and Intervention in the Third World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the place of the developing world in Soviet foreign policy, focusing on Soviet policy toward revolution, national liberation, and war. Concentrates on explaining why the Soviet Union intervenes in local conflicts and on understanding the differing forms that its intervention has taken. Also weighs the effects of Soviet policy and behavior on U.S.-Soviet relations, and explores the sources of policy success and failure. The overarching theme is the sources of change and continuity, in order to evaluate the importance of recent shifts in Soviet policy.

title: Soviet Policy and Intervention in the Third World
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes the place of the developing world in Soviet foreign policy, focusing on Soviet policy toward revolution, national liberation, and war. Also weighs the effects of Soviet policy and behavior on U.S.-Soviet relations, and explores the sources of policy success and failure. The overarching theme is the sources of change and continuity, in order to evaluate the importance of recent shifts in Soviet policy.

title: Freud and Politics
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The implications of Freud's work for 20th-century political and social thought.

title: Reform and Reformers in the U.S.S.R
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the roots of policy innovation and reform in nondemocratic states, using the Soviet Union as a case study. Drawing on literature from both "Sovietology" and broader comparative politics, addresses the questions, "Is reform ever inevitable?" and "Did Gorbachev really matter?" Special emphasis on interpreting data and testing hypotheses about the sources of change in nondemocratic systems.

title: Reform and Reformers in the U.S.S.R
subject: GOV

title: Reform and Reformers in the Former Soviet Union
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the roots of policy innovation and reform in nondemocratic states, using as case studies the demise of the Soviet Union and the movement for democratic and market reforms in its successor states. Draws mainly on discussions of the Gorbachev period and its immediate aftermath, but also uses historical cases for comparative study. Attempts through focused class discussion to explore such questions as: "Is reform ever inevitable?" and "Did Gorbachev really matter?"

title: Reform and Reformers in the Former Soviet Union

title: American Foreign Policymaking
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines alternative approaches to the study of American foreign policymaking. Special emphasis placed on the politics of foreign policy innovation.

title: Political Theory in the Age of World Wars
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How the two world wars affected the most significant thinkers of our time - from Weber to Hannah Arendt.

title: Political Agency
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the nature and sources of political agency. What motivates civil disobedience, or tireless advocacy on behalf of the oppressed, or responsible representation, or impartial deliberation, or simple voting? What forms of reason figure in political agency and what sorts of desires and emotions? What is the relationship between the motives that animate political agency and the ideals and identities that orient it? Readings include Kant, Aristotle, Hume, Arendt, Rawls, Habermas, and others.

title: Terrorism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the origins of terrorism, problems of definition, and the challenges posed by terrorists to states. We will explore the psychological, socioeconomic, political, and religious causes of terrorism, and how terrorists' motivations evolve. We will examine the role of fear -- both in leading to terrorism and in influencing responses. We will assess the strengths and weaknesses of a variety of countermeasures, from the point of view of ethics as well as efficacy.

title: Terrorism
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the origins of terrorism, problems of definition, and the challenges posed by terrorists to states. We will explore the psychological, socioeconomic, political, and religious causes of terrorism, and how terrorists' motivations evolve. We will examine the role of fear -- both in leading to terrorism and in influencing responses. We will assess the strengths and weaknesses of a variety of countermeasures, from the point of view of ethics as well as efficacy.

title: Terrorism

title: Crime and Punishment
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course considers the justifications for, and the limits of, the criminal law. Why should one obey its commands? What conduct can justly be criminalized? How much discretion should police, prosecutors, and juries have in enforcing the law? What justifies punishment? We will explore these and related questions in light of controversial cases, including hate speech, sodomy, surrogate motherhood, racial profiling, jury nullification, and the death penalty.

title: Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The Phenomenology of Spirit is one of the most influential and original works in the history of Western thought, embodying radically new ideas about self-hood, history and society. In this course we shall read and attempt to come to terms with it.

title: Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The Phenomenology of Spirit is one of the most influential and original works in the history of Western thought, embodying radically new ideas about self-hood, history and society. In this course we shall read and attempt to come to terms with it.

title: The Politics of Black Urban Regimes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Are there political patterns and dynamics that have been common to city regimes under Afro-American mayors or governing coalitions with a major Afro-American component? And are there policy dynamics and policy issues that have been common under Black urban regimes? Selected features of these queries are addressed, using case studies of cities like Gary, Newark, Atlanta, Washington, East St. Louis, Baltimore, and Cleveland.

title: The Politics of Black Urban Regimes
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Are there political patterns and dynamics that have been common to city regimes under Afro-American mayors or governing coalitions with a major Afro-American component? What is the status of biracial interactions (Blacks vs. Whites, Blacks vs. Hispanics, Blacks vs. Asian Americans) under Black Urban Regimes? Selected features of these queries are addressed, using case studies of cities like Gary, Chicago, Atlanta, Washington, Baltimore, and Cleveland.

title: The Foundations of Law
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of the various intellectual influences that have shaped Western law. Emphasis on the Roman law, the origins of the English common law, and modern conceptions of constitutionalism, with special attention to the origins of the American Constitution.

title: Finding and Using Political Data
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to variety of data sources, current and past, foreign and domestic, in print and in computer archives. Choosing indicators and exploring data. Thinking in terms of dimensions and typologies. Interpreting tables in terms of independence or systematic association, and the question of "spurious" causality. Why relevant populations may be hard to define, but drawing a sample is often easy. How to feel confident about casual effects in regression and simple path models. A largely nontechnical introduction to uses (and abuses) of empirical research, drawing on numerous examples from past research.

title: European Political Economy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the relationship between politics and economics, the nature of economic policymaking, and the problems of economic performance in the principal Western European nations, including Britain, France, Sweden, Germany, and Italy. Object is to illuminate the politics of these nations through the prism of economic issues.

title: Crises and Conflict in the International System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the relation of crises to international politics: When do they happen, how do they arise, how do they develop and escalate, what is their relation to war? Considers the impact of security and insecurity, deterrence and compellence, competition, military power, escalation, misperception, superpower intervention, and the nuclear era. Study of cases from a variety of periods involving different countries.

title: Crisis and Conflict in the International System
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the relation of crises to international politics: When do they happen, how do they arise, how do they develop and escalate, what is their relation to war? title: Public and Private in Political Theory
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: The distinction between public and private life is crucial to limited, liberal politics: privacy protects individual freedom and limits political obligations. But deciding where to draw the line between public and private raises vexing moral issues. Public values penetrate and shape the private sphere, and even such "clearly private'' matters as religion and sexuality have political dimensions. Do ideas like property and personal privacy help us mark off the private sphere? Is the public sphere concerned with justice and the private sphere with the good life? Should we get rid of the public/private distinction?

title: How to Write About Politics: A Practicum
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How can you convey insights from political science to a wider audience? In this course, we explore how to use both analytical and narrative techniques to animate an important topic; to convey a scientific finding; or to express a considered opinion. To this end, we discuss the core components of excellent political writing and workshop ideas and drafts for op-eds, long-form narratives, policy analyses as well as works of data and explainer journalism by members of the class. Readings include Jamelle Bouie, Ta-Nehisi Coates, Jeffrey Goldberg, Jill Lepore, George Orwell, Anne-Marie Slaughter, E. H. Smith, and David Foster Wallace.

title: How to Write About Politics: A Practicum
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: How can you convey insights from political science to a wider audience? In this course, we explore how to use both analytical and narrative techniques to animate an important topic; to convey a scientific finding; or to express a considered opinion. To this end, we discuss the core components of excellent political writing and workshop ideas and drafts for op-eds, long-form narratives, policy analyses as well as works of data and explainer journalism by members of the class. Readings include Jamelle Bouie, Ta-Nehisi Coates, Jeffrey Goldberg, Jill Lepore, George Orwell, Anne-Marie Slaughter, E. H. Smith, and David Foster Wallace.

title: Technology Science Practicum
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This practicum is a capstone to the Technology Science Program, designed to give students the opportunity to conduct original research and write a publication-ready research paper. In consultation with the instructor, students select a concrete technology-society conflict to address, produce autonomous research to analyze it, and provide a set of actionable recommendations or produce appropriate technology to solve it. Throughout the semester, students receive feedback both from their peers and the instructor to aid the development of their projects. Class meetings include the development of writing schedules, discussions focused on framing, analysis, methodology, and peer-review of student projects. Emphasis is placed on issue spotting, academic story-telling and research framing for maximum impact. The course culminates with a formal presentation of the students' projects and papers.

title: War and Peace: Actors, Institutions and Foreign Policy
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: What determines states' decisions for war or peace? This course aims to familiarize students with the major variables, both systemic and unit-level, that we know influence the security policies of states, and also equip them with the necessary tools to conduct research and complete a research paper of their own.

title: Politics of Inequality in Latin America
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Latin America is the most unequal region in the world. Why? And what can be done about it? Topics include the origins and types of inequality, social policies to help the most vulnarable, and tax and corporate policies to restrain the most powerful. The course emphasizes th political effects of inequality, from populism to governmnet dysfunction, and reflects on what wealthy countries with rising inequality like the United States can learn form Latin America.

title: Is Democracy History or Destiny?
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: Democratic theory and practice emerged in specific historical circumstances.  Those circumstances no longer exist, even in the countries where democratic government is most securely established.  What then is democracy's future?  Is it history?  Will China be democratic in fifty years?  Will Egypt?  Will the US?  On what foundations does democratic government rest?  How can we think intelligently about democracy's recurrent crises and the enormous challenges of democratization?

title: Global Distributive Justice
subject: GOV
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines how concerns about socio-economic justice apply beyond the limits of the domestic state. Do we have reason to care about equality at the international level? If so, should we care about the relative standing of individuals, or of nation-states? Who, if anyone, is responsible for addressing global inequalities? Topics covered include the moral relevance of borders, natural resource distribution, immigration policy, climate change, the international status of women, and global institutional design.
